TALK.START.PARA: —Last night I was in the process of arguing that family allowance is probably the single most important measure that a government can take to stress the primacy of the role of families and to relieve some of the social and other devastation that flows from family breakdown. In that context, it is very important that we address the purposes of family allowance to consider to what extent it ought to be increased rather than reduced. The legacy of this Government is that since it came to power it has presided over a failure to index family allowances to the point where about $6.8 billion has not been paid that would otherwise have been paid if the amount had been indexed over the period from 1978 to the present. That is a testimony to the Government's concern for families.

PARA.TAB: The measure that is presently contained in the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991, and which is undoubtedly the most significant of the measures, is the proposal to introduce an assets test. As will be well known in this place, we have always placed great store on horizontal equity and the necessity to recognise that families on identical levels of income with dependants have more expenditure obligations than those without. Therefore, in most circumstances we think that it is important to recognise that by the payment of family allowances. There are those who would argue that the burden of bringing up children is so important that it ought be recognised irrespective of levels of income and assets.

An income test has been in place for some years and that is a recognition that there ought to be a cut-off point. The need to avoid the distortions that flow from having only income tests in place has led to the need for the introduction of an assets test. Whilst that has been a matter of some anguish on this side of the Parliament, nonetheless there has been a very general recognition that it is important to have a balanced means test in place and that that therefore necessitates the introduction of an assets test at a reasonable level.

The original Government proposal contained in the 1990 Budget was for simply a limit of $300,000 with no exceptions to that principle. That clearly would have wrought very great hardship on people, particularly in rural areas, who find themselves asset rich but income poor for factors, in most instances, which are well beyond their control. Quite rightly, the community and the Parliament ultimately rejected that fairly crude attempt to impose an assets test, irrespective of the circumstances of those who might have been affected by it. The Government did belatedly concede to that concern by raising the limit to $500,000. But it was still an arbitrary limit and ultimately it was rejected by the Parliament.

The measure before us now contains a number of significantly improved features. In particular, the inclusion of hardship clauses means that even if one has assets in excess of $600,000, one can still qualify for the payment of family allowances. Even Wilson Tuckey, my colleague in the other place who felt so strongly about this proposal to cross the floor, nonetheless recognised in the amendment that he moved that there was a need to have a cut off point. His preference of $2m was related to the relevant rate of return that one is presumed to get before losing the family allowance on the basis of the income test. But, nonetheless, even Mr Tuckey recognised that fact. I think the overwhelming view in the community is that there ought to be a limit. The argument is really where the line ought to be drawn and to what extent there ought to be exceptions.

The Government's hardship proposals, in principle, did meet those original concerns but there were still a number of areas that needed to be fleshed out. In particular, I refer to the two legs of hardship—family income at the level of approximately $13,078, with an increment for children, and liquid assets of less than $10,000 for a family group. The residual clause that picked up any other readily realisable assets of people caused quite a deal of concern in the initial stages.

Since that time, there have been extensive negotiations and correspondence with the office of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson). I have to say that I believe the Minister has approached this matter in a very sensible and realistic manner, to the point where we now have firm undertakings, by way of letter, that there will be exemptions for both tools of trade and working capital. Therefore, we have reached the stage where those people who have assets that are a necessary part of earning an assessable income—in particular, from rural activities—will find that those assets, liquid or otherwise, will not be held against them. Only those people who have genuinely surplus funds, which are not necessary for their immediate income earning activities, will be caught by this test.

That is a fair and reasonable approach. It has taken quite a deal to get there but at the end of the day the way in which the Minister has expressed those principles is satisfactory. But we will need to wait until we finally see the guidelines which will be introduced. I will be urging—and I take this opportunity to require—the Minister to table those guidelines in this place when they become available. I would also be seeking an assurance from the Minister that he will give the Parliament due notice in the event that any change to those guidelines is proposed.

If we obtain those assurances we will have assuaged the concerns of many people, particularly those in rural areas, who have been very concerned indeed that moneys that were necessarily quarantined for farming activities will not be held against them. Having reached that point, I cannot believe that the Minister would want to surreptitiously change the guidelines or somehow dramatically disadvantage rural families by watering down the provisions in relation to working capital.

I assume that the good faith will continue, that we will have these guidelines tabled. If we do not, I will table them in due course. Nonetheless, I am sure the Minister will be anxious to keep faith and to consolidate the expanded provisions that are proposed to be put in place. On that basis, we have reached a pretty satisfactory resolution of most of the outstanding matters.

I want to express a couple of other concerns. It is not clear to me why the hardship provision should operate only for a two-year period. One can understand the extent of the Government's anguish at the fact that it has been responsible for causing `the most serious recession in 60 years', to use the phrase of the current Treasurer (Mr Kerin). There is no doubt that the Government is continuing, and will continue, to pay dearly for the social devastation that it has deliberately chosen to inflict upon many thousands of Australians.

I hope that when the history books come to be written and the role of Mr Keating is properly analysed this will be seen as an enduring legacy of misery and an albatross that ought to be around his neck for many years to come, and that his ability to mesmerise the press gallery and to punish ordinary Australians will be kept in context.

So it does not seem to make a great deal of sense simply to have a hardship provision that will, hopefully, take one through the current recession because there will clearly be people beyond that point who are in hardship for whatever reason, whether it is a cyclical downturn in the economy, a fall in particular commodity prices or other factors operating in rural areas or in small business in the cities. It does not make a great deal of sense to limit the application of hardship provisions for that length of time.

Indeed, when I look at what the Minister says to me by way of draft response—initially two years is a reasonable time for the operation of the hardship provisions as this will allow time for the provisions to settle in and to be properly evaluated—it is clear that he really does not have a good argument for removing the sunset clause either. He is simply saying, `We will have a look at it down the track'. However, he has not advanced any reason of logic or principle on why hardship provisions should not continue to be available. So in due course we will be moving an amendment to delete that sunset clause.

I do not want to dwell on the other aspects of this package, other than to indicate that we will also be moving an amendment to oppose the provisions on the reduction in waiting periods for rent assistance. The Government is acknowledging the fact that many hundreds of thousands of Australians find themselves in need of welfare as a result of the current recession. Those numbers will have a very significant impact on the Budget.

To the extent that there are people in additional hardship, then those needs ought to be recognised in a tangible way. But it does not follow from that recognition that there is a need to reduce waiting periods for rent assistance. Those people are in the same situation as similar people might have been in good times. The principle of a waiting period, if one assumes its validity, is not compromised by the fact that there are many more people in the same situation. Individual circumstances do not warrant any reduction in the waiting periods unless we take the view that waiting periods per se ought to be removed. That is the view of the Democrats and groups such as VCOSS, but it is not our view, and I do not think it is the Government's view.

We really cannot understand why the Government wants to make this change, other than perhaps to appease some of the concerns for the failings of its policies and to be able to suggest that somehow it is doing something. Other than that, we will be supporting the Bill subject to those amendments.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crowley)—I call Senator Lees.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I am sorry to interrupt. I understand there has been a slight change in arrangements. If it is all right with Senator Lees, we will allow her speech to go ahead and adjourn the debate at the end of her speech. I give notice to the chamber that at the end of Senator Lees's speech I will be moving to adjourn this debate.
—Tell us why.
—Senator Durack asked us to do so; that is the agreement with the Opposition. It is not our initiative.
—It is to debate the Federal Court of Australia Amendment Bill.
—I was on my way around to tell the Whip, when the previous speaker finished a little earlier than we had thought. It is on the basis of an agreement with the Opposition.

—Does that mean that we will complete the Federal Court of Australia Amendment Bill and we will resume the debate on the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill so that the period of time that is currently available for the Democrats to consider their position in relation to the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill will not be compromised?

—There is an agreement with the Opposition and the Democrats about sequencing and we will not be proceeding, after the Federal Court Bill, straight back to the transport and communications Bill. I was about to tell the Opposition Whip what it was about, but we got caught a little short by Senator Alston's speech finishing earlier than anticipated. It is a reflection of an agreement negotiated between the Whips and we are simply acting to implement that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) implements a number of changes to the Social Security Act, most of which were announced in this year's Budget. The changes that I am most concerned about are the introduction of an assets test on family allowance; changes to the current assets test for the family allowance supplement; and the introduction of new financial hardship rules for both the family allowance and the family allowance supplement. I will discuss those matters later.

PARA.TAB: I will briefly mention a couple of very positive moves. Firstly, we have seen the introduction of a special child bereavement allowance which enables payment of family allowance, child disability allowance and double orphan pension to continue to be paid to parents or guardians for four weeks after the death of a child. These changes came as a result of the Strathfield tragedy, and I congratulate the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) for this move.

The Bill also provides for sole parent pensioners to receive an education entry payment, another very positive step. The payment is $200 each calendar year to assist with education costs. Persons who qualify for the payment have to be sole parents, must be enrolled in a course of study and must be eligible for Austudy. I argue that rather than being a cost to the community, this is in fact a saving. It will enable these people to move more readily out to open employment as they will have improved qualifications.

The Bill extends the qualifications for Jobsearch and sickness allowance for young persons. This is really a very welcome and a long overdue move. The definition of an independent young person will be changed to include a 13 week registration with the CES any time in the previous six months. The conditions previously were so harsh that very few young people actually made it into the system and were able to gain support. This move has come after a lot of lobbying from bodies such as the Brotherhood of St Laurence and ACOSS in particular.

The Jobsearch allowance will also be extended to 15-year-olds in certain circumstances, enabling them to become eligible for transition to work incentives. The independent rate will be extended to 16- and 17-year-olds who are being cared for by persons other than their parents.

The Democrats welcome and support these moves. Earlier this year the Brotherhood of St Laurence released a paper, entitled Policy Issues for Social Security, which found that the most severe poverty caused by inadequate income support payments is that of young people, particularly those living away from home. It has been reiterated many times in this place that young unemployed people are suffering terribly as a consequence of this recession. The Democrats have consistently opposed reductions in young people's statutory incomes and although that situation, unfortunately, continues at least these measures make access to an income easier for some young unemployed.

The Bill also provides for the extension of the availability of rent assistance to young people under 18 and a reduction in the rent assistance waiting period from 26 weeks to 18 weeks for people without dependent children. The Democrats have been calling for this for quite some time as a wealth of evidence, again from the welfare agencies, has shown that these arbitrary waiting periods have been causing considerable hardship. Rent assistance is vital where people on low incomes are trying to survive in the private rental market. This measure is a recognition of the unfairness that this lengthy waiting period has been causing. I would like to see this waiting period end, as has been mentioned by Senator Alston, but at least we have some improvement; it is a step in the right direction.

I would like to concentrate on the changes affecting farming families. At last the Government has recognised that rural Australia is in deep trouble and that farming families are in crisis. It seems to me that there has been a great deal of reluctance on the part of the Labor Party to acknowledge this crisis—I presume that that is because farmers have never been its natural constituency. However, one only needs to spend some time in rural areas to appreciate that poverty and hardship there is as great as, if not worse than, anywhere else in this country at the moment.

It is time to stop talking; it is time to start offering positive assistance. In preparing for this speech I went back through the Hansards of the last few months. Almost everybody in here has at some stage mentioned the problems being faced by rural Australia. In particular, there have been a number of very long and eloquent speeches outlining the problems being faced in our rural communities. Time and time again we have discussed economic and social hardship in country areas. We have talked about declining farms incomes and the falling return on farm assets—it is down to 0.3 per cent in 1991, according to the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics. We have talked about the escalating farm debt; more and more foreclosures; the increase in suicides in rural areas; marriage breakdown; children unable to continue secondary school, let alone go on to university, et cetera.

We all know that this crisis is unparalleled in post war Australia. Our rural communities are attempting to deal with an unprecedented range of circumstances coming together. This is causing farm incomes to drop to zero and well below. High interest rates, government policies, the slump in commodity and stock prices and drought—a drought which is now estimated to be affecting 60 per cent of eastern Australia—have combined to leave rural Australia in despair.

For example, in the Australian on 11 November 1991 there was a story about the plight of the town of Jericho in central Queensland. The local shire doctor, Melissa Buttini, tells a tale that is common virtually wherever one goes in rural Australia these days. The article states:

"We've begun hearing terrible stories—we've had families who couldn't put food on the table, women who can't afford contraceptives, patients who can't afford to have scripts made up," she told the Australian.
I've one patient 38 weeks' pregnant and with a young kid and because her husband's away working for a wage, trying to keep things together, she's had to be pulling cattle out of dams.
I've got a colleague at another town who said the other day `at least the men haven't started shooting themselves yet', but I've had people come in so stressed they talk about suicide.

SPEECH.PARA: I hear these sorts of comments over and over again as I travel in rural Australia, particularly in rural South Australia.

PARA.TAB: Rural Australia is hurting very badly and farm families need more than just talk. They do not need to put up with any more hand wringing and crocodile tears or listen to any more speeches. What they need is policies, and they need them to be put into action.

The Democrats have a three-step proposal for assisting rural Australia. The first thing we need to do is stabilise the situation. That basically involves a moratorium on all foreclosures; access to income support as needed; further cuts in interest rates; a stop to cutting tariffs and other support, because the farmers are receiving absolutely nothing in return; and the maintenance of community services in rural areas.

The second step is to set the framework for future stability. This involves debt restructuring—and, for that, legislation is needed—re-regulation of the financial markets and regional development planning.

The third step involves active and intelligent support from government and strategies that support and promote sectors in which we can thrive, including investment incentives, value adding to primary products and, in particular, supporting Australian research and development. We need import replacement; we need strong and effective anti-dumping legislation; and we need to encourage the population to remain in rural areas. Indeed, we need to look again at the whole idea of decentralisation.

This shows that access to income support is only one very small part of this overall plan. It is just one of the pressing needs and it is a need that will give breathing space to rural people. This brings me to the family allowance, the assets test that the Government is putting on it today, and the family allowance supplement.

It was with great interest that I heard Senator Alston say that he has assurances from Government that this assets test will not harm rural Australia. I argue that we need far more than just assurances. We need to have very specific, stipulated guidelines put into this Bill that show very clearly that the tools of trade are not included in this assets test. It is no good relying on a letter from the Minister and on a few reassuring words. What we need is legislation in place that specifically excludes the family farm from the assets test.

I have no problem with an assets test on luxury items—if, indeed, any farm families still have them. It will certainly catch those elsewhere in Australia who still maintain their second or third block of flats somewhere, units on the Gold Coast or perhaps luxury yachts on Sydney Harbour. Fair enough, include those in the assets test, but it is not fair enough to include farm and small business assets.

Last year, we were able to combine with the Liberal Party of Australia because it supported us in keeping the assets test off family allowance. At that time a lot was said about the fact that families deserved some support for the additional cost of raising children. We wonder what has changed since last year so that we are now looking at an assets test that includes the family farm. We are certainly still talking about a rural sector in crisis. Indeed, some would argue that the situation is even worse than at the time we had this debate last year. What has changed? Yes, the Government has introduced long overdue hardship provisions, but are these adequate?

I note with interest that the Liberal Party will be moving to take the sunset clause off and, of course, we will be supporting it. But that is only tampering with the edges; tinkering around. What we need to do is make certain, and give the farm community some certainty, that the tools of trade will not be included in this assets test. The only way we can do that is to amend legislation. I will be moving a specific amendment aimed at ensuring that there is no consideration of the family farm in that assets test, and a separate amendment which will also remove from the assets test the tools required by other small business people.

The hardship provisions in the Bill also provide some additional access to family allowance supplement. What will happen is that some low income families with limited available funds or liquid assets will still qualify for family allowance and family allowance supplement under this package if their net assets are under $600,000; their income is below the married benefit rate of $13,000; and their available liquid funds do not exceed $10,000 for a married couple, or $6,000 for a single person.

Following the introduction of the assets test on family allowance, families with assets over that $600,000 threshold can still get family allowance if they meet the same requirements; in other words, that they do not have an income over $13,078 and that their liquid assets are under that figure.

These changes will certainly improve access for some families to FAS. However, the assets test introduced on family allowance will deny it to many farming families who have previously received it and relied upon it. I do not believe it is good enough simply to rely on the Minister's word that there will be no hardship. I believe we need to see changes in this legislation. For a great many farming families, family allowances meant that they could feed their children and, as the President of the National Farmers Federation recently pointed out, the real challenge is not only keeping people on their farms but also ensuring that people get enough money to feed their families.

On Monday I met with three women from the Murray Valley in New South Wales who were in Canberra to put their view on how rural women were coping and the actual views of rural women in the Murray Valley region to politicians. This group provided me with a number of case studies. Again, the stories are all too familiar. They match those in other parts of the country. I refer in particular to a letter from Jan Outram. She says:

SPEECH.PARA: For many people in the electorate of Farrer the Family Allowance has been the difference between being able to afford to buy groceries or not. I would like to quote the case of two families in our district.

Family 1: One partner of the farm has a limited amount of relief teaching to cover household expenses but come Christmas holidays when there is six weeks of nil income, she relies wholly and solely on the Family Allowance to feed their family of five.

For the second family, the family allowance was previously able to be put away for such essentials—maybe these days they are luxuries—as school fees and compulsory school uniforms. Today, that family is relying on their family allowance to put food on the table. She also mentions a third case history:

In the past twelve months we have drawn upon the family savings that our parents have put away for their retirement. Instead of having an adequate retirement that they planned for since the day their own children became independent, they will now be financially dependent upon us until death.

We are now raising the fourth generation on this farm. With this generation seeing it harder and harder to make a decent living. We are no longer able to build upon our assets and our income is decreasing each year. We do not need the added burden of assets testing to get a Family Allowance payment to meet weekly household expenses.

This group also made the point, one we have been arguing for quite some time, that farming families need their assets to earn their living. They cannot sell off a piece of the farm here or borrow even more money just to put food on the table. I accept that taxable income is not always the best way to determine who needs support, but I would argue very strongly that we are looking at a sector that is earning this year, on estimate, 0.3 per cent on its assets, and that is certainly a good way to determine who should and who should not receive support.

PARA.TAB: It is not just rural women who are disadvantaged in so many ways by our superannuation and taxation systems. There is a continuing unwillingness to recognise the value of women's unpaid work, particularly when it comes to caring at home for children. Family allowance—and, prior to that, the child endowment support system—has been seen as one small way of addressing these inequities. The acceptance of the assets test clearly signals the end to the notion that the family allowance is not a welfare payment. I guess we could argue that with an income test put on it we certainly moved in that direction previously.

If we have to trim the fat because of this country's dire economic circumstances, there are many in the community who are asking why it should be Australia's children who are paying and, in particular, why our rural children. It is for these reasons the Australian Democrats will be opposing the assets test on family allowance.

Some Opposition members like to go out into rural areas and portray the Democrats as people who do not understand what is happening. But I would argue very strongly that we have been consistent on these issues. We do understand very well what is happening in rural Australia and I would argue strongly that rural Australians have indeed been abandoned by those politicians they have looked to for many years.

The Government's inability to realise that this is just another example of its lack of understanding about what is happening to the community beyond this place and beyond the offices of Cabinet Ministers is really amazing. As I said, the Democrats will be opposing the introduction of the assets test on family allowance. If that move is unsuccessful, I will be moving two specific amendments. One amendment will remove the assets test on the family farm, and the second amendment will remove the assets test for other small business people. The final amendments I will be moving will exempt work related assets from other assets tests under the Social Security Act.

We are particularly concerned that we should be providing farm families with access to various means of income support available under that Act. Once again in my travels through rural Australia, I have heard many similar stories about farmers being unable to get any sort of income support. One story that keeps cropping up is that of women from farming families who have separated, who have moved off the farm and who cannot—because they still have a share in that farm—gain any access to income support at all. These women, usually with dependent children, are not able to be supported by the father because he does not have an adequate income himself—in other words, the spouse cannot pay any maintenance.

Similarly, I have received a number of letters and had phone calls from elderly people who cannot access the age pension because they still have an interest in the property on which they may have retired. In some cases, they have retired to nearby towns. They cannot now divest this asset. They cannot now pass it onto their children, to the generation that is now working the farm, because they will be caught by deeming provisions.

There is some provision in the Social Security Act to pay a pension or benefit. The Act makes reference to `if the asset is unrealisable'. What this has basically meant is that people have had to put the farm on the market. The Government has addressed this very recently. I understand there will be legislation before this place in a matter of a week or so that will move to give a few farmers access, and this special income support package is specifically for those facing severe hardship. However, it is going to give very, very limited access to unemployment benefits for very few farmers. It will still involve a considerable amount of red tape. A phone call I received yesterday from Queensland highlighted that many farmers cannot wait the months and months it will take for this benefit to be put in place. If the assets test were now to be taken off for farm families, it would give them access immediately to a variety of benefits.

This new measure the Government is planning for unemployment benefits apparently will let in about 2,000 farmers throughout the country. A United Farmers and Stock Owners handout from South Australia asks:

SPEECH.PARA: How big is the problem? To date, the Government, both State and Federal, and the major parties, both Liberal and Labor, have failed to understand the size of the problem. As an illustration, the latest changes to the Commonwealth's roads program will, according to the Government's own costings, benefit 300 or 400 families in this State, not the 10,000 who need it.

So I would argue very strongly that the Government's package is inadequate. What the Opposition is suggesting—that is, that we rely on a couple of letters and comments from the Minister—is totally inadequate. We need to see in this legislation specific statements that mean the family farm is excluded from the assets test.

PARA.TAB: Once again, I urge Opposition senators to give our amendments some serious consideration. There are two specific amendments and each of them will be moved three times. The first is to remove the assets test for farm families for family allowance; then off family allowance supplement; and, finally, from other pensions and benefits. The second amendment does the same thing for small business people, removing the assets they need to run their business from the assets test for family allowance, family allowance supplement, and then for other pensions and benefits. I argue that we need to redress an injustice that has already existed for far too long, to the detriment of not only farmers and their children but also this country as a whole.
Debate (on motion by Senator McMullan) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: FEDERAL COURT OF AUSTRALIA AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 12 September, on motion by Senator Tate:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Federal Court of Australia Amendment Bill seeks to implement a number of proposals by the Government which will make major changes to our legal system. The Bill seeks to amend the Federal Court of Australia Act and introduce into the Federal jurisdiction, but not into State jurisdiction, the concept of class actions, which has been a feature of the American legal system for many years. However, that is a form of legal proceeding which has never been known in the English legal system, either in the United Kingdom or in Australia; it has also not been taken up in the European legal system in the same form as it appears in the American system. Therefore, the Government's proposals involve major, some would even say revolutionary, changes.

PARA.TAB: The idea of adopting in Australia the American system of class actions has been debated here for many years. The reason for the action is said to be the problem that occurs when there are a number of litigants or potential litigants with small claims, the total of which could involve a very large amount indeed. There is always the likelihood that few claimants will commence proceedings at all on their own account because it would be too costly; in other words, it would be too difficult for them to join together in any form of group action, and anyway if a number did pursue their own claims there would be a multiplicity of actions. It is said that the American system, which enables one person to bring an action on behalf of a large number of others who have a similar type of claim arising out of some action or inaction by the defendant, is the answer to the problem.

Those who have debated the subject for many years and who are not so impressed with it believe that that problem is greatly overstated. No doubt it was this sort of concern and type of debate that persuaded my predecessor as Attorney-General, Bob Ellicott, to give a reference on this subject to the Law Reform Commission in February 1977. It is interesting to look at the history of the matter in the Commission. The Commission, which was then under the chairmanship of Mr Justice Kirby, as he then was, was not averse to making major changes to the legal system. There was a lot of sympathy for that sort of thing in the Commission.

However, the Commission deliberated on this subject for nearly 12 years before it reported. The reference was made in February 1977 and the report was delivered to the Government on 1 October 1988. It was not tabled in the Parliament until 21 December 1988, so almost 12 years elapsed while the Commission deliberated on the problem which it had been given by Bob Ellicott. I do not think it is any secret that the Commission had considerable difficulty in coping with this question or in coming to any conclusions about the appropriate way of dealing with the problem. It did not have difficulty in coping with many other legal problems that it was given by way of references. Indeed, I gave the Commission a number of references when I was Attorney-General, as has the present Government. Although the Commission's reports took time, because it was appropriate that the matters should be properly considered, I am unaware of any other report that took such a long time as the one on the subject of class actions.

It is quite clear that the Law Reform Commission was considerably divided on the subject. Indeed, a former commissioner, who was assigned a major responsibility for a time with this reference, wrote an article on the subject in the Australian Law Journal as long ago as 1980 which perhaps reflected the problem that faced the Commission. Therefore, this Government's proposal is by no means self-evident. It has caused great difficulty and a great deal of debate for those who have thought about the matter. I regret to say that it will cause a great deal of division of opinion in this chamber and in another place, if it ever gets there, because the Opposition will oppose the legislation. If that fails, we will propose a number of amendments to the Bill which we hope will give it a more acceptable face.

However, before I discuss those matters, I would like to deal with the issues themselves and examine whether the Government's proposals should be supported. As I have said, the question with which this legislation deals has had a long gestation. Many had hoped that it would have been stillborn and would not have been brought into the Senate. A number of people would even go so far as to say that it is a monstrosity. To some extent the Government gives some colour to that concern because the speech by the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) on this Bill is remarkably bland. It is almost as if he is trying to hide this creature to which the Law Reform Commission gave birth.

It is interesting to reflect that, after all these years of struggle in the Law Reform Commission, it was only after Justice Evatt was appointed President of the Commission that this matter suddenly took new life. No doubt she was the driving force in the report of the Commission which advocated what it calls group proceedings, with all sorts of extensions of Federal jurisdiction and revolutionary proposals about contingency fees, assistance funds and so on.

TALK.START.PARA: —We don't accept those.

—I give credit where it is due. I know that he has not fallen for the full Evatt program, and thank God he did not. No doubt support from the Australian Democrats might have been more enthusiastic if he had done so. It really is one of those rather loony proposals that come up from time to time from commissions like the Law Reform Commission. I am glad that the Government has not gone the whole way with it. However, unfortunately I believe that the Government has gone too far. The Opposition is not implacably opposed to trying to solve the problem. Our amendments indicate that we have an alternative proposal which does not go anywhere near as far as the Government's proposals. But we feel that our proposal would command a great deal more support both in the legal and business world and would achieve the same purpose, and I will deal with that in a little more detail later.

PARA.TAB: The Minister's second reading speech to this Bill is interesting. The Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: The new representative proceeding provided in the Bill is based on the existing representative action procedure in the Federal Court and in State Supreme Courts.

I regret to say that statement is simply not correct. Where one person can bring an action in a court not on behalf of himself and specified people, no matter how many there may be, is a representative action. But for a person to be able to bring an action where he or she purports to bring it on behalf of an uncertain number of people, not specified in any way, except in general terms that they would have a common interest, where the ultimate judgment is for a sum of money which does not reflect accurately the damages established by all those people—many of whom would not even know the procedures on foot, yet their rights would be very considerably affected as we will also see in this debate—is something quite different.

PARA.TAB: That is why I have called the Minister's speech bland. Were I allowed to in this chamber—which I probably would not be—I would refer to it in an even less flattering way than that, given that the Minister says that the legislation is based on existing representative actions available in our existing system. The Minister does say—I have already commended this—that he has not adopted the Law Reform Commission's group proceedings approach or the extension of the jurisdiction of the Federal Court of Australia for such proceedings. I am in two minds about the question of the extension of jurisdiction in this area. I will say something about that in a moment as well.

It is very bland and misleading to say that the Government has not adopted the Commission's group proceedings. It may be that that is literally true, given the special definition in the report. The fact of the matter is that the Government has adopted a proceeding which is basically the same proposal. Let us not mince words about it. It is a question of whether we are having a class action along the lines of the American system or whether we will seek to improve the existing representative action that has long standing and experience in our legal system.

I have already indicated the problems which this Bill seeks to address. As I said, the problem is that a number of people with claims arising out of a very similar set of circumstances, perhaps in cases created by one defendant, have to have a multiplicity of action. Some people do not even start the cases at all and it is alleged that there has been an injustice. Our legal system—based on the United Kingdom system, which includes the English and Scottish system, and the European system—has a different solution to the problem; namely, representative action.

The real problem in this case is that the representative action approach was not working as well as it could about the time that this debate started in Australia. Although I cannot speak for him, when my former colleague Bob Ellicott gave this reference I think he may well have had it in mind that something less ambitious and less revolutionary than the pure American class action might have been the solution. I know that he used the words `class action' in his reference. I think that was unfortunate. I certainly would not have used that expression had I been giving the Law Reform Commission a reference. Nevertheless, I think there are other ways of looking at it.

Clearly, the Minister seems to think that representative actions would be some sort of solution, but, unfortunately, as I said, they were not working very well in the 1970s when this debate was going on. Since then there have been major improvements in representative action. The person starting the representative action has to be specific as to the people he is representing. That seems to be a reasonable proposition. A representative action also had some procedural limitations as to the sorts of claims that could be brought under it. That is something that has now been overcome both in England and in Australia in some of the State jurisdictions and certainly in the Federal jurisdictions.

I believe that the Government and the Minister do not fully appreciate the extent of the improvements that have now been made in some cases by legislation but mainly by rules of court and the decisions of judges. The representative action has now reached a stage where, if a government introduced this legislation by a statute—I am certainly not objecting to that—in relation to the Federal Court in a different way, we would not have any objection to it. Indeed, quite recently a judge of the Federal Court, Mr Justice Wilcox, using the Federal Court rules, allowed a claim where 116 people were in a group on behalf of whom the claim was being brought. We cannot say that a representative action is something that is not workable where there are a large number of plaintiffs.

Let me summarise the objections that we have to this approach to the class action. Firstly, in our view, it is unnecessary because the representative action can be extended and improved, if necessary, to do the job. I believe that if we adopted that system in the Federal Court of Australia Act the State jurisdictions that have not brought their system up to date would follow suit. Indeed, with the cross-vesting now available as a solution to these conflicts of jurisdiction, Federal and State, I would have no objection to the whole thing applying through the cross-vesting system which does not occur in this legislation.

Secondly, it is a totally new concept for our legal system and it has not been adopted in legal systems in the United Kingdom or the European Community. This legislation seems to be part and parcel of the Government's proposals for a new product liability law, greatly extending the availability and easing the proof of product liability claims, which has frightened a large number of people.

I am pleased to see that the Minister indicated only the other day that he proposes to modify those rather unfortunate proposals that were made. I wonder why the Minister, when he took such a positive step in those cases, does not also reconsider this proposal. The two are combined. They are certainly combined in the minds of those small sections of the community which are pushing very hard. They wanted this easy product liability law and the class action in order to enforce new and easy methods of proof.

The third objection against this legislation is that it will introduce new and uncertain burdens on our court system. As I said, it is a revolutionary proposal. It will encourage more litigation. Fortunately, as the Government has not picked up some of the other aspects, the legislation may not encourage more litigation as much as Justice Evatt and the Law Reform Commission's proposals would have done. We already have an enormous expansion of work in the court system, both Federal and State. We are training more and more lawyers and we are starting to become a community nearly as legally driven as is the United States community. I do not think we ought to be encouraging this system any further. This sort of new facility will only add to the work of the courts and the cost of litigation, and it will be a bonanza for lawyers.

The fourth objection to this legislation is one which I have already touched on: it will be available only under Federal jurisdiction. I am very surprised that the Government would take this retrograde step. For years, including when we were in government, we have been looking—as has this Government, the former Attorneys-General, particularly Mr Lionel Bowen, and I am sure Senator Tate as well—at ways and means to minimise the problem of having Federal and State jurisdictions.

If people want to copy the American system, as they are doing here, they ought to look at the terrible confusion that has always been the case in America which is caused by having a Federal court system and a State court system. When we set up the Federal Court we started down that track. It soon became evident to us when we were in government—and it was clearly evident to Mr Lionel Bowen—that it was not a sensible direction in which to go and that we needed to bring the Federal and State jurisdictions together. One of the really commendable reforms to our legal system by this Government —the proposal came out of the constitutional convention process, but was taken up by Mr Lionel Bowen—was the very radical proposal to have cross-vesting of jurisdiction between Federal and State courts.

I have not been close enough to see how the legal system has been operating in recent years, but I understand it is working very well and has ironed out most of the problems. Yet a Bill has been brought in which goes in quite the reverse direction. In this Bill, the Government is saying that this new proceeding will not be available where the Federal Court gets jurisdiction under the cross-vesting legislation. We ought to be moving further. Having recognised the problem, the Government ought to be moving to integrate totally our court system in Australia and get rid of Federal and State conflicts completely if we possibly can. We were going in the right direction; I think this is going backwards.

Another objection to these proposals—which is perhaps on a more philosophical plane—is that the class action can be brought on behalf of people who do not know about it. People are given a chance to opt out if they do know about it, are not happy with it and want to conduct their own proceedings. That is a redeeming feature of this Bill. But most class actions will be taken on behalf of an indeterminate number of people, and a lot of people will be brought in and have their legal rights determined without even knowing that this is occurring. In many cases, they will not care. Our court system is based on the fact that individuals make their own decisions to initiate proceedings; it is done by the conscious decisions of individuals. That is what ought to happen; people ought to take responsibility for whether they want to start proceedings. But under this Bill they become part of a system without knowing, or perhaps even caring. It really goes against the philosophical basis of our legal system and affects the individual rights of people to make those decisions.

Of course, additional costs and expenses will be imposed upon unsuccessful defendants. If plaintiffs succeed in these cases, large sums of money will have to be determined and made available. When judgments are made, notices will go out to the newspapers far and wide. Under the American system, when claims have been settled, judges have awarded rights to people in Australia and all parts of the world. They receive notices and they can come in and get their cut of the cake.

This will clearly create additional costs for business—for example, higher insurance costs—which will be passed on to the consumer. The average consumer could well be worse off because of the higher prices he or she will have to pay for goods in order to cover these costs. This legislation is said to be in favour of the consumer and those few people who have not themselves bothered to take any action about their claimed loss. It may be of benefit to those people—and, as I have said, those people do not need to be in Australia, if the American system is any guide—but the ordinary, average consumer will probably pay more as a result of this facility which the Government is proposing.

I believe it is pretty clear that the Government is yet again giving in to a very vocal, noisy lobby group in the consumer area. There is an element in this area, like there is in the green movement, which proposes extreme solutions to problems. Clearly, there are problems with consumer rights. I am not saying that they should not be attended to, but there is a point at which these things can be taken too far. The Government has clearly given in—it probably believes it survived in the last election only because it pandered to the extreme greenies. It is pandering to these very noisy elements in the consumer movement and hopes to survive by pleasing a few of them.

There is a host of reasons—legal, practical, philosophical and political—why this Bill should not be passed in its present form. Because the Bill seems to the Opposition to be going along the wrong course, we will oppose the second reading of it. However, if we do not succeed in that regard, we have circulated a number of amendments and I will explain our alternative if that comes about.

In brief, we are saying that instead of having a system where an indeterminate number of people, unbeknownst to them, can be swept up in litigation, only having the right to opt out if they happen to learn about it—and that may not be the case—the Government should have introduced a system which would improve the representative action and give people the right to opt in to an action which had been commenced on behalf of the group. A person might start off representing 100 people, but find that a few more want to join—maybe even another 100 people.That is basically our alternative proposal. I hope the Senate will consider that and pass it in place of the Government's proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats welcome and support the Federal Court of Australia Amendment Bill 1991. Indeed, we congratulate the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) and his Department for bringing it before the Senate. We are strong advocates of the concept of group proceedings, as provided for in this legislation. Indeed, if we have a criticism to make, it is that this Bill is long overdue.

PARA.TAB: The process which has led to its introduction began in February 1977 when the then Fraser Government asked the Law Reform Commission to examine the matter of class actions. The Commission's report, entitled Grouped Proceedings in the Federal Court, was not tabled in this place until almost 12 years later in December 1988. Even though that report contained fully drafted legislation, it has taken three more years for the Government to put forward a Bill which is quite similar in effect to the recommendations of the Commission.

This delay is perhaps indicative of the ill-founded hostility and alarm which the spectre of representative proceedings, as they are termed in the legislation, has provoked in the business community in particular. Yet any careful reading of the legislation makes it clear that these fears are unfounded.

Indeed, there are some critical defects in this legislation which, if left uncorrected, will seriously undermine the public interest advantages that are supposed to flow from it. The Australian Democrats will be moving amendments at the committee stage to remove some of these defects.

We will not be supporting the Opposition's amendments which, in our view, would gut the Bill. In this matter, as in so many others, we feel that the Liberal Party of Australia is being a mouthpiece for the nervous Nellies in the business community who do not realise that cutting out shonky operators will be not only to the benefit of ethical practice but also to the benefit of those companies which are concerned about serving consumers and being competitive in domestic and international markets.

The Democrats have shown a longstanding commitment in this place to grouped proceedings. In an attempt to spur the Government to implement the Law Reform Commission's recommendations, former Senator Haines adopted the Commission's proposed legislation and introduced it in 1989 as a private member's Bill called the Federal Court (Grouped Proceedings) Bill.

It is indeed a founding principle of our Party that the public interest demands that access to the courts be made easier and less costly for those with limited means. Grouped proceedings are a step in that direction. It is therefore pleasing to see that our work and the campaigning of many other organisations, such as the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations, has at last borne fruit. But the greatest credit must go to the Law Reform Commission, whose report on this matter is of outstanding quality.
In summarising the case for grouped proceedings, I can do no better than quote the Commission's conclusion:

SPEECH.PARA: An effective grouping procedure is needed as a way of reducing the cost of enforcing legal remedies in cases of multiple wrongdoing. Such a procedure could enable people who suffer loss or damage in common with others as a result of a wrongful act of omission by the same respondent to enforce their legal rights in the courts in a cost effective manner. It could overcome the cost and other barriers which impede people from pursuing a legal remedy. People who may be ignorant of their rights or fearful of embarking on proceedings could be assisted to a remedy if one member of the group, all similarly affected, could commence proceedings on behalf of all members. The grouping of claims could also promote efficiency in the use of resources by enabling common issues to be dealt with together. Appropriate grouping procedures are an essential part of the legal systems' response to multiple wrongdoing in an increasingly complex world.

The core of the issue is that the actions of corporations and government departments can have adverse impact on millions of people. It is an unarguable matter of efficiency, equity and justice that where large numbers of people have been affected they should be able to seek redress through grouped proceedings.

PARA.TAB: In its report, the Commission cited numerous examples where lower costs and greater efficiency could be achieved if grouped proceedings were available. For example, more than 300 workers afflicted with the asbestos related disease, mesothelioma, brought individual actions against CSR Ltd, its subsidiary, Mimalco, and the Western Australian Government requiring common issues of law to be determined in each individual case. This was also necessary in the hundreds of damages claims by bushfire victims against the State Electricity Commission of Victoria. Other cases cited include misleading advertising by a credit union and a college, losses by cruise passengers, damages for discrimination, defective software and the chemical pollution of oyster farms.

Despite the Commission's conclusions, after detailed and thorough examination, that existing court procedures do not offer equivalent advantages to grouped proceedings, the business community, and in particular a working party composed of various organisations of the business community, have publicly claimed that the need for grouped proceedings has not been demonstrated. They also fear that the cost to business will be disproportionately high, that excessive litigation will be encouraged and that consumer groups will use the new procedure to pursue political objectives.

These criticisms rest on the assumption that the Federal Court, on which this Bill confers wide discretion in the execution of representative proceedings, will prove itself to be so incompetent and, indeed, so naive that it cannot prevent such consequences arising. These claims are a reflection on the Federal Court, not on this legislation.

As I have said before, it is utterly predictable but nevertheless disappointing that the Opposition is prepared to gut a Bill which the Democrats consider to be a major demonstration of progress in the administration of justice in Australia. The Opposition has proposed a series of amendments which would restrict the applicability of representative proceedings to the point that they would be almost unusable.

Under the Opposition's amendments, group members would be required to have claims arising from exactly the same circumstances giving rise to exactly the same issues of law or fact and they must seek exactly the same form of relief. This is a quite transparent attempt to narrow the range of possible actions to a point where they almost disappear. The amendments would also reverse the opt out provision in the Bill whereby persons are included as group members unless they apply to be excluded—in other words, to make it an opt in provision.

The Democrats recognise that issues of civil liberties arise here but the practical implications of being included in a group without one's knowledge are virtually nil. On the other hand, the potential for representative proceedings to deliver justice to the disempowered and the poor will be greatly enhanced if they are automatically eligible to receive the benefits of a finding in the group's favour.

The Opposition's intention is clearly to protect people who break the law to the detriment of large numbers of people from the consequences of their actions. Somehow this is supposed to benefit the business community. In fact, the reverse is true. As I have said before, businesses with ethical and lawful practices will benefit if their shonky competitors are more readily brought to justice. What the Opposition is proposing would keep Australian business ethics at their current low level, which everyone agrees must be lifted.

I do not wish to be misunderstood as saying that all businesses currently have low ethical practices. However, in the late 1980s we saw examples of many high fliers and sharp operators giving the business community a bad reputation. I believe that we must take every opportunity to exclude those bad apples—if I may use that expression—from the business community, the overwhelming majority of whose members are prepared to follow proper ethical practices in Australia.

The Democrats' support for this Bill is qualified by a number of reservations. First, the Bill specifies that representative proceedings may not be brought in relation to any cause of action arising before the date of proclamation. This is a sop to those people who are opposing the intent of this Bill. It has no legal or, indeed, moral justification, given the Government's admission that the Bill confers no new legal rights.

It seems contrary to the policy objective of this Bill to make it impossible for people who have suffered at the hands of organisations, government departments or businesses, not to be allowed to use a better procedure which is now available. This provision will disadvantage large groups of people in the community, including AIDS sufferers in New South Wales and in other States, and many others. The Australian Democrats express great regret that the Government has seen fit to pay attention to the representations from pressure groups—as Senator Durack so correctly said—which in this case have suggested that insurance companies will suffer if this time limitation is not introduced. I will be interested to hear the justification of the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) for this provision and, as I understand it, the Government's reluctance to support our amendment to remove it.

Secondly, the Bill allows a representative proceeding to be stopped or stayed if the cost of distributing compensation funds is excessive in relation to the amount claimed. It also allows respondents to receive any undistributed compensation funds. This provision allows any outfit which has ripped off the public to keep or retrieve the spoils, provided that there are large numbers of people affected who cannot be contacted except at high cost.

We believe that this sends the wrong message to the business community and that, indeed, it is wrong in principle. Why should people who have ripped off the public benefit because of some mechanical defect in the process? We believe that a cy-pres mechanism, under which undistributed compensation funds are channelled to the next best recipient, is a far more satisfactory approach. We are assured by the Consumer Credit Legal Service that there has been an increasing acceptance of this principle in the business community. One dispute in Victoria, over the awarding of a credit providers licence, was resolved in part by the establishment of a cy-pres fund. Accordingly, our amendments provide for the group representative to direct unclaimed compensation to a Commonwealth, State or Territory legal aid fund.

It has been put to us by the Government that there are constitutional problems in allowing the Federal Court to allocate funds in that this could be identified as taxation. On the advice available to us, our amendment avoids this problem by allowing the redirection of compensation funds only on application by the group representatives. In other words, we are suggesting that people who are entitled to certain moneys simply exercise their right to assign their property to others. That can hardly be construed as taxation. We say that the decision as to where the funds should go is a matter for the affected group entitled to the funds, not for the court.

In summary, I wish to commend the Government for the principle of the Bill, which is a major advance in providing greater access to the legal system. It is parallel to the cost of justice inquiry which was pressed for vigorously by the Australian Democrats and by Senator Schacht, and which is now pursued no less vigorously by the Cooney committee, the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank those honourable senators who have contributed to the second reading debate on this very important Bill. I believe this Bill will introduce a means whereby those many people who might be affected by a particular action of a person or corporation in our society will be able to obtain the relief to which they are entitled. I do not believe this particular proposal will lead Australia to go down the United States road—as it is sometimes referred to—and become an overly litigious society, such as in the film Class Action, which I know you, Mr Acting Deputy President, have seen and believe has merit as a film. I do not think we are going down that road by means of this proposal because we have set our face firmly against some features of the American legal system, such as contingency fees, which appear, from my observations over there recently, to drive the American legal system rather than the merits of the issues themselves. It is important that people who have a legal right be given an opportunity to assert that right in the proper forum of the court so that it might be adjudicated upon. That is what we are providing for in this proposal for enhanced representative proceedings.

PARA.TAB: It is also very important to make clear—certainly, it is in my mind and I hope by now in the mind of any fair-minded commentator from the business community—that this proposal is not inseparably, inevitably linked with the question of product liability. One of the great benefits of this piece of legislation will be that it will probably be a means by which actions by shareholders and others in contravention of corporations law might take place: actions against company officers for false statements and takeover documents; contravention of fundraising provisions; and actions for loss or damages as a result of market rigging, insider trading or market manipulation. The enhancement of the rights of many shareholders to take this sort of representative proceeding will be a great aid to the more formal regulators, such as the Australian Securities Commission, in ensuring compliance with the corporations law. I am quite convinced in my own mind that, if shareholders had had such representative proceeding available to them during the latter part of the 1980s, at a time when regulation was so weak under the National Companies and Securities Commission, for reasons to do not with the initial idea of the structure of it, which at the time Senator Durack established it was a very good example of cooperative federalism—

TALK.START.PARA: —You didn't give them enough money.

—The fact is that the States starved that institution of the money needed to enforce those laws that were agreed upon at the Ministerial Council on Companies and Securities. I am getting a little off to one side. What I am trying to say is that I believe this procedure will be of great assistance in ensuring that, in the area of the corporations law, not only the Australian Securities Commission but shareholders will be given an enhanced capacity to ensure that they can get those remedies which flow from contravention of the corporations law.

PARA.TAB: It is also important to say that there is a real need in Australian society for this type of procedure. Certainly, when one looks at the English model, upon which most of the rules of court relating to representative proceedings in Australian jurisdictions are based, it does not provide the capacity to deal with the modern phenomenon, for example, of claims against pharmaceutical companies. In fact, when I was in England recently I discovered that the court was trying to grapple with 1,500 separate claims which were being processed in relation to a particular pharmaceutical. The Australian jurisdiction has followed the English model until now, except in Victoria where it has an opt-in procedure, put there after the bushfires tragedy specifically to try to provide a process to deal with those particular types of actions. The Federal Court rule makes it very clear, and it is typical of the rules in Australian jurisdictions. Order 6 rule 13(i) provides:

SPEECH.PARA: Where numerous persons have the same interest in any proceeding the proceeding may be commenced, and, unless the Court otherwise orders, continued, by or against any one or more of them as representing all or as representing all except one or more of them.

What is important about that is that it has to be understood that in those representative proceedings the procedure is not an opt-in procedure, despite lots of misrepresentations—or misunderstandings would be fairer—on the part of business.

PARA.TAB: The present representative actions in the Federal Court and in other Australian jurisdictions, except Victoria for the reason I mentioned, do allow actions on behalf of unidentified persons. They do not require consent in their representative actions. There is no requirement to name the persons represented. Persons who do not want to be represented must apply to become defendants, but in any case they are bound by the decision; they cannot opt out. I regarded that as an infringement of the rights of the persons who might otherwise be in that group. That is why the opt-out procedure has been decided upon. I do not think it is right that persons in the group should lose all their rights to bring separate proceedings if they so wished.

The English rule that we have adopted so that the plaintiff becomes the self-elected representative of the others—and he certainly does not have to obtain their consent—has to be modified by this opt-out proposal. The model now in the representative area works an injustice; it strips the individual of an opportunity, his freedom of right, to bring his own case. Therefore, under proposed new section 33J of the Bill we have a procedure which is headed, `Right of group member to opt out'. It is a right and that is why it has to be emphasised—not that I believe in fact that it will be much exercised, because quite clearly it is a very expensive process to opt out and mount one's own case.

The United States experience, based on a paper provided to me, although written some decade ago, indicates that perhaps one per cent of group members might opt out and that of those only a very few actually mount their own actions. Our legal officer in the Washington Embassy, Mr Brian O'Callaghan, has made extensive inquiries and has been able to find nothing that really refutes that experience reflected in that paper. But the right has to be acknowledged and that is what we are doing in this enhanced representative action.

Whilst it is true that the courts in Australia, as in the United Kingdom, have tried to be more flexible, particularly with the joinder of plaintiffs procedure in the very case which Senator Durack mentioned—I think he mentioned Mr Justice Wilcox in the Federal Court of Australia in relation to a case conducting that; it was done under the joinder of plaintiffs rule rather than the representative rule—it is interesting that the head note to that in the Federal Court reports reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Regret expressed that the provisions relating to grouped proceedings such as those recommended by the Australian Law Reform Commission were not enforced in the Federal Court.

By the way, I make it very clear that I am not saying that Mr Justice Wilcox supports this Bill. I would not try to trespass on the proper distinction between the arms of government and I am not hereby saying that the Federal Court of Australia applauds and supports this piece of legislation; that is a matter for the Executive Government and this Parliament. But at page 314 of his judgment Mr Justice Wilcox said:

If there were in force in this Court provisions relating to grouped proceedings, such as those recommended by the Australian Law Reform Commission in its report `Grouped Proceedings in the Federal Court' (ALRC 46), it would have been possible for the Court to determine all common questions of fact or law at a single hearing in such a manner as to make the result binding on all applicants and all respondents.

The result would have been to avoid the repetition in each of the later cases of most of the evidence in this case, with consequential savings in costs and the earlier finalisation of the whole litigation. But that recommendation has not become law. So it will be necessary to deal with each of the cases separately.

And he goes on. So there is an indication that even the Federal Court, under its more flexible joinder of plaintiffs process, indicates that there would be merit in moving somewhere along the lines of the ALRC report.

PARA.TAB: We have not gone as far as that report in some respects but I believe that we have come up with a very workable proposal which gives persons who want to vindicate their rights the opportunity and preserves the rights of individual litigants to opt out but—and I emphasise this point, as did Senator Spindler —preserves at all times the supervisory powers of the Federal Court to ensure that the process is not abused. In fact, proposed new section 33ZF states:

SPEECH.PARA: In any proceeding (including an appeal) conducted under this Part, the Court may, of its own motion or on application by a party or a group member, make any order the Court thinks appropriate or necessary to ensure that justice is done in the proceeding.

That is a very good declaration, a statutory recognition, of the proper role of the court in everything that it does in this area. It goes on in proposed new section 33ZG to deal with vexatious litigants and matters such as that.

PARA.TAB: I believe that this is a proposal which should commend itself to the chamber. The second reading of this Bill merits support and I commend it to the Senate.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
