SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Court of Australia Bill is a very well drafted Bill. I do not agree with most of what is in it, but if we are lumbered with the Bill, it is an easy Bill to deal with. It is a good example of what I would hope the Commonwealth Parliamentary Counsel would achieve more often.

PARA.TAB: Having said that, I do not need to repeat the Opposition's objections to the extent to which this Bill takes the availability of group proceedings. The amendments that I have moved are designed to amend the Federal Court Act in a way which gives effect to what we think is the appropriate form of group proceedings, namely, the extension of a representative action, well-known in our jurisdiction in the past, mainly in State courts, of course, but in the Federal Court in recent times.

Instead of being able to take proceedings on behalf of an identified number of named people, which may be a difficulty under the present system, the Government proposes a system whereby the proceedings are taken and people have to opt out. Obviously, they cannot opt out if they do not know about it, and many will not know about it. If it is an extension of individual rights, it will be somewhat ham fisted in its operation.

The existing situation where there is a mixture of rules of court, decisions of judges and, in some cases—I think, in Victoria or South Australia—a statutory provision, is not satisfactory. That is why the Opposition has brought forward this alternative which will amend the Federal Court Act and overcome a lot of the existing deficiencies in representative action through the opting in procedure which these amendments are designed to achieve.

I suppose there may be debate about certain aspects of these amendments. There may be deficiencies in them, even from the point of view of what we are seeking to achieve. However, it seems as though the Government and the Australian Democrats are not going to support the amendments. Therefore, I see no point in making another speech in relation to the subject. We have already debated whether we will have an opting in or an opting out form of group proceedings at the second reading stage.

Our concern is that the Government's form is, in fact, the class action. We have no objection to people grouping together and saving costs on all sides, saving court time and so on. That is what we seek to achieve with this alternative proposal. In many ways, what we want to achieve would be satisfied by going as far as these amendments would suggest. However, that is not going to be the case.

As I have already said, our proposal to omit section 33M is based on the fact that we believe that under our proposal the Court does not need to have the number of powers that it has under the Government's proposal. Our system would leave people and their legal advisers free to make most of the decisions themselves. They do not need the Court acting as a nanny to the extent required under the Government's proposal. The Government's proposal is much more court controlled and interventionist than ours is. However, as I have said, if the Opposition's proposals are not accepted with respect to proposed clause 3—as I do not expect them to be—and the decision of the Committee is to support the Government's proposal, I will not propose amendment No. 7. That is the position that the Opposition is adopting. Perhaps that will facilitate the progress of the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I confirm that the Australian Democrats will not be supporting the Opposition amendments which Senator Durack has moved. We believe that the cumulative effect of all the amendments would be to gut the direction of the Federal Court of Australia Bill and to turn it into a much weaker and almost useless version of a group proceedings Bill. Accordingly, the Australian Democrats will be voting against these amendments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate to the Committee that the Government will not be accepting the amendments put forward by the Opposition for the very evident reasons which have been commented on already by Senators Durack and Spindler. The amendments fundamentally change the character of the Bill, despite the fact that the chamber has given its assent in the second reading to the principle of what is sought to be achieved. I indicate that the Government will be opposing these amendments.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: 1.Clause 3, page 2, proposed section 33B, lines 18 to 21, omit the section.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment seeks to ensure that people who have suffered an injustice or damage and have a current cause of action are able to avail themselves of these provisions. As the Minister has confirmed, the Bill does not in any way create new legal rights. We are simply enabling people who have a current cause of action to adopt a procedure which is cheaper and easier for them to engage in; in other words, a procedure which gives them access to our legal system. The attempt by the Government in this particular clause to ensure that only those causes of action can be dealt with under this procedure which arise after the proclamation of the Bill is contrary to the intent of the legislation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will be opposing this particular amendment. The limitation of the Bill to those causes of action arising after its commencement is a sensible one. We believe that the Federal Court can now be prepared to accept this increased workload which will flow from the enabling of those who have a cause of action arising after its commencement to band together in the enhanced representative proceedings provided for in this legislation. But I do not think it would be fair to burden the court with the increased workload that would come from allowing causes of action, which arose before the commencement of the Bill, to be litigated in this particular format.

PARA.TAB: There is also the question, a very subsidiary one in my estimation, but in fairness I put it on the record because I mentioned it in discussions with Senator Spindler: I would imagine that because of the poverty of the process until now insurance companies, manufacturers and those engaged in business enterprise in this country have been able to make assumptions when setting premiums in relation to likely successful court actions or settlements that might be made in relation to claims. They have been able to factor those into their insurance premiums. The situation should be clear from this point onwards but it ought not to go back in time in a way which would have possible insurance implications. That is a point but not to my mind the principal one.

We are doing very good work in the chamber this morning in putting this new procedure into place—presuming it gets the support of the House of Representatives, which I confidently expect it will. In relation to future causes of action it makes good sense. The Government will be maintaining that particular limitation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will oppose the Australian Democrats amendment to make these new proceedings retrospective. In the reasons given by the Minister, he now seems to have found a greater concern about burdens on the court than he has hitherto shown in this debate. I welcome that. But the overwhelming reason why the Democrats amendment should not be accepted is the second reason that the Minister gave.

PARA.TAB: This amendment is a classic example of the way the Democrats think. They present themselves as great believers in civil rights, human rights, fairness and all the rest of it. What could be more unfair to defendants who, as the Minister said, have not been able to cover themselves for new liabilities that are going to be created if this amendment goes through? Clearly, and I have already dealt with this objection, the new and not inconsiderable burden of this legislation on the business community—let us not worry about the cowboy types that the Minister is concerned about—is going to fall to a large extent upon producers of products; even though it is not necessarily contained as part and parcel of the product liability legislation. I can see the wider justification and I accept what the Minister says about that.

The reality is that the consumer movements and the people the Democrats claim to represent here will in the end pay enough as it is. But now the Democrats are going to be saying, `Well, it doesn't matter about all those people who have produced products and haven't covered themselves sufficiently for insurance. That doesn't matter. They can go to hell. We want all these retrospective liabilities to be created'. They do not give any consideration to the rights of people in the business world. It is a one-sided typically Democrat approach to everything that we see in this chamber. There is a major matter of principle involved here. It is a principle that the Democrats obviously do not respect or even consider; namely, the rights of the defendants. They are all for the rights of plaintiffs and they want to extend them. They could not give a damn about the rights of defendants.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must respond to the claim made by Senator Durack that what we are suggesting has a retrospective effect. What we are talking about is a legal right that is in existence. It is not retrospective. What we are saying is that people who have a cause of action should have the possibility to avail themselves of procedures which would make it easier for them to pursue their claim under an existing cause of action. Indeed, if it is a choice between people who have done wrong in the business world or wherever—who have caused some people damage or loss—we believe the rights of people must take precedence over the imagined rights of those who have perpetrated these losses. It is quite clear that what we are talking about is giving people a chance to recover for damage that has been caused to them.

PARA.TAB: Once again, the Opposition is doing the business community an actual disservice because this legislation will not affect people who are acting with probity, with honesty and with due care and consideration for their consumers. It will only sort out those people who are negligent and who do not care whether they cause damage or not. In these circumstances, the Australian Democrats are proud to be on the side of the consumer who has been done damage. I press the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Spindler has only dug himself further into his morass of ignorance about the way the world works. He seems to think that the defendants in these cases are full of moral turpitude. The Minister has instanced the commercial cowboys and so on, but I am talking about the business people who, in many cases, may have strict liabilities imposed upon them by the law; that liability is there.

PARA.TAB: I agree that it is not retrospective in that sense, but the fact is that in a large number of these cases liability would arise under fairly technical rules in the law of contract and tort. In the case of contract, it might be some very technical matter of construction of a contract, involving purely legal argument and where there is no sense of wrongdoing, as the Democrats seem to see it. They seem to see business people as all being engaged in some sort of wrongdoing most of the time.

It is that element and attitude of mind which the Democrats just do not understand. That is why anybody with any sense—it might be businessmen, it might be professional people, most of whom do have sense—will have insured against this sort of liability. With all the goodwill in the world, the probity and everything else that Senator Spindler talks about, there is no way one can be sure of not being found to have civil liability in a court. Indeed, the way our criminal law is developing, a number of people are surprised to find themselves in the criminal courts.

We are talking here about wide civil liabilities that are imposed by the law on people for many reasons and in many circumstances, and it is only fair that those people should be able to insure themselves and cover themselves; and prudent business and professional people do that. The amendment proposed by the Australian Democrats would leave those business and professional people totally unprotected from what could be very considerable liabilities.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Spindler's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Clause 3, page 5, proposed section 33M, lines 20 to 35, omit the section.
3.Clause 3, page 11, line 8, at end of proposed subsection 33ZA(3), add the following word and paragraph:

" `; and (e) specify a day (which is 6 months or more after the day fixed under paragraph (d)), after which the Court may make such orders as are just for the payment from the fund to the respondent of the money remaining in the fund".
4.Clause 3, page 11, proposed subsection 33ZA(5), lines 13 to 16, omit the subsection, substitute the following subsections:

PARA.TAB: `(5) Where the Court concludes that the cost of identifying some or all of the group members and distributing to them the amounts ordered to be paid to them would be excessive having regard to the total of those amounts, the Court may, by order, direct that those group members not be paid.

`(6) On application by the representative party after the day fixed under paragraph (3)(d) and on or before the day fixed under paragraph (3)(e), the Court may order that the money remaining in the fund be paid to a Commonwealth, State or Territory legal aid fund.
`(7) After the day fixed under paragraph (3)(e), the Court may make such orders as are just for the payment from the fund to the respondent of the money remaining in the fund.'.".

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments are designed to ensure that funds which have become available as a result of a successful action are not reclaimed by bodies of persons who have caused the damage but are put to a beneficial use. There will be cases when not all members of a group will have claimed or collected their amounts and therefore there will be a remaining fund. In addition, there will be cases where, because of the small amount due to each claimant, it will be impractical to distribute those sums. In both cases these amendments are designed to ensure that the people to whom amounts are due have the option to ask the court to have these funds transferred to legal aid bodies.

PARA.TAB: The question of constitutional validity has been raised by the Government, but we understand that the fact we are allowing the people to whom these funds rightfully belong to dispose of them in this way by requesting the court to take action on their behalf overcomes that possibility.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not be accepting these amendments. Although I can see the motive behind Senator Spindler's concerns and do not say that they are completely without merit, I believe that the task of the court is to adjudicate between parties and award compensation to an injured party in those cases where it is appropriate. We are saying that there should be a process to enable many people to come before the court in certain situations and get compensation. But if for one reason or another that compensation cannot be easily paid or persons cannot be found to whom payment ought to be made, the defendant should not be disadvantaged. We do not believe it is right in a sense that the defendant be punished by having assets diminished simply because a payment cannot be made to those who otherwise would be entitled to receive a payment.

PARA.TAB: For that and for certain constitutional reasons—I am not convinced it is not within the judicial power of the Commonwealth to allow this sort of payment to be made by a court to a body that is not a party to the action before it—the Government will not be supporting these amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition opposes these amendments. I have already given the reasons why we are opposed to amendment No. 2. Amendment No. 3 is unnecessary and amendment No. 4 is the only one of any substance. I adopt the Minister's arguments. I do not know about the constitutional considerations, which may or may not be the case. I do not think that is the important aspect.

PARA.TAB: The important aspect of the amendment is the attitude of mind of the Australian Democrats who propose this idea. They have no idea as to fairness and the rights of defendants, other than of the people whom they are purporting to represent here. They are proposing something that is outrageous. They are saying that even when money is left over in a fund, which could be a considerable sum of money, an unsuccessful defendant in a class action should not get it back, but that it should go to government or to legal aid funds. Legal aid is in respect of a Commonwealth, State or Territory fund. The person concerned, having paid out all these huge sums of money, will be fined or will become a compulsory contributor to legal aid funds. It is one of these dream world ideas that animate the Democrats; it is totally unfair and one-sided, and we oppose it.
Motion (by Senator Tate)—by leave—agreed to:
That the sitting of the Committee be continued until proceedings on the Bill are completed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Durack in his comments ignored very much the basic issue, which is that the funds have been placed in a trust account which is there at the direction of the people to whom it rightfully belongs. We are simply providing a mechanism for these people to exercise their discretion to do so.

That the amendments (Senator Spindler's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Amendments negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Title agreed to.
Bill agreed to.
