TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to reports concerning the shooting of people in Dili yesterday and earlier reports of the deaths of two men in Dili on 29 October. What are the facts presently known to the Australian Government concerning the incident in Dili yesterday? When did the Government first become aware of that incident? What were the circumstances of the deaths on 29 October? What action has been taken by the Indonesian Government in relation to these deaths? What steps have been taken to convey to the Indonesian Government the concern of the Australian Government that all such incidents are fully investigated and appropriate action taken to bring to account any members of the security forces guilty of violation of human rights?

—I have some information on this issue. I know it is of concern to members of all political parties, on both sides in both Houses. The Government is deeply disturbed by the reports to which Senator Hill refers. In respect of the incident on 29 October, I do not have much detailed information. I will seek to obtain that for Senator Hill. Although the details of a recent incident are unclear, it is now evident that an appalling tragedy has occurred in Dili in which many people have been killed. The number is not available at the moment.

PARA.TAB: Consequent upon this, the Indonesian Ambassador was called to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade this morning and the Australian Ambassador in Jakarta has been instructed to call on the authorities there. Through these channels, we have asked the Indonesian Government for urgent information about what exactly happened in Dili yesterday. We have urged the Indonesian Government to conduct a thorough investigation and publish a full and factual account of what happened and why. We have said that we expect that those responsible for breaches of human rights should be appropriately dealt with. Those three issues go to some of the gravamen of the question.

Senator Gareth Evans, who is overseas, has been asked to discuss the matter with Dr Alatas, the Indonesian Foreign Minister, in Seoul where they are attending the APEC ministerial meeting together. An officer of the Australian Embassy in Jakarta is on his way to Dili to see what he can find out about this incident. His inquiries will include the investigation of reports that an Australian aid worker was present at the event and may also have been injured.

In the discussions with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade this morning, the Indonesian Ambassador said that the Indonesian Government was viewing yesterday's events very seriously and would undertake a thorough investigation and that it regrets the deaths which have occurred. The Ambassador gave officials an account of the incident based on preliminary reports. He said that violence had erupted following an attack by demonstrators on an Indonesian army officer. Of course, we are not in a position to assess the accuracy of conflicting reports of the incident, but we certainly welcome the Indonesian Government's acknowledgment of the seriousness of it and its decision to undertake an investigation.

I should also indicate that the Australian and Indonesian governments have worked hard on the basis of goodwill on both sides to build a responsible and beneficial relationship between our two countries. In that relationship, East Timor has always been an area of concern. We have recognised Indonesia's sovereignty over East Timor. We have consistently expressed our concerns about human rights abuses there. I say again that we encourage the Indonesian Government to deal with this tragedy openly in accordance with the international standards of respect for human rights to which both countries subscribe.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I seek some clarification. Is the Minister simply saying that the Australian Government has no further facts at the moment other than that a tragedy occurred in which many people were killed? If the Australian Government has further facts as to the circumstances of what occurred, will the Minister please advise the Senate?

—At this stage I do not think that we have a clear picture as to what occurred at all, except to say that there were a number of deaths. Obviously, I am not in a position to relay the Indonesian version of events which was conveyed to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade by the Ambassador this morning other than that which I said the Ambassador had said: that there was a serious situation and a number of deaths had occurred. He also offered a comment on an attack on an Indonesian officer. If any information comes to hand, I will make it available. I think it will depend on a number of issues, discussions in Jakarta and the visit of an Australian official to Dili.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. I refer to the debate about the future airport needs of Sydney. Is the Minister aware of claims that the construction of a major airport at Badgerys Creek would create 50,000 new jobs in western regional Sydney? What is the Minister's assessment of these claims? Are such claims correct?

—I have noted these claims. They are significant claims in a time of need to create genuine new jobs. Unfortunately, the claims are not correct. As I have said before in this chamber, a lot of people do not appreciate the extent of employment that currently exists at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport—KSA. Sydney Airport currently has a situation where 45,000 people rely on it directly for their jobs. A great many of these 45,000 people not only work at Sydney Airport but also live in the electorates adjacent to the airport and are ably represented in this Parliament by a number of Labor members.

PARA.TAB: The correct analysis to use for Badgerys Creek is the directed international airport option. That is the only one that generates a maximum amount of employment. That option of a directed international airport at Badgerys Creek would cost in the vicinity of $2 billion and would result in direct airport employment at Badgerys Creek of 28,300 people by the year 2010. The difficulty is that this figure has to be discounted by the fact that 10,000 of those jobs would simply be transferred from KSA to Badgerys Creek; therefore, they would not be new jobs.

The flow-on employment at Badgerys Creek would only be about 6,000. The reason for that is that a great deal of the indirect employment generated at Badgerys Creek would be sourced elsewhere in Sydney; that is, around the current support facilities that are located near the existing Sydney Airport. The total employment at Badgerys Creek from a directed international airport would be about 34,500, not the 50,000 mentioned. As I said before, that would have to be discounted by the 10,000 jobs that would simply be transferred from KSA to Badgerys Creek, which would give a net figure of 24,500 new jobs.

The amount of genuine new employment anticipated to be generated at KSA by the increased growth that will be served by the third runway is 13,000 jobs directly employed at the airport and a further 13,000 employed indirectly. That is a total of 26,000 new jobs that will arise as a result of the KSA development.

But the difference between that 26,000 and the 24,500 I mentioned at Badgerys Creek arises because the airport at Badgerys Creek would be non-commercial—a directed international would be profoundly non-commercial—and those jobs would be created by what would be, in effect, a giant RED scheme; whereas the 26,000 jobs created at KSA would all be sustainable jobs funded directly by the industry in which those people work.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Why did his ACTU accord partner yesterday reject the Minister's much vaunted industrial relations law review package? What role did Keating campaigner Bill Kelty play in its rejection? Are any of the Government's planned fourth term major reforms likely to be achieved with a change of leadership?

—The Government has been involved in consultation on industrial relations reform with employers and unions for the past 12 months. Indeed, we have succeeded in making some important reforms already. Last year, honourable senators will recall, we amended the Federal Industrial Relations Act for the purpose of encouraging union amalgamations.

PARA.TAB: But the question of industrial relations reform is a continuing issue. The key question for the Government is: what is the appropriate type of industrial relations system for Australia? The secondary question is: how does one give legal integrity to that system? By stating that, it is clear that this is a complex and difficult issue and that there are many points of view about it. We start from a situation in which the parties are polarised on this matter. So far, it is fair to say that there is no consensus as to what a reasonable outcome will be. We intend to press on and work at achieving that as far as it can possibly be achieved.

In order to indicate our views to the community as to what we think is the direction of that reform, honourable senators will remember that some weeks back in this chamber I made a major statement about industrial relations reform which, while not applauded by the Opposition, was certainly acclaimed by the Business Council of Australia, the Confederation of Australian Industry, the ACTU and others. Since then the national wage case decision has come down, in fact, complementing the very things I said in my parliamentary statement.

The consultations are not complete. As I have said, we will continue to talk to try to refine and define a package which I can bring forth to this chamber and this Parliament in order to enact what I think is a very important reform to the industrial relations system.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Is the Minister aware of an interview which took place this morning on Hobart radio with the Green Independent, Christine Milne, MHA, in which she accused the Minister and his Department of deliberately frustrating a visit to Australia by representatives of Organocell-Thyssen? In light of the potential importance of this technology to Tasmanian forests, can the Minister tell the Senate whether the Thyssen visit will proceed?

—I am vaguely aware of it, but I am now more aware than I was a second or two ago of the interview which took place between Dr Werner Greve and Christine Milne about a proposed visit to Australia by Organocell-Thyssen which has been postponed. There is a fair bit of misinformation being spread about what has transpired. I suspect it has more to do with the Greens' approach to forestry issues in general rather than any real concern about Organocell, because they have certainly not made any representations to me.

PARA.TAB: The reason for the visit, which was to be held this week, being postponed involved the practical difficulties relating to the appointments with key people whom the delegation wanted to see in Tasmania and other States, including Canberra. It turned out that arranging a visit which was a qualitative one in terms of the people it would meet was just not possible, and to bring Organocell-Thyssen out from Germany for a tour of that kind would not be in the best interests of anyone.

We are working on arrangements for a quality tour by Organocell early next year. The visit will continue to be arranged by the Commonwealth, but will be done in consultation with other interested States—particularly Tasmania, which has an obvious interest in obtaining the most environmentally sensitive and cost effective pulping technology available. My office has been in contact with Mr Llewellyn, the Tasmanian Minister for Forests, and confirmed again our strong interest in the technology and in the visit proceeding and recognised that it is a matter of priority for the Tasmanian Government.

I can assure the honourable senator that there was certainly no feeling within the Commonwealth, nor obviously within the Tasmanian Government or industry, that the Organocell technology is without promise. I would hesitate to try to explain it to the Senate at Question Time, but I did have an explanation of it from Thyssen scientific people when I was in Germany in July this year. Similarly, there is no feeling that we should not pursue, collaboratively, technological developments with Germany, and the visit will take place in light of those circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. It also refers to the brutal massacre of defenceless East Timorese at a memorial service in Dili yesterday. Firstly, will the Minister make the results of the inquiry by the Australian Embassy officer who is now on his way to Dili available to this Parliament? Secondly, does the Minister accept that the policy of successive Australian governments of appeasement over East Timor has been a failure, particularly as far as the human rights of the East Timorese are concerned? Thirdly, will the Government now support calls for self-determination for the people of East Timor?

—The issue of self-determination for East Timor was resolved in terms of the world community—and particularly the Australian Government's position—many years ago. It has been a bipartisan position on the part of the major political parties. I must say, personally, that I have some sense of regret about the earlier period of our involvement with East Timor; but that is not an issue which can be revisited at the present time.

PARA.TAB: As I said in answer to a question from Senator Hill, in terms of our relationship with Indonesia the concern about human rights in East Timor has always been a difficult issue for us. It has been a shared concern and one which we have had to try to deal with in the best possible way. The honourable senator asked in the earlier part of her question whether I would make available the findings resulting from a visit to Dili by an official from the Australian Government. As I said to Senator Hill, we will provide any information we can, arising from that visit or any other source, which enables us to better understand what happened.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. Is it true that in Australia approximately 500 babies die every year from sudden infant death syndrome? Is it also true that some 200 of these lives may be saved just by making people aware of the significance of the position in which infants are put down to sleep?

—I know that all honourable senators are interested in the condition known as sudden infant death syndrome. It is a fact that the Menzies Centre for Population Health Research based in Hobart has demonstrated a strong association between placing an infant to sleep on the stomach and death from sudden infant death syndrome. This particular research has been published in Lancet, the prestigious international medical journal. It certainly leads to the suggestion that parents should be advised to place their infants to sleep on their back or their sides and that this may reduce the death rate from SIDS by as much as 40 per cent—which would be about 200 infant lives saved in Australia every year.

PARA.TAB: A conference was held on this matter in Canberra in July. It was attended by such authorities as the National Health and Medical Research Council, the Royal Australian College of Paediatrics and other medical colleges, the Royal College of Nursing Australia, and various State health authorities. That conference adopted a unanimous recommendation that infants should not be placed on their stomachs to sleep unless there was specific medical or other reasons. As a result, hospitals and clinics in every State are presently adopting that recommendation. I believe that this is a major breakthrough in the epidemiological study undertaken by the Menzies Centre for Population Health Research. It is to be commended for undertaking this study. I hope that as many mothers as possible can be informed of this recommendation. Whilst it is not claimed that this is the sole cause of the phenomenon of sudden infant death, nevertheless, if this precaution can be taken, it may reduce the incidence of that tragedy by some 40 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Is the Minister aware of the role that the Red Nose Appeal takes in the funding of this very important research? If so, could he pass on the compliments of the Senate to that organisation?

—I am not aware of whether the Red Nose Appeal funds this research undertaken by the Menzies Centre. I would be amazed if it did not because obviously it has made a most significant advance in dealing with the sudden infant death syndrome. Quite clearly, this program would need evaluation now that the initial findings have been made. There is no doubt that Tasmania, with its stable population, is a perfect place in which to carry out the studies from the statistical base that have already been compiled. I will certainly pass on the compliments of the Senate if it turns out that the Red Nose Appeal has contributed funding for this research that has been undertaken. Millions of dollars are contributed every year to that very worthwhile appeal. It certainly strikes a chord with most Australians. Hundreds of thousands of dollars are contributed by generous Tasmanians, so it would be good to see some of that money being returned for this splendid research effort in Tasmania.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to his comment in Question Time yesterday that:

QUESTION.PARA: I confess that the majority of the community is not enchanted with this Government at the present time.
Does the Minister therefore believe that the community would be more or less enchanted with Mr Keating as the leader of the Government?

TALK.START.PARA: —I said to Senator Bishop privately yesterday that I thought I had given her enough publicity this week. She got her name in the paper as a result of an answer I gave to a question earlier in the week. I told her that I was not going to do it again this week for her.

PARA.TAB: Let us be clear about what I said. Senator Bishop is developing this reputation as being the ayatollah of the Estimates and the qazi of Question Time. All these questions are recycled day after day and I am not going to give her answers to them all. On the question of enchantment, let me say that any enchantment that anybody in the electorate has for Senator Bishop's Party is as a result of distance. Distance lends enchantment to the view. Because Senator Bishop's Party is a long way away from being in government, a few people have some enchantment with it, but not much.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have a look at the opinion polls.
—Get out of Canberra and have a look at what is happening.

—I was trying to say quite seriously that Senator Bishop just has to look at the opinion polls and, as Senator Alston says, get out of Canberra a bit and listen and talk to people about what they think about the political process in this country at present. What I said yesterday is absolutely correct. One can draw that conclusion.

PARA.TAB: The great tragedy for the people of this country who have some degree of disenchantment with the government of the day—and this is true of State governments in almost every State in the Commonwealth—is that they are not very happy with the alternative. I go to boardrooms and I talk to people all around the country. The perception of the Opposition's current leader, Dr Hewson, is that of a man who can see through a keyhole with both eyes. That is the current view; that is the view of his vision for this country. When we look at who is supporting him on the front bench in the Senate, for goodness sake, and when we look at the Opposition front bench in the other chamber, we see some real indication of why people are so gloomy.

As I have said before, the Opposition is psyching itself up. It was very revealing to read what happened in the House of Representatives earlier this week. Mr Alexander Downer—Smart Alex—said in the House of Representatives earlier this week, `We did not do these things before because we did not have the guts'. It is recorded in Hansard. Smart Alex said that the Opposition did not have the guts. Opposition senators now make all these noises here. They come here showing that they have the guts, but what people worry about is whether they have the brains. The answer to that question is that they have neither the brains nor the guts, and that will be exposed in the next 18 months when the heat goes on.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. It was interesting to hear the Minister duck and weave and rant and rave and avoid the question. We have several times this week given him the opportunity to give unqualified support for the Prime Minister until after the election. We have also given him the opportunity to condemn Mr Keating for destabilising the Government to the point where we have a paralysis of policy. So I ask the Minister—
—Order! Ask the supplementary question, Senator Bishop.

—Will he either tell us in an unqualified fashion that he supports the Prime Minister until after the next election or, alternatively, condemn Mr Keating for his actions in continuing to destabilise the Government of this country, resulting in policy paralysis?
—Not a hard question, John; it is pretty straightforward.
—I can hear Elmer; do not be cheeky, Elmer. Senator Bishop's name is Bishop, but she sounds like Senator McCarthy when she comes in here and says all the time—
—I raise a point of order, Mr President. I find that comparison quite offensive. I ask the Minister to withdraw it.
—It is an offensive term.
—Mr President, Senator McCarthy was an elected senator of the United States and chairman of a Senate committee, the same as Senator Bishop. I am not obliged to—
—Order! I suggest to Senator Button we might obtain a little more decorum in the chamber if he were to withdraw that reference to Senator McCarthy.
—Mr President, I withdraw. It is an issue of legitimate debate—but on the adjournment some night. I am not here to answer to any loyalty oath administered to me by the Opposition.
—Where does your support lie? How did you vote?
—Order! Senator Alston, you are repeatedly interjecting.

—I am not here subject to any loyalty oath administered by the Opposition. The Opposition's difficulty is: if it could come in here and point to one statement or act of disloyalty by me to the Prime Minister, it would be on stronger ground. But Opposition senators cannot—none of them can. In those circumstances, I do not have to subscribe to the honourable senator's view of the world—I subscribe to mine. Mr Hawke will be Prime Minister at the next election and after it and I, as a Minister in this Government, will be loyal to him.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Is the Minister aware that the New South Wales Government has caved in to the blatant political pressure of the New South Wales Law Society and has decided not to end the New South Wales legal profession's monopoly over conveyancing? As the Minister would be aware, the restrictive operation of the legal profession's practices inflate costs unnecessarily to the Australian public. Therefore, will he make strong representations to the New South Wales Government to proceed with the proposal to end the conveyancing monopoly of the New South Wales legal profession? In making these representations to the New South Wales Government, will the Minister point out to the New South Wales Government that the legal profession's monopoly over conveyancing in New South Wales means that the New South Wales public pay by far the highest conveyancing fees in Australia; and that the New South Wales Government's commitment to micro-economic reform will vanish if it allows the most powerful, greedy, venal and selfish interest group anywhere in Australia, that is, the New South Wales legal profession, to intimidate and threaten the Government and people of New South Wales?

—I am not aware of the detail but it appears to be the case that the New South Wales Government has refused to accept the recommendation of its Attorney-General, Mr Peter Collins, that conveyancing be no longer the exclusive domain and monopoly of the legal profession in New South Wales.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting that the question should come from a South Australian senator. Of course, there is an ability under the Torrens title system in South Australia for people outside the legal profession to assist those engaged in conveyancing—landbrokers, I think they are called in that State—and to reduce the cost of household conveyancing in South Australia by a very marked degree.

I believe that no part of Australian society can be immune from the need to reorganise itself or be reorganised by government, if it need be, in the interest of micro-economic reform. It is quite clear that the union of lawyers in New South Wales has proved to be very strong—indeed, insurmountable for the Cabinet in New South Wales.

My colleague Senator Collins is often questioned by the other side about the waterfront unions. I believe that it is now a question of the lawyers unions being subject to exactly the same questioning and scrutiny, particularly from those opposite who say that they believe in competition being the means by which the marketplace can deliver the best and cheapest services and goods to the Australian community. If they really believe in competitive pressures as being a way in which the marketplace can be organised to deliver services at a reasonable cost to Australian consumers—in this case, conveyancing advice—they should support doing away with the monopoly of lawyers in this area.

I do not know whether I can make an appeal, in Senator Schacht's terms, to the Government of New South Wales but certainly this will reinforce the need for the review of the professions that the Trade Practices Commission is undertaking at the moment. If anyone thought it was not proper for the Commission to look at the professions, this is certainly a case which indicates that it is very proper that it should look at the restrictive trade practices and monopoly rights which some professions have arrogantly arrogated to themselves over the decades.

I also believe that the cost of justice inquiry has a very real interest in this. If the distinguished Chairman of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, Senator Barney Cooney, and other members were minded to invite the President of the Law Society of New South Wales—I do not say `compel', of course—to come before the Committee and explain why lawyers should retain the monopoly in this area, it would make for a very interesting session indeed.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Social Security: Assurance of Support Cases

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. I refer to the Minister's admission on Monday that major difficulties in his Department's computer programs mean that it will be unable to identify $23m of assurance of support debts owing to the Commonwealth.
—How much?

—I said $23m. When did the Minister's Department first become aware of its inability to locate beneficiaries who are assurance of support migrants? What is the exact nature of these major computer difficulties? When were these difficulties rectified and what is the cost to the Australian taxpayer of his Department's failure to take immediate action?

—I think Senator Patterson is working under some difficulties because she seems to have this pretty well totally wrong. What I said the other day, when asked a question about computer difficulties, was that we did have a computer programming problem in the Department which meant that we had not been able to identify as much debt as we would have liked in the year 1990-91. I said then that we had recovered, or identified for recovery, $1.77m and that because we had become aware of this—which was in June of this year—we had been able to improve the programming so that we could bring that figure up to $9m. That was caused by a deficiency in the matching process, which I briefly outlined the other day. The deficiency was that my Department and the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs did not have a common system for identity matching.

PARA.TAB: As the honourable senator would be aware, there has been a change in the system with the new bonds which I am sure will help us to get over that problem. I explained to her the other day that there had been a difficulty in that often we would get the same name for a whole lot of people; some people had changed their names; some people had Anglicised them, and whatever. So, we had problems. As the honourable senator is the one who has been raising the issue, I should tell her that it is very difficult for the Department to choose to go in aggressively, knocking on all of the doors of people, many of whom will be totally, utterly and completely innocent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish! What rubbish!

—It is not rubbish; it is a fact. The Department is going to be very careful about following up multiple matches because it does not intend to breach any of the privacy guidelines. Nonetheless, I do not think the honourable senator understands the system.
—But you said a minute ago that there was no match.

—I did not say that at all. The Honourable senator should go and have a look at the Hansard because I have. It should be remembered that assurances of support are not new by any means. They were first introduced by the Menzies Government in 1955, although they were called a different name. While the name has changed, the system has been basically in effect ever since then.

PARA.TAB: The difficulty is that not only do these debts of 1990-91 not necessarily relate to assurances of support in that year, but also a great many of them are up to 10 years old. It is going to be very difficult in terms of systems problems for my Department to work its computer programming to try to cover a decade of assurances of support. It has to be remembered that it was only in 1988 that the idea of transferring this to Social Security to follow up was even thought of, given that governments previously did not worry about it. The Fraser Government's answer to this had always been to waive the debt. We did not want to keep doing that, so we have taken on the task.

There was a delay immediately in 1988 when Welfare Rights challenged our capacity to do it. This group said, given that we were operating under Migration Act regulations, that it could not be done under Social Security, et cetera. That took 12 months or so to iron out. Now that we have ironed it out, we intend to chase through the files manually. Obviously, this will take quite a bit of time because we will have to go back over a decade of people. Some of the people who were involved will be dead; some will have already left Australia and gone to other places and we will not be able to chase up money from them.

In times of recession governments also have to determine just how hard they want to chase. If people gave assurances of support five years ago or whatever—even if it was two years ago—and they had a job and all of a sudden they are out of one, it is very difficult for the Government to chase them. I am not sure whether Senator Patterson is advocating that if people are in this situation we sell up their homes or whatever. But the Government will identify as many of them as it can and we will certainly raise a lot more money than $9m over time as we examine the files one by one, and there are thousands of them. So it will be a long term job but it is one that we will undertake. As soon as we can identify exactly how much can be collected from the exercise, we will let Senator Patterson know.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. He will be aware of the excellent work undertaken by his Department's North Australia Development Unit, a unit which focuses on the social impact of government policies in isolated rural communities. In view of the transfer of this unit to the newly expanded Office of Northern Development in Darwin, will the Minister guarantee that the social justice work of the value for money project—a project to protect Aboriginal communities from unscrupulous traders—is not disrupted by the administrative changes? Furthermore, will the Minister liaise with his ministerial colleague Senator Collins to ensure that the economic focus of the new office is matched by the social impact priorities pioneered by his Department?

—Senator Reynolds would know that the idea of transferring the unit out of my Department is one that the Government considered over many months, given that NADU had taken on a role which was well and truly beyond that of the Department of Social Security and into a whole range of other issues. It was difficult in that circumstance to work out exactly the best resting place for it. In the end, after lengthy discussions with the Prime Minister's office and with Senator Collins, it was determined to transfer it over.

PARA.TAB: It is not only a matter of making guarantees to Senator Reynolds about the value for money project. I think I can make a guarantee that all of the work that had been undertaken by that unit will be continued and furthered. Having Senator Collins involved is probably better in any event because, as the Minister for northern development, he is in touch with so many of the communities which will benefit from the work of NADU.

There is an arrangement between departments that these matters will be monitored to make sure that they are not falling off in any area. Having visited north Queensland last week and talked to representatives of a number of Aboriginal communities, I think they are pretty well satisfied with the transfer. They are a bit sceptical but they understand that we will be watching it very carefully to make sure that none of the problems which could have occurred if we were to drop off in intensity will occur.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Prime Minister to the CANATA agreement between Australia and Canada which specified that Australian canned fruit `would receive no worse tariff treatment' and the further agreement reached between Mr Hawke and the Canadian Prime Minister, Mr Mulroney, at CHOGM in 1989 in Kuala Lumpur, that `Australian canned fruit would remain fully competitive with other suppliers'—in effect meaning that there would be only minor tariff differences at the end of a 10-year period. In view of the Canada-US free trade agreement that will have the effect of reducing US tariffs to zero per cent, leaving eventually a 10 per cent to 15 per cent tariff difference between US and Australian fruit into Canada, and the fact that Australia because of the present tariff differential has already lost 30 per cent or $30m from the Canadian market—its best export market—did Mr Hawke, at the recent CHOGM conference in Harare, secure from Mr Mulroney a watertight confirmation of their agreement that Canada would abide by the 1989 joint prime ministerial agreement that Australian canned fruit would remain fully competitive with other suppliers?
—I will have to obtain an answer from the Prime Minister about that. I am not sure what happened at Harare but I will obtain an answer as soon as possible.

—The Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade will be aware that the director of an Australian aid project in the Occupied Territories of the West Bank and Gaza, Mr Sami Khader, has been arrested and held in an Israeli detention centre. The aid project receives considerable financial support from APHEDA, the overseas aid agency of the ACTU. Mr Khader is amongst 2,000 Palestinians arrested in the past few weeks, bringing to over 15,000 the number of Palestinians currently detained without trial for resistance of the escalation of settlements in the Occupied Territories. Has the Minister any information from the Israeli authorities regarding the personal safety and well-being of Mr Khader? What representations is the Australian Government making to the Israeli authorities regarding the continuing violations of the basic human rights of Palestinians living under occupation in the West Bank and Gaza, and Mr Khader in particular?

—There are really two parts to the question; one relates to Mr Khader and the second part relates to violations of human rights of Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza. Senator Crowley is right that this matter of Mr Khader was drawn to the Government's attention by APHEDA, the ACTU international development agency. Mr Khader was detained by the Israeli authorities on 1 October in the West Bank under military laws applicable to residents of the Occupied Territories. It is understood that charges may be brought against him.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Embassy in Tel Aviv has made representations to the Israeli Government. The Israeli Government has said that the case is still being investigated, although he remains in detention. His family has not been able to visit him in the detention centre near Tel Aviv but a lawyer has been granted access and on 12 November officers of the Australian Embassy were able to visit him in the detention centre. They found him in reasonable spirits. He had not, apparently, been physically mistreated but we do not yet have a complete picture on that. He clearly appreciated Australian monitoring of his case and the efforts of APHEDA in particular.

Regarding human rights in the Occupied Territories, that continues to be of concern to the Australian Government. The Government believes that the Israeli Government should abide by its obligations under international law in handling security issues. Our Embassy has not been able to confirm a figure of 2,000 Palestinians arrested during the past few weeks. But from available statistics there are about 14,000 prisoners in Israeli gaols, most of them tried and convicted. About 3,000 are awaiting trial or the completion of legal proceedings and about 600 are what are called administrative detainees.

The Australian Government has in the past made regular representations to the Israeli authorities concerning human rights violations in the Occupied Territories. We have deplored the deaths of Palestinian demonstrators and expressed our opposition to practices such as deporting Palestinian residents of the Territories. We have also raised our serious concerns on these and other issues in international forums, including the Commission on Human Rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. With reference to the tragic accident yesterday involving the Army Pilatus Porter aircraft I ask: given the fact that the normal load of this aircraft is six persons and there were apparently 10 on board, eight of whom presumably were parachutists and therefore equipped with parachutes and full combat gear and would have weighed considerably more than the standard 160 pounds to 180 pounds of a passenger, was the aircraft operating within its design maximum all-up weight? Secondly, was the aircraft correctly loaded within the permissible centre of gravity limits?

—I will give Senator MacGibbon the information with which I have been provided and, if there is anything left out, I will chase that for him later. Obviously, prior to answering, though, I think all of us should extend sympathy to the families of those who have died in the performance of their duties.

PARA.TAB: The information available at the moment is that the aircraft was flying in support of a parachute jump master free-fall course being conducted by the parachute training school at Nowra. On board were a pilot, an Air Force officer and eight parachutists. Two of the parachutists died in the crash; eight others were injured and remain in hospitals in the Sydney and Nowra areas. The pilot and one parachutist remain seriously ill but stable.

The pilot is one of the Army's most experienced with this aircraft and the aircraft itself was a significant number of hours away from its next scheduled service. The task is a normal one for the aircraft, which had flown several sorties earlier in the day. The airstrip involved is also frequently used by this type of aircraft for similar tasks. The weather conditions were fine with no turbulence reported.

An accident investigation team from the directorate of the Air Force safety unit has commenced investigations at the site. An Army board of inquiry has also been appointed. All similar aircraft have been grounded as a precautionary measure. There is no reason to believe that the aircraft was being operated beyond its designed all up weight limits.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Is the Minister aware of a document from a company supplying direct mail databases to the New South Wales Liberal Party which indicated that confidential data about voters' years of birth and postal addresses came from the New South Wales electoral roll? Do the databases maintained by the Liberal Party contain illegally obtained information on New South Wales voters? Can the Minister assure the House that there has been no leak of suppressed voter records from the Australian Electoral Commission? Finally, will the Minister investigate any possible leak under the joint rolls agreement with the New South Wales State Electoral Office to ensure that confidential voter data is not finding its way into the hands of political parties, including the Labor Party?

—I thank Senator Sowada for raising this issue in the first place. It was on 27 September before the Senate committee of inquiry into the disclosure and advertising ban Bill that she initially raised this matter and I think also in a press statement soon thereafter. I am not aware of the document Senator Sowada has referred to. However, I am advised that the New South Wales State Electoral Office did provide roll information in the form of computer tapes to the political parties in New South Wales prior to the May State election. The State Electoral Commissioner has advised the Australian Electoral Commission that the tapes were provided to the political parties only and were not provided or sold to anyone else. The Commission is required, under State legislation, to provide the political parties with the tapes during the life of each parliament.

PARA.TAB: I think Senator Sowada's concern is as to the availability of confidential roll information such as date of birth and actual address, et cetera. The Australian Electoral Commission, as a result of Senator Sowada raising this matter on 27 September, has been made aware that the major political parties in New South Wales have had access to non-public roll information about New South Wales electors, including that information that the Senator referred to—years of birth and postal addresses.

On being alerted to this, I am advised that the Australian Electoral Commissioner did direct an investigation. As a consequence of that, I am advised that under longstanding joint roll arrangements with New South Wales, the Australian Electoral Commission did provide the New South Wales State Electoral Office with a master tape of New South Wales electors prior to that election in May 1991.Extracts from these tapes are commonly used as internal working documents for the State Electoral Commission and for providing tapes of publicly available roll information to the political parties in New South Wales. I do stress, in terms of those political parties, that what they normally do get and what they are entitled to and nothing more, is the publicly available roll information. For this latter use, normal practice is for the State Electoral Office to suppress confidential information.

Due to what I am told was an oversight in the State Electoral Office, the confidential information was not suppressed, resulting in its inclusion on the tapes forwarded to the parties. The New South Wales State Electoral Commissioner has admitted full responsibility for this error and, at the request of the Australian Electoral Commission, has contacted the political parties concerned and requested recovery of the data from all sources to which it was supplied, including any persons or organisations to which the data may have been forwarded. The New South Wales Commissioner has agreed to this course and I am advised that both Liberal and Labor parties have returned the tapes to safe storage.

TALK.START.PARA: —How about the Democrats?

—I am not sure whether, under New South Wales legislation, the Democrats are actually entitled to this sort of information. My understanding is that the legislation was passed at a time when they were not the force in politics that they may be now. That is as much information as I can give Senator Sowada. I think it covers all the points she raised. In general terms, I am assured that the information has been returned. I am further informed that it has been returned from all sources, but if there is any confusion as to whether it is still in the hands of organisations not being the political parties involved, I will come back to the Senate and provide further information.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. I refer to the long running industrial dispute involving an abattoir owned by Match Plan at Camperdown in Victoria where a number of people have been engaged in activities which have included unlawful picketing, besetting, harassment and wilful damage. Is the Minister aware that this dispute has now been running for more than three months with a hard core of 25 persons engaged in full time picketing activities in order to keep others out of work, and that if work on the site is allowed to proceed there will be an extra 200 jobs for unemployed Australians? Can the Minister confirm that, despite the ready availability of work with the company, the bulk of these people are receiving the dole and as such are being paid by the Minister's Department to exclude 200 other Australians from jobs? Finally, has a mobile review team yet been sent out to the picket line and, if not, why not?

—I would assume that a mobile review team has not yet been sent to the picket line. I would not have thought that the mobile review team would have that as its greatest priority at the present time. There are targets identified for the team and it works on those targets.

PARA.TAB: I have heard of a dispute at the abattoir. I am not aware that there is unlawful picketing. I was not aware that it had been going on for three months, although that seems pretty close to right.

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't all picketing unlawful?

—I certainly do not regard all picketing as unlawful. I do not see that it could possibly be called that. I am surprised by the allegation. The policy of the Department, of course, is that unemployment benefits—either JSA or Newstart; in this case, JSA—are not paid while industrial action is continuing. I would have to find out whether anyone who is involved in this dispute is receiving a payment and try to determine on what basis it was received. When I have that information, I will provide it to Senator Alston.

—I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Because of the continuing violence in Croatia and the escalation of the war in and around Zagreb and Dubrovnik, can the Minister elaborate on his statement of 11 November and outline the specific economic measures Australia proposes to take against Yugoslavia?

—In Question Time earlier this week I said that the Australian Government would follow the course adopted by the European Community, but that there was some necessity to work out exactly what the European Community was doing in terms of sanctions. I am now in a position, in answer to Senator Jones's question, to say something about what the Government is doing in respect of this issue at this time.

PARA.TAB: The measures being taken will add Australia's voice in support of the peacekeeping efforts of the European Community. The purpose of it all is to try to encourage the parties in Yugoslavia to cooperate with the European Community so that a solution to Yugoslavia's problems can be found. In the beginning the European Community said that it would exempt from sanctions those republics of Yugoslavia which cooperated with the European Community. We propose to make the same distinction.

Having said that, the particular measures which the Government has decided to implement at the moment are that Yugoslavia's participation in the Australian program of training for eastern Europe has been suspended, so that only students from cooperating republics will be allocated places in 1992; Yugoslavia will be removed from the list of countries benefiting from the Australian system of tariff preferences and, again, cooperating republics will be re-listed amongst the places which continue to enjoy this advantage; and the Government will not sign the agreement on double taxation which has been negotiated between Australia and Yugoslavia.

Finally, although Australia does not currently sell any oil to Yugoslavia, should the United Nations Security Council take action on the European Community's proposal for an oil embargo against Yugoslavia, Australia will adopt the necessary measures to ensure compliance with that embargo. Listing one or other of the Yugoslav republics as a beneficiary of the Australian system of tariff preference does not imply a decision on recognition of that entity as an independent nation. If there is any update on that position, I will advise Senator Jones of it at a later date.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you listed any of the republics?
—No, not yet.
—I call Senator Button.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—During Question Time recently Senator Calvert asked me a question about fisheries research. I have obtained an answer from the Minister for Science and Technology. I seek leave to incorporate that quite long answer in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
Senator Button—On 7 November (Hansard, page 2667) Senator Calvert asked me as the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology the following question without notice:

Is the Minister aware of the decision by the CSIRO to place in mothballs for at least 12 months its sophisticated $16m fisheries research vessel, the Southern Surveyor, only 14 months after the vessel was originally commissioned? Further, is the Minister aware that both the CSIRO and Tasmania's professional fishermen have condemned the shortage of Federal funds which has caused the dilemma and placed in jeopardy an orange roughy fishery worth millions of dollars to our nation's economy? Does the Government consider it acceptable for a $16m taxpayer investment to be tied up for 12 months, or will the Government consider a reallocation of Federal funds to allow the Southern Surveyor to return to the ocean and its invaluable work? What assurances can the Government give the taxpayers of this country that this outrageous waste will not be allowed to occur?
The Minister for Science and Technology has supplied the following answer to the honourable Senator's question:
The facts are:
—CSIRO is facing a $0.55 million shortfall in its annual running and maintenance costs of $3.5 million for the Southern Surveyor.

—Southern Surveyor was purchased and converted between 1988 and 1990 at a total capital cost of $16.0 million; CSIRO provided $7.3 million and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy $8.7 million from the Fishing Industry Research Trust Account (FIRTA).
—In the past two years, CSIRO has provided extra funding totalling $1.2 million for the ship. CSIRO can no longer afford to carry the extra costs.
—The fishing industry does not contribute directly towards any of CSIRO's research or vessel operating costs.

—Approximately half the original operating funds were provided to CSIRO under the 1978 Cabinet decision declaring the 200 mile Australian Fishing Zone (AFZ). In return CSIRO was to provide about 90 days (50%) vessel time for AFZ research as reflected in the AFZ Agreement between CSIRO and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. Since that time CSIRO has met all cost increases for the vessel and as a result is now carrying about 65% of the total cost—this is the $0.55 million shortfall.

—The major factors contributing to the current shortfall are the lack of supplementation to CSIRO for actual wage increases because the vessel is managed and crewed under contract; the crew are not employees of CSIRO, and increased repair and maintenance costs.
—After careful consideration of the options to meet the shortfall CSIRO has developed a 5 year strategy to optimise the use of the vessel within its existing budget.
—This strategy involves laying the vessel up for 16 months from February 1992 until June 1993 then operating it at full capacity for 4 years until June 1997.
—The vessel's crew would be laid off in February 1992 and a new crew engaged in June 1993.
—The strategy provides for CSIRO to meet all existing contractual commitments to the Fishing Industry and DPIE.

—The strategy has been discussed with DPIE/ AFS who acknowledge CSIRO's financial situation and, in the absence of additional funds to operate the vessel, consider this appears to be the best available option to maximise both the value of the vessel and the time it can spend at sea.

—Alternate funding arrangements for the vessel are being explored with DPIE; the vessel management company for commercial charter work; and with the Defence Science and Technology Organisation (DSTO) who have expressed an interest in a 3-5 year joint operation of the vessel with CSIRO.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Remuneration of Service Men and Women in Gulf War

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Campbell asked me a question relating to the payment of allowances to members of the ADF who served in the Gulf conflict. I now advise the Senate that Senator Campbell's assertion that benefits to members who served in the Gulf conflict had not been paid is totally incorrect.

PARA.TAB: It is also quite erroneous to say that the Government has been tardy in honouring its promise to provide Australian service men and women with these benefits. Official records show that all eligible members' entitlements to the Gulf allowances and tax exemptions were actioned promptly and have been finalised. If Senator Campbell has details of any service member who has yet to receive his or her benefits, the matter will be fully investigated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Reid asked me a question concerning the National Museum of Australia. The Government is committed to the development of the National Museum of Australia. Construction of the museum was deferred with the view to its opening to the public by 2001, the centenary of federation of Australia as a nation.

PARA.TAB: The Government has provided an additional $1m in the 1991-92 Budget to enable the museum to develop a strategic plan and to provide a basis for the Government to bring to fruition its commitment to complete the museum by 2001. The council will need to consider, in the context of the plan, the question of the siting of the museum. The Aboriginal and other community groups will be fully consulted in the planning of the museum's development.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer.

SPEECH.PARA: Had the answer been given yesterday, I would have sought to have asked a supplementary question. My question was: where will the museum be located? It is clear from that answer that the Government has shifted somewhat from the original plan that it should be at Yarramundi Reach where the present display area is built. I think that the Senate and the public generally are interested and entitled to know why it is that this is taking place at the present time.

PARA.TAB: I have been prompted to ask the question because of correspondence which Professor Mulvaney has had with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and an article in the Canberra Times recently. The article stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the National Museum of Australia is headed for the Parliamentary Triangle followed a briefing from the Arts Minister David Simmons.
The author of the article went on to say:
I break no confidence, Prof Mulvaney, when I say that you're quite right. Sadly, Yarramundi Reach is a dead letter.

The Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson), in answering the question today, does not seem to have referred to the briefing—referred to in the article—by the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Simmons) which leads people to conclude that Yarramundi Reach is a dead letter and that the museum will be placed in front of the old Parliament House.

PARA.TAB: Is the Government aware of the views of the Aboriginal community in relation to this? The Minister said in his answer that the Aboriginal community would be consulted. The Aboriginal community has been consulted previously and made its view very plain. The council of the museum had settled upon Yarramundi Reach and for some reason that decision is now sought to be overturned. Why is that decision being overturned? Why are we now being told that the museum will be in the Parliamentary Triangle and not the splendid plan that it was previously? Does the Government not realise that the views of Aborigines about where the museum should be placed, and how it should be placed, are of some importance and interest, and that the Aboriginal advisory committee is quite adamant that the Yarramundi Reach site is where the museum should be placed?

To save time, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a copy of a letter written by Professor Mulvaney to the Prime Minister on 4 July this year and a copy of the Prime Minister's reply of 29 July. In that letter, the Prime Minister refers to the Yarramundi site as the originally selected site and indicates that he recognises that a move would be generally opposed by the Aboriginal community.
Leave granted.
The letters read as follows—
4 July 1991

SPEECH.PARA: The Hon R.J. Hawke
Prime Minister
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2601
Dear Prime Minister,
The National Museum of Australia

PARA.TAB: I am writing to you on a matter of grave concern and urgency, concerning the proposed change of site of the National Museum of Australia. I hope that you will share my concern at the quite unnecessary conflict that this proposal has introduced and trust that you will intervene to prevent what could become a major public controversy by outraged Aboriginal people, who would consider that their trust has been betrayed, and so threaten Aboriginal cooperation in this significant national enterprise.

You will be aware of recent media controversy on the proposed change of site from Yarramundi Reach to the Parliamentary Triangle. This move is favoured by the National Capital Planning Authority, and a number of newly appointed members of the Museum Council appear to be strongly advocating that change.

I write as Chairman of the 1975 Planning Committee on the Gallery of Aboriginal Australia (within the Pigott Inquiry on Museums and National Collections), a member of the 1981-82 Interim Council and a former Chairman of the Council of the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies.

The reality is that the Yarramundi site was selected for several cogent reasons from a large number of sites, but the relevant one in this context is because Aboriginal members of the above committees, and other Aboriginal persons consulted, were unanimous that a major Aboriginal presence in the National Triangle would be offensive to Aborigines, and that Yarramundi Reach met their requirements admirably.

On 21 June, together with Peter Pigott and Professor David Ride, I was invited to attend a Museum Council meeting to outline past policies. Pigott and Ride were both members of the Museum Council until recently, and the latter was Chairman of the Council's Building Committee. It is evident that council is divided on the question of a new venue, but that Aboriginal members and its Australia-wide Aboriginal Advisory Committee are adamant that the Yarramundi site is the only one acceptable, and that to move elsewhere would be a breach of a firm undertaking across a decade.
I have no doubt that Aboriginal frustration will result in a major public controversy centred in the national capital.

Should the Council, by a majority, and the Minister decide to move the location of the museum, it will be very divisive in the general community, and even more serious within the Aboriginal community.

One undesirable compromise would be to place the Aboriginal Gallery at Yarramundi and the other components near Old Parliament House. This would ensure a serious and permanent cultural apartheid in the national capital. Those Aboriginal persons at the Council meeting which we attended, were emphatic that this would be a disastrous situation. The National Museum must be a single, integrated entity, at this time when reconciliation is the objective in national policies.

I have written to you directly in this manner, in the hope that by your intervention, this potential barrier to reconciliation and undesirable controversy can be settled without public participation. I remind you, also that the consent of both Houses of Parliament probably would be necessary to approve a presence in the Parliamentary Triangle. I would be happy to provide any further information. I write with the full endorsement of Peter Pigott and David Ride.
I suggest that further information could be obtained from Ms Pat Turner, a member of the Museum Council and a Deputy Secretary within your own Department.
Yours sincerely,
John Mulvaney
Prime Minister
Canberra
29 July 1991

SPEECH.PARA: Emeritus Professor D J Mulvaney AO CMG
128 Schlich Street
YARRALUMLA ACT 2600
Dear Professor Mulvaney
Thank you for your letter of 4 July 1991 about the National Museum of Australia.

I appreciated receiving your views on the need to continue planning for the Museum on the basis of its location at the Yarramundi site as originally selected, rather than within the Parliamentary Triangle—a move which you indicate would be generally opposed by the Aboriginal community.

I can assure you that the Government has given no consideration to an alternative site for the Museum. Your comments, however, will be taken into account in any future strategic planning for the Museum's development. Such consideration will also take cognizance of the Government's commitment to a reconciliation process between Aboriginal and other Australians.
In the meantime I have drawn your letter to the attention of the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories who has responsibility for the future development of the National Museum of Australia.
Yours sincerely
R J L Hawke

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall not take any more time on this occasion, but I think the Minister should give a more detailed answer to my question as to where the Museum will be located.
—I did not say that Yarramundi Reach was a dead letter; it certainly is not.
—I didn't say you said it.

—I am not aware of the briefing of Minister Simmons to which Senator Reid has referred. The answer that I gave today was provided by Minister Simmons. It says that the siting will be considered, and that includes Yarramundi Reach.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Yesterday Senator Bishop asked me a question relating to the heading of a question without notice she asked of Senator Button in his capacity as Leader of the Government in the Senate. The heading read, `Leadership of the Australian Labor Party'. INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Olsen proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The Hawke Government's continuing missed opportunities to build economic growth and achieve sustainable job opportunities and while expecting the Australian people to accept a procession of `public relations' budgets, mini-budgets, industry and economic statements instead of much needed action.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call Senator Olsen, I understand that informal arrangements have been made to limit the debate to 85 minutes, with speaking times as follows: Senator Olsen, 15 minutes; Senator McMullan, 15 minutes; Senator Coulter, eight minutes; Senator Brownhill, 10 minutes; Senator Maguire, 10 minutes; Senator Kernot, seven minutes; Senator Crichton-Browne, 10 minutes; and Senator Childs, 10 minutes. With the concurrence of the Senate, I shall ask the Clerks to set the clocks accordingly.

—We are here today on the eve of the Government's eighteenth attempt in nine years to produce some kind of economic statement as a cure-all for the sickness that it, and it alone, has inflicted on the Australian economy. We have had 18 budgets, mini-budgets, economic and industry statements. There were three in fact this year: the March industry statement; the August Budget; and the November jobs statement. Where are we with the results? We are exactly where this parade of perception setting yet almost totally ineffectual statements have put us, and that is bumping along the bottom of a deep and patchy recession; the longest recession since the 1930s.

PARA.TAB: Not once in all of the verbose and grandiose detail of those previous 17 statements did the Government change its policy approach or even admit to being wrong in its policy approach. Not once did it make any attempt to abandon the very policy which sent us into such a fast and painful decline with its reliance on high interest rates alone to steer the economy and dampen demand. We know it certainly dampened demand but as a policy in isolation it steered out of control and along the way it wiped out the very heart of the Australian way of life: a job and a home.

Is it any wonder that the public is cynical? It is faced with a government about to announce a so-called job statement in an attempt to persuade us that it can somehow replace some of the jobs which it deliberately and cold-heartedly allowed to be eradicated. Is it any wonder that the State Premiers have turned their backs on Canberra when they are faced with a bickering, squabbling, non-performing bunch of politicians who happen to call themselves a government.

Yesterday, the Premier of Queensland, Wayne Goss, put it succinctly when he indicated that the leadership, not Australia, was at the forefront of this Government's priorities. It is a government paralysed by its leadership jostling rather than determining the policy direction we need to put in place to create long and meaningful jobs for Australians. So the Australian dream, a home—that achievable opportunity which sold us to migrants worldwide—is no longer a realistic expectation for Australia's younger generations; and jobs, the very thread which sews the fabric of our society together, are lost to many and are not ever even being experienced now by a growing number.

Eighteen statements down the track and the result is that one in every 10 Australians has no work and precious little hope of finding any in the next 12 months. With the school leavers about to come on to the job market in the next few weeks it is believed that as many as six out of every 10 school leavers in December may also be left without employment prospects and opportunities. Yet absolutely nothing this Government has so far displayed can in any way give any person hope that tomorrow will bring a new dawning from the statement it is going to put down.

I asked a senior economist this week how we would assess and quantify just one statement out of those 17—the March industry statement—and what it had done for Australia. He shrugged his shoulders and asked, `How does one quantify platitudes, public relations creations, policy half promises and policy ideas which tinker rather than correct?'. That question seems to say it all. These words could be a eulogy to 18 statements and nine years of non-cohesive economic direction. The nine years of the Hawke Government are littered with lost chances, missed opportunities, discarded ideals and broken promises.

Let us not forget that the architect of this policy direction is not only the Hawke Ministry as it is now but the pretender to the throne, the pretender to the prime ministership, Paul Keating himself. He was there participating during these nine years in this policy direction of high interest rates that have bankrupted people, broken families, destroyed businesses and destroyed jobs for young Australians. In fact, if one looks back, one sees that the track record of this Government is absolutely appalling.

It is not hard to reason why when the clash of the massive egos that we have at the top has created that policy impasse, the paralysis of government. Where that was not the problem, the Government simply would not take the necessary hard decisions which may have estranged it from its union base. Because of the Government's union base it would not and could not take vital taxation reform decisions. Paul Keating's option C for a broad based consumption tax was rejected in favour of an increasingly cumbersome, unwieldy, haphazard and costly wholesale sales tax system that it expanded from $3.5 billion worth of income in 1983-84 to $11 billion now. The Government has got its consumption tax but it is a hidden consumption tax. It just expanded the wholesale sales tax net to catch a lot more people in the net and gain a lot more revenue. It is taxation by stealth because the Government is not prepared to front up with major taxation reform for the long term well-being of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —And no compensation.
—There are no offsetting factors—none at all—but behind the scenes the Government is prepared to expand the hidden wholesale sales tax that everybody pays every day of the week.
—Along with bracket creep.

—Yes, along with bracket creep which is destroying incentive and destroying productivity gains that come from the incentive of wanting to work and produce more in the workplace. Because of its union base the Government could not and would not dare tackle deregulation of the labour market when it deregulated the financial markets in 1985—a major imbalance in the policy direction of this country. Nor, because of its union base, has it had the fortitude to move along micro-economic reform at the pace essential to ensure that the manufacturing sector can restructure and perform competitively. In other words, the Government is removing the tariff barriers but it is not at the same time removing the cost impediments to our manufacturing industry via micro-economic reform.

PARA.TAB: The March industry statement this year makes that last point glaringly evident. If the Government had been so serious about the future economic health of Australia it would have and could have included new initiatives on labour market reform and rail, coastal shipping and waterfront infrastructure reform. But they were not there. The Government is stale and it is so impotent, so cowardly and so beholden to the union movement. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) has been working on draft industrial relations legislation but, because the ACTU will not cop it, 18 months of drafting legislation has now gone out the window. The Minister is not prepared to take on the ACTU when he knows it is right because he has been working on that legislation for 18 months. Because he could not get past the door of the ACTU and get its agreement, 18 months of legislative work has gone. He knows it was important for the benefit of Australia in terms of industrial relations and structural reform but he is not prepared to proceed because of the attitude of the ACTU.

The Government would rather see the further demise of our manufacturing sector than offend the union movement. More jobs gone to keep more union mate bosses happy! It certainly seems the end result. How can a government be so lacking in foresight and policy direction when manufactured goods make up some 70 per cent of our imports yet only 20 per cent of our exports; when we have a severe shortage of venture and development finance in this country; when we are the only industrialised country in the world not to have an increased proportion of exports to GDP; when only Spain invests less on research and development than we do; and when the Economic Planning Advisory Council says our labour productivity is still declining?

Surely these facts would spell out to any government that we are in deep trouble and that action, not perception of action, is what is called for; and that we need a sense of direction, purpose and rekindled hope for Australians. But the Government is taking no direction to rekindle hope for the Australian community. In the light of that overwhelming list of failures behind us, how then do we judge tomorrow's job statement? Can there be anyone left in Australia who can trust that the actuality of tomorrow's statement will come anywhere near meeting the perception it will aim to create? I doubt it. Jobs, or more importantly the lack of them, is tomorrow's main subject area. But we know that is only because Paul Keating's cheer squad forced the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to consider the 10 per cent unemployed worthy of consideration as a community concern and also due to the pressure that the Premiers have been applying to the Prime Minister and the Federal Government.

The States are screaming for job support and stimulation. I remind Senator McMullan that there are five Labor Premiers. It is the States which have to face the front line problems when our social fabric starts to unravel as jobless numbers rise, with increases in crime, homelessness, bankruptcies, domestic violence, child abuse and suicide and increasing pressures on the social structure of our community. All those pressures are being applied as a result of a lack of economic direction in this country. Real government, true government that puts the good of the country first, when faced with such enormous social problems would not be looking for just a quick hit fix headline. It would be looking at changes in policy direction and long term agenda.

It does not take a mind reader to work out which way the Prime Minister will slant his statement tomorrow. Perhaps he will dust off some old speeches. Perhaps we will have a recycling of the `no child will live in poverty' type of statement, or maybe a clever country theme.

TALK.START.PARA: —A soft landing.

—Or a soft landing. Perhaps he will announce projects, not policy change. Will it be roads? Will it be runways, or better cities? Despite admitting that it will accelerate the better cities program, the Government is not proposing to spend any money on it in the next financial year. The Prime Minister has at last acknowledged in the Australian that the press got it right when it reported that document that went to Federal Cabinet on Sunday evening. Initially, the Prime Minister denied it publicly. Yesterday, a little more pressure was brought to bear and he had to back off and say, `Yes, that was the document that went to Cabinet on Sunday. We are going to accelerate it and put out $652m, but we are not going to spend the $652m'.

PARA.TAB: What an absolute nonsense! Again, the Government is setting public perception, not achieving the bottom line purpose of creating meaningful, long term jobs for Australians. Not at all. It is about getting a headline, trying to convince the public it is doing something—creating action—when, in fact, it is not doing anything on the bottom line to create real jobs for Australians. It is treating the symptom, not the disease, applying bandaids to try to quench the haemorrhaging of jobs that we have in this country at the moment.

That is not what Australia needs and the Government full well knows it. We need jobs now, but we need them through policies—not individual projects—that create jobs. For example, if tomorrow there were an honest—if perhaps belated—attempt at turning around the job market, we would hear much about an immediate effort to look at anti-dumping controls.

It is interesting that Dr Michael Deeley, managing director of ICI Australia, has recently said publicly that one-third of all Australian imports are dumped. His view was supported, I might add, by the ACTU in its presentation to the Government a fortnight ago that anti-dumping is one of the most important things that need to be acted on in this country. It is Dr Deeley's view that immediate anti-dumping controls to halt the deluge of cheap items on to our market would create more jobs in Australia than even a further fall in interest rates. That view is shared generally by industry, by the ACTU and by many other groups within the community. If the Government were serious, what we would see tomorrow would be not a public relations exercise, but some meaningful measures.

I remind the Senate that the March industry statement legislation is just now turning up on the table. It is only now, eight months after that industry statement was brought down, that this Parliament is considering legislative effect to that statement. Does that mean that as a result of the statement tomorrow, it will be the middle of next year before we see any legislation to create changes in policy that will bring jobs to Australians? That is the track record of this Government. It tries to set the public perception and does not worry about taking action—let that flow down the track in due course. That is why so many Australians are out of work today.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is somewhat strange in Parliament to hear a member of Parliament complaining that the Government too often comes to Parliament with statements about the economy. That concern is based on two fundamental misconceptions. One is that it seems to me obvious—and I am surprised that it has not occurred to Senator Olsen—that a democracy requires that when a government is going to take action on the economy, it ought to come in here and advise the Parliament what it is that it is going to do, and that it does so frequently is a plus, not a minus.

PARA.TAB: More importantly, it says to us that the old era of once a year budgets and once a year economic statements is long gone. It is possible to argue that it was never appropriate, but that is a debate for the historians.
