What is clearly apparent is that as the rate of change in economic circumstances increases rapidly, as the availability of information about the state of the economy changes and increases rapidly, it is no longer appropriate to contemplate a circumstance in which policies are set in place some magical day in August and not reviewed and not revised. It always was, in my view, an absurd proposition; if it were not so historically, it certainly is now.

Ironically, of course, we often hear the shadow Treasurer call for mini budgets. As soon as we propose that there should be a statement he says, `This is a terrible thing. You are proposing to change direction and this is a sign that there is something wrong'. A few weeks ago the Opposition was saying that it is exactly what we should do. The real concern of the Opposition is what is going to be the distinction between what is in our document and what it would propose. It is that question of substance to which I wish to turn in a moment. Let us continue with this discussion of the question of process.

Those who would advocate that there is something wrong with having perhaps three economic statements in a year, as we have had in 1991—for which I make no apologies and, in fact, which I think is entirely appropriate to the circumstances of 1991—are those who would advocate the fixed solution to changing problems. That has been the position of the conservatives in Australian politics for a decade. They stand transfixed in the face of changing economic circumstances, advocating the same policy mix whatever the circumstances. If the economy is growing too quickly, they say, `What you should do is cut wages, cut public spending and change the tax mix to increase indirect taxes'. If the economy is not growing quickly enough, they say, `You should cut wages, cut public spending and change the tax mix to increase indirect taxes'.

They do not need a series of economic statements because they have had the same policy for 10 years in the face of changing economic circumstances. I believe they were not appropriate policies for any of those circumstances, but they cannot possibly be appropriate economic policies for all circumstances. It is inconceivable that they could be.

Reflected in the attitude expressed by the advocates of `Don't bring in an economic statement. Let us have one set of policies over the decade irrespective of the changing circumstances'—those who have developed in the cloistered environment of the IMF, the university and the merchant bank—is an elegant economic theory which anybody can find in an American textbook from Chicago. Every time reality does not conform, they think reality must be wrong. How could it be that there is no economic evidence around the world to support the theories that are being advocated? Where people have tried these policy mixes, the outcome has not been as is advocated.

Let us return to the prospect, as the Prime Minister has indicated, of a statement to be made tomorrow. That statement will not be a major change to long term economic strategy. That is the one thing which Senator Olsen has said which is correct. It will not be, because it should not be. The basic thrust of long term economic policy is for a sustained economic recovery of the type which Australia has not been able to enjoy since the First World War. All the evidence is that economic growth rates in Australia in the last 75 years have been lower than the international comparisons and lower than they might otherwise have been with appropriate mix of policies.

It is appropriate that we should be having essentially a stable pattern of fiscal, monetary and wages policy, and I am confident that will continue after tomorrow's statement. Let us not forget that, while we are in the middle of a very serious recession which is causing pain to many people, when we find the hyperbole about the nearly nine years of Labor Government, notwithstanding the serious problems of recession, we have 1.54 million more jobs in Australia now than we had in 1983 as a result of the phenomenal success of job creation of the Government in its first seven years. That is not to minimise the cost of the recession to individuals and to families affected by it, but it seeks to give some sense of perspective that is in context and in terms of the impact of the series of economic statements made by the Government since 1983.

What we will have tomorrow is another element of short term response within a coherent long term framework of fiscal policy, monetary policy and wages policy designed to achieve the sort of sustainable recovery which—to the shock, horror and concern of the Opposition—all the responsible economic commentators are saying indicates that in the course of 1992 there is likely to be a pattern of moderate low inflationary growth which is sustainable in the long term and which causes great fear and apprehension to the Opposition. If Opposition senators do not understand that they have all too narrow a lead in the polls against the Government in the middle of a recession, they should know that when that recession recedes so will their lead. Any sensible analyst would understand that.

On the last occasion we discussed these matters in the Parliament, I talked about encouraging signs in the economy. The Opposition went into apoplexy and said that that was a terrible thing to say. I was quoting the National Australia Bank which was indicating—

TALK.START.PARA: —And you were wrong. That was eight months ago. We have not had the recovery that you talked about then.
—Senator Olsen is very excited about that being eight months ago. Actually, it was about two weeks ago. Senator Olsen should relax. As usual, he is seven and a half months out of date.
—No. The last time the Minister responded to an economic debate with me was eight months ago. He then said that small business was about to restock and that the signs of recovery were there.

—The debate I am talking about took place two weeks ago, but Senator Olsen is seven and a half months out of date. That is not a surprise to anybody except Senator Olsen. Westpac has made similar reports. The Opposition may not be quite so concerned about Westpac. There may have been something about the National Australia Bank that particularly upset those opposite. We find from Westpac a forecast for 1992 saying that Australia's growth will be 2.3 per cent next year, which is better than or equal to New Zealand, the United States and Japan. It is not something about which we should be excited because a figure of 2.3 per cent is not, long term, a rate of growth to which we aspire. We would hope that, long term, it will be higher. But it is not an insubstantial rate of growth, and in terms of the international economic environment in which we find ourselves it will be a satisfactory performance and the platform on which continuing sustainable growth can be based. With inflation at 3.5 per cent, it is comparable with all those other countries to which I referred.

PARA.TAB: We are talking about a circumstance in which all the responsible economic commentators, all the banks and all the independent analysts are saying that 1992 will be the year in which recovery will commence and moderate sustainable recovery will be achieved with low inflation, while maintaining the success on the balance of payments front. That is what those people are saying. I think their views are right. Westpac is also saying—and as circumstances change so it is appropriate that the fine-tuning of economic policy should be modified—that we now do not find a concern about overheating in the economy as occurred after the previous recession. I think that that is correct. The situation where we have the basis for modest growth without the risk of overheating gives the opportunity for the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to make a statement tomorrow that can enhance the job creation success of the recovery. It gives room to move in a manner that is consistent with overall strategy.

There is a continuing case for all governments in terms of contemporary economic management to have flexibility to continue to introduce economic packages such as those which have been introduced this year—the rural assistance package, the reduction of taxes on business inputs, the enhanced depreciation regime and so on. Are people saying that these things should not have been done? Of course they are not. They are simply saying that they wish what we were doing was introducing a consumption tax to blow out of the water the success on inflation. They ask us to slash government spending by $4 billion and to destroy 46,000 jobs, which are the announced policies of the shadow Minister for finance. It is suggested that we should have had a balanced budget which would have cost 40,000 to 50,000 jobs as the solution to unemployment—that is, to throw more people out of work. It is said that the solution to inflation is to put up prices, and that we should be changing the labour market so that the weakest workers in the marketplace are less protected. That is the solution to increasing living standards—allowing workers' wage standards to be cut. It is the very old conservative formula—that when one has a problem with unemployment one puts people out of work; when one has a problem about inflation one puts up prices; when one has a problem over living standards one cuts wages.

That is not what will be contained in the Prime Minister statement tomorrow. If honourable senators opposite are worried that that is not the case, I am sorry for them, but I am not sorry about it. It is not what should be in the policy and it will not be in the policy statement. We will find another example of a statement which modifies at the margin the policy directions to give some extra impetus in the area of jobs. It will sustain a stable macro-economic environment which government is obliged to provide. It will continue to have the moderate stimulus from the automatic stabiliser that flowed from the Budget—a stimulus which those opposite would not have provided and which would have made unemployment worse. It will continue to allow the moderation of monetary policy which has led to interest rates being at their lowest rate for a decade. It will continue the stable and effective wages policy which has been developed over the past nine years and which has created the preconditions for and enabled us to achieve record low inflation and low inflationary expectations.

TALK.START.PARA: —You get inflation out of a depression.
—Nobody but Senator Crichton-Browne believes that. The inflationary expectations are that Australia will be able to sustain this low inflationary environment.
—As long as you have a depression.

—No, because all the banks are saying that next year we will have growth and low inflation—and Senator Crichton-Browne is petrified that they might be right, and I believe that they are. Those opposite are concerned that the economy is about to recover, and the only thing they have going for them is about to evaporate. They come in here trying to create an environment in which they hope the public might perceive tomorrow's statement. I am delighted to say that people are not listening to those opposite. I am delighted to say that the Prime Minister's statement will be seen as a positive contribution to responsible economic management in Australia. It will address the issue that Australians are most concerned about. If those opposite go out into the streets of any city and ask, `What is the biggest issue in Australia—the tax mix, vertical fiscal imbalance or jobs?", the people out there will answer that it is jobs. That is what our statement will be about tomorrow. The proposal of those opposite is absolutely wrong and out of touch with the needs of modern Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats would agree with most of the statement in this matter of public importance debate this afternoon. I find it passing strange that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, Senator McMullan, should have criticised the Opposition for not looking at the facts in the light of its economic theory. It seems to me that if one looks at the facts, one sees that Australia during the time of the Labor Government has built up its largest foreign debt ever and has over a million people unemployed. We have seen a massive shift of wealth from the poor to the wealthy, a shift which is still continuing. We have seen a shift of capital from productive investment to speculative investment and we have seen high and rising immigration rates lead to a capital widening rather than a capital deepening. In light of this the Government is still persisting with the same policies.

PARA.TAB: Even stranger is that the Opposition would pursue precisely the same policies. Indeed, the Opposition is as driven by market economics, by so-called economic rationalism, as is the Government—perhaps even more so. Today, Senator Button quoted Alexander Downer, who remarked recently that the Opposition would have done what the Government has done in its term since 1983 but it did not have the guts. That was quoted in this chamber earlier this afternoon. The former shadow Treasurer, Mr Howard, said of the policies of Mr Keating, whom a moment ago Senator Olsen described as the pretender to the throne, that they were ones which had a relatively easy passage because the Opposition agreed with most of the policy changes which Mr Keating was introducing. While we agree with the statement, as we have said before, we find that the Opposition would have landed Australia in precisely the same predicament, perhaps even more quickly than the Government has done.

Moreover, neither the Government nor the Opposition has any long term view of where it sees Australia's position in 10 to 20 years from now, simply leaving the economy to the market and to the naked forces of aggression and greed which will not deliver Australia the sort of future to which it must aspire.

There is a considerable arbitrariness in the cultural arrangements which a society makes for itself, including economic arrangements. This is one of the things that honourable senators in this chamber and, indeed, honourable members in the other chamber have, by and large, totally ignored. It is an unfortunate fact that we have very few scientists who enter politics who have a biological basis to their understanding of social relationships. As a consequence, they believe that the natural world outside can be pushed around in much the same way as human relationships and social arrangements and economics can be pushed around. That is simply not the case.

There is a real world out there with which we must conform. As I have said many times in this chamber, the real world of tomorrow will be a greenhouse world in which we as a society must conform if we are to build a viable future. That is what this debate is supposed to be about: a viable future for ourselves and our descendants. I quote a very famous economist from this country, Dr H.C. Coombs. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: There is nothing divinely ordained about the economic system: it is the product of human ingenuity, effort and capacity to organise and can therefore, properly be questioned, criticised and, if a better alternative exists, rejected.
That is one of the things that neither the Government nor the Opposition is prepared to do. In his most recent book, Stephen Boyden said:

PARA.TAB: In contrast, the biologically determined sensitivities of ecosystems or of humans are not changeable.

In the long run, if humans and civilisation are to survive, then their economic and political systems must be attuned to the underlying immutable laws of nature. In the final analysis, biophysical realities take precedence over cultural—

SPEECH.PARA: I would include there, economic—
arrangements.

That brings me to the point of difference in the wording. The wording in the matter of public importance includes the words `to build economic growth'. The Australian Democrats have been criticised in this chamber quite unfairly in the past when questioning the idea of growth. Economic growth refers to a progressive exponential increase in the dollar value of goods and services manufactured year on year after having taken out the inflation factor. It refers to a real and exponential increase in the flow of resources through the economy. It is clearly not sustainable in the long run.

PARA.TAB: More importantly, this afternoon I want to stress that, as measured by economists, economic growth includes many things which are really costs. I ask Senator Olsen whether, for instance, when the $6 billion is added—I stress added—to GDP as a consequence of motor vehicle accidents, he wants economic growth to occur by growth in the number of accidents which occur in Australia. Is that the sort of growth he wants? In using the term `economic growth' unqualified, I presume he is referring to what economists mean by economic growth; that is, growth of GDP.

Sometime ago I asked Senator Walsh, when he was Minister for Finance, about that $6 billion. He correctly pointed out that it did appear as an addition to GDP. He said, `If you start to take the costs out of GDP, it may be that all of GDP would gradually disappear'. Of course, if we were able to disentangle the costs and the benefits of GDP, we may well find that in the time since the Hawke Government the cost component of GDP has been the component which has been growing and the benefit component of GDP is the one which has been falling. Therein would lie a very satisfactory explanation of the fact that ordinary people perceive their conditions as having become considerably worse during the past 10 years, even while the economy was growing. I make a plea to both the Government and the Opposition that if they use the term `economic growth' they need to define that term rather more carefully.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the beginning of this year Australia had an unemployment rate of 9.1 per cent; interest rates were about 15.5 per cent; bankruptcies were up by 56 per cent; our monthly balance on the current account was about $1.86 billion in debit; our gross foreign debt was nearly $165 billion; and we had negative economic growth. Eight months later, following an industry statement, various Premiers conferences having been held with and without the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), at least one leadership challenge and one Budget, where are we? We have an unemployment rate of about 10 per cent; interest rates on rural loans remain at 15 per cent and higher—elsewhere it is 14 per cent—bankruptcies have increased by 72 per cent; the balance on the current account is $1.3 billion in debt; and our gross foreign debt is $166 billion. Honourable senators may well ask: what has changed? We started the year with problems of unemployment—over 600,000 persons without jobs—a recessed economy, a lack of stimulus, no business confidence and record levels of bankruptcies. We will finish the year in exactly the same way.

PARA.TAB: At the education level, we started with overcrowding and cutbacks to our universities and technical and further education colleges and the year will finish with record numbers of school leavers unable to obtain a course or tertiary education of their choosing. For some there will be no tertiary education at all. We started this year needing incentives, a start on projects such as Coronation Hill and the third runway at Mascot. But we are still awaiting a decision on these and other major projects, projects that could provide jobs and stimulate growth. The rhetoric of this Government will live on long after its deeds for, in truth, this Labor Government has done more to put people out of work, out of business, out of school and off their farms than any government in Australia's history—a terrible indictment of any government.

In March this year, after much fanfare, the Prime Minister delivered his `light on the hill' address. It was billed as Building a Competitive Australia. Mr Hawke said his intention was to deliver a statement about `What we must do together to meet the economic challenges facing this country'. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Government has a responsibility to lead the community by getting the right policy framework—we will do that.

The Australian electorate must be excused for asking just when this is to happen. The economic statement was designed as a major strategy on the direction this country should take. It was detailed and specific but, as we suspected at the time—and as we now know—it was all just words; words to prop up a failing leader and a tatty and dispirited team of sometime followers.

PARA.TAB: The intention was to make Australia more competitive. Has it done that? The answer is obviously no. We have levelled the playing field in Australia, but our rural industries are merely more vulnerable to corrupt world markets. Our wool prices are the lowest in real terms this century and the wheat markets have collapsed. The intention was to get more Australians working together; the reality is they are not working, neither are they together. One million Australians will be looking for work this Christmas but, unfortunately, they will not find it. This Government has not been able to achieve unity, even within its own ranks. The Age editorial of this morning says:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hawke came to power eight years ago promising to bring all Australians together. These days, the Prime Minister cannot even bring six state premiers together with himself to discuss how to revive his own apparently fatally compromised plans for reform of Commonwealth-State relations.

It is a terrible indictment on the Federal Government that it cannot even get its own Labor Premiers together. At the present time we have Senator Richardson wanting to drive the bus that runs over the Prime Minister; we have the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) door-stopping to torpedo the Premiers Conference and the Prime Minister; we have the Speaker of the House and other assorted colleagues arguing with the Cabinet and Caucus about a third runway; and we have the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) withdrawing industrial relations legislation because his ACTU masters do not like it. Increased productivity was much talked about, but soon abandoned.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at specific areas and specific promises. In the March statement the Prime Minister claimed that small- to medium-sized businesses were `key agents of economic growth and structural change'. He promised the establishment of a small- and medium-sized enterprise development program and some $3.4m was allocated. Yet how much better off is Australian small business? Small business bankruptcies in 1990-91 show that business failures are running as high as 70 per cent in some States, with an across Australia average of 50 per cent, and the rate is increasing.

What about the resource-based industries? The Prime Minister assured our resource industries, particularly forestry and mining, that legislation would ensure an environment that gave confidence to those companies to invest and proceed with their operations. But the Prime Minister forgot to ask his unofficial Cabinet—the green vote. Accordingly, at present in Australia we have dozens of projects waiting to proceed which are unable to do so because the companies involved cannot be certain that Government policy will not be changed tomorrow and render their operations non-viable.

What has happened to the magnesium metal project in Queensland, the Gladstone special steels project, the Geelong wool combing project, the Yabulu nickel refinery, the Boyne Island aluminium smelter, the Marando iron ore mine, the titanium dioxide plant in South Australia and the Tasmanian pulp mill? They all require some input, direction or assistance from this Federal Government. Senator Button has claimed they have all been obstructed by environmental processes, but the Government still refuses to make a decision.

Industrial relations reform is just as far off now as it was in March. The Minister for Industrial Relations suggested in his contribution to the March statement that there was a need in Australia for `reconciliation and renewal'. Eight months on, and only yesterday, we find headlines in the paper suggesting that the Federal Cabinet is still to decide on a proposed package of industrial relations reforms because the ACTU will not give the official nod. Monday's media detailed the trials and tribulations of an abattoir owner in Victoria who has attempted to use contract labour in his works but has effectively been held to ransom by the AMIEU. So much for the Government developing an atmosphere of `reconciliation and renewal'.

Where was it for this abattoir owner who had struck an amicable arrangement with his workers, but found that union labour did not like the idea? Where is it for the Western Mining company, with its new nickel mine at Kambalda? All it wanted to do was make sure that we remained competitive with the rest of the world by working a seven-day week and making sure we maintained productivity through continuous shifts. We will see 150 people lose their jobs there because the Government has not made sure that it has the right framework to enable everyone in Australia to understand that we have to work for a living.
In March, the Australian newspaper suggested that `A competitive Hawke fails his own test'. Only a day after the announcement, it said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the audacious reforms to the business environment are coupled with a marked reluctance to force change upon Labor's allies: the trade union movement and the greens.

How right it was. Other newspapers stated, `Many ingredients but no cake' and `More faith and hope than charity'. No action was taken to get Wesley Vale, Coronation Hill or the third runway going; and there is still none today.

PARA.TAB: Look at the lost opportunities for rural Australia: record unemployment, record crime levels, increasing suicides and rapidly declining farm and stock numbers. There is no hope for manufacturers, with half-hearted attempts at waterfront reform and reform of shipping and the railways. Any genuine efforts to gain productivity reforms have been abandoned. Promises of increased emphasis on education have been made, but the reality is that students will be turned away from tertiary institutions.

In March I said that Mr Hawke missed the point so badly that he could be likened to a snooker player who forgets to chalk his cue, does not know how to bridge his fingers and, in pulling back his cue, hits the black ball. Since then, I would suggest he has now pushed his cue forward, missed the white ball and ripped the cloth.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are debating a matter of public importance put forward by Senator Olsen which calls for policies to build economic growth and sustainable job opportunities. I oppose this proposition because it ignores a number of key factors. It ignores this Government's focus on getting the economic conditions right for medium and longer term growth, and it ignores our concentration on economic fundamentals for long term growth and for sustainable job opportunities.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, I would like to look at monetary policy and the role of this Government over the last 18 months in regard to interest rates, which is a very important economic fundamental. Monetary policy has been eased time and time again and rates have been lowered. But, of course, those opposite do not want to know about it. Interest rates were not originally set high as an end in themselves, but were designed to moderate spending on imports by Australians. That is the reality: they were designed to ameliorate the flow of domestic expenditure into imports because domestic production could not match total local spending. Australia could not keep financing a large import bill. After all, imports have to be paid for in hard currency and, as a result, interest rates were high in order to moderate that level of spending. But it is pleasing to note that our overseas balance of payments improved significantly during the last financial year.

It was very pleasing to note a 13 per cent increase in export volumes in the last financial year—in other words, real exports were up 13 per cent. I am pleased to point out on behalf of my State, which is a major producer of motor vehicles, that total exports of motor vehicles and motor vehicle parts now amount to almost $1,000m per year. Furthermore, last financial year, while export volumes rose 13 per cent, import volumes fell by 3 per cent. So there has been a major turnaround in our overseas balance of payments from some $22,000m in the previous financial year to $15,000m.

We have eased off interest rates and we have eased off the monetary policy control of spending in Australia. As a result, interest rates have come down significantly. There have been 10 rounds of reductions in interest rates since early 1990.

TALK.START.PARA: —You kept the controls on interest rates for too long.

—I would like to go back to January 1990. When we proposed lowering interest rates the present Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, said that an interest rate reduction at that time would be short lived, premature and political. That is what he said in January 1990. Since then we have had nine rounds of interest rate reductions in this country.

PARA.TAB: We have had contradictions from those opposite which show why they are not competent to run an economic policy or be given the chance to do it. Look at a statement made in this place by Senator Hill—the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate—as recently as 22 August this year. Despite Dr Hewson's saying that interest rate reductions were short lived, could not be sustained and were political and premature, Senator Hill came in here and said, `They should be lowered faster'. He said that in his keynote speech in reply to the Budget Speech. What a massive contradiction between the claims made by Dr Hewson last year and those of the parliamentary leader of the Liberal Party in this chamber. The Opposition cannot get a consistent line on economic management. Since then, cash interest rates have reached their lowest level for 12 years.

One matter that concerns the Opposition—and I understand it—is the importance of housing interest rates. Last year, the predominant housing interest rate from banks was 17 per cent for home mortgages. Now the predominant rates are between 12 and 13 per cent. I know that Senator Olsen understands this very well. Interest rates for home loans have come down enormously and they are very sensitive politically. Housing affordability has risen accordingly. As interest rates have come down in this country, housing affordability has gone up.

I turn to inflation because this is the jewel in the crown. The real success in this country has come in getting inflation down and cost rises out of the Australian economy. By the end of September last year, the consumer price index had risen by 6 percentage points in this country. This year, in the 12 months to September, prices rose not by 6 per cent, 5 per cent or 4 per cent but by a mere 3.3 per cent. There has been a massive reduction in inflationary pressures in the Australian economy.

What will concern those opposite at the end of January is that inflation will slump further. They will go into 1992 facing a Government that has got inflation down to 2 per cent. The reality is that the December quarter consumer price index last year was 2.7 per cent. That will not show up in the annual figures at the end of January next year. Even if the inflation rate for the December quarter this year is 1.3 per cent—double the present quarter—we will have a 2 per cent inflation rate in the Australian economy. Is that not a tremendous achievement? We are getting inflation out of the system in Australia. When those opposite left office, they had inflation running at 11 1/2 per cent. That was their record and it is objective fact. We will have inflation at a much lower rate than that.

One of the factors bringing down inflation is the reduction in interest rates. The wonderful thing now is that interest rates are part of the base for the consumer price index. We have already had an interest rate reduction since the last consumer price index was calculated. I can say right now that one factor is working to bring inflation down in the December quarter. We know what it is—the recent reduction in interest rates.

We are getting the fundamentals right in the economy. Interest rates have come down enormously. We are getting the parameters right in the form of cost inflation, which is down enormously from the record of those opposite. We now have a very competitive inflation rate in the Australian economy compared with those countries with which we trade.

I would like to hark back to December last year. The current Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, said on 22 December last year, on the record, `Inflation in Australia clearly is stuck between 7 and 8 per cent'. I have just detailed that inflation is now down to 3.3 per cent and heading towards 2 per cent. It will be 2 per cent by the end of January. The gentleman who is the present Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, said last year that inflation in Australia clearly was stuck between 7 and 8 per cent, and he is wrong again. Wrong again, Dr Hewson.

Let us look at the international comparisons for inflation, because this is where the real advantages are for the Australian economy. In the past, under the Liberals we consistently had inflation rates above the average for the 23 industrialised OECD countries in the Western world. Consistently, regularly and repeatedly we had inflation above the world average. It is now below the world average. Our inflation rate of 3.3 per cent compares with the average rate of 6.2 per cent of the 23 industrialised countries of the world. There is a tremendous cost advantage potential for Australian firms selling products abroad.

Look at the inflation rate. Our inflation rate now is lower than that of Japan. Is that not a wonderful achievement? Inflation is now lower than the 3.4 per cent in Japan. Those opposite worship the conservatives in the United Kingdom who said that they would bring in new economic policies and reform the British economy: inflation in the United Kingdom is 5.8 per cent compared with our 3.3 per cent.

Senator Olsen pretends to speak for the farm sector. Look at the inflation rates in those grain exporting countries that compete with us: Canada, 6.2 per cent; the USA, 5.0 per cent; and Argentina, of course, well above us. We are becoming very cost competitive. We are getting inflation out of the system in Australia. We will give our exporting industries a cost advantage when they sell overseas and we will make those traded goods produced in Australia and selling in competition with imports more cost effective.

TALK.START.PARA: —We know well the terms of this matter of public importance by this stage of the debate. Some of its key phrases are `missed opportunities', `public relations budgets' and `the need for action'. The Australian Democrats generally agree with the thrust of Senator Olsen's matter of public importance but, as is often the case, for very different reasons. The most obvious one would be that we would disagree on where sustainable jobs ought to be created. Senator Coulter has already addressed the issue of economic growth and the necessity for improving the measurement and quality of our economic activities.

PARA.TAB: I want to go to the first part of the statement and answer the question posed there. Has the Hawke Government continuously missed opportunities to build economic growth and to achieve sustainable job opportunities? The answer to this is undoubtedly yes, but it is silly to concentrate on Coronation Hill or resource projects. As this week's EPAC discussion paper suggests, the future of this country does not lie simply in resource development or real estate but in high value added products such as telecommunications, scientific equipment and biotechnology. That is why it is outrageous that this Government has totally neglected the solar power industry in Australia at a time when the world is finally starting to look seriously for renewable energy sources.

We are one of the few developed countries in the world which are net energy exporters. That means that, if some sort of global agreement is reached on the imposition of a carbon tax or some other kind of anti-greenhouse tax, we will be very heavily affected.Sensible forward planning by the Government would ensure that we would be able to replace the export of fossil fuels—which is not sustainable in the long term anyway—with the export of renewable energy technology. We already lead the world in this technology. Professor Martin Green has developed the world's most efficient photovoltaic cell; Solarhart and other firms produce world class solar hot water heaters; but we have no national strategy to develop and capitalise on the enormous potential employment which such an industry could create.

Another example of lost opportunities can be found in the area of railway development. We need urgent upgrading of our main line rail links and large investments in urban light rail systems. In the last eight years the Hawke Government has spent less in this area than was spent in one year of the Fraser Government's term. There are numerous other examples, such as the huge growth and employment possibilities which the creation of recycling industries will bring, as well as the swag of locally developed inventions which each year are bought up by foreign investors and then developed overseas, thereby shifting potential Australian jobs into actual overseas jobs. Some recent examples are the loss of Australian control of the gene shears technology and the inability of the developers of the Scram Jet to obtain local development finance.

The lack of appropriate amounts of venture and development capital is now widely recognised as a market failure, and at last the Federal Caucus is starting to demand some action on the issue. The Caucus working party on employment has recently called on the Government to legislate to create a national development fund with a small proportion of superannuation savings. This has been Democrats policy for many years, and it is tragic that it has taken a recession to get the Government to consider seriously its national obligations in this regard.

Perhaps the biggest missed opportunity has been the overvalued exchange rate which our farmers and manufacturers have had to contend with since the late 1980s. The Government's refusal to lower the exchange rate has been the greatest single blow to industry creating sustainable jobs. Of course, the use of high interest rates accentuated this overvaluation and then created the current recession, thereby destroying over 200,000 jobs.

So, yes, there have been many lost opportunities and there has been an awful lot of public relations hype in the way the former Treasurer has conducted economic policy. But to say that there has been no substance to the various Budgets and mini-Budgets delivered by the Government is simply wrong. To be fair, I think we should acknowledge some of the excellent tax reform work which has been achieved by this Government. We have not supported every decision, and neither will we in the future, but a lot of equity has been returned to the tax system.

However, in the area of micro-economic reform, the Democrats argue that the overall policy thrust has been incorrect. For example, the unilateral lowering of tariffs without, at the same time, a strengthening of the anti-dumping legislation has been suicidal. There should have been coordinated import replacement strategies operating between the Government and local industry. People who lose their jobs in industry restructuring should be automatically retrained, not left to live in poverty without any genuine prospect of alternative employment.

Similarly, the ridiculous notion of competition at any cost in telecommunications services is another area of Government policy which is totally opposed by the Democrats. The wholesale privatisation of government business organisations is also an ideologically driven notion which has no public interest benefit. It is also one which the Opposition continues to dish up to us.

So the Opposition wants action. Does that mean eliminating legitimate environmental concerns? Does it mean eliminating a Federal Budget deficit? Murphy's economic model predicts that this would cost 46,000 jobs. Does it mean eliminating all awards? Does it mean abandoning cabotage? Does it mean regressively changing the tax system to boost the disposable income of the wealthy? This is action but it is action New Zealand style, and it means that the disparity of wealth distribution will worsen and the lot of ordinary people will deteriorate.

The Democrats reject this simplistic analysis. The most important action the Government can take is to change direction in economic policy, and the statement to be delivered by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) tomorrow could well be Australia's last chance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, I endorse wholeheartedly the matter of public importance raised by Senator Olsen. Firstly, I might take up the matter raised by Senator McMullan, who sought to give the impression that Westpac is declaring that there will be a significant upturn in activity next year. The truth of the matter is to be found elsewhere. A newspaper article states:

PARA.TAB: Australia faced its longest recession since World War II, Westpac bank chief economist Bill Evans said yesterday.
He said the Westpac-Melbourne Institute's leading index of economic activity remained steady in September, pointing to the prospect of a weak recovery early next year.

SPEECH.PARA: He went on to say that, in the event that its analysis is right, this will be the deepest and longest recession this country has had since the 1930s. I find it cute that out of those statistics Senator McMullan can build an argument to suggest that Westpac is claiming that the recession has bottomed out and we are now on the way to recovery.

PARA.TAB: If ever there were a government in terminal decay and decline, it is the Hawke Labor Government. It is in a state of total paralysis and now, of course, is its time of reckoning. All of its rhetoric, all of its talk, all of its false dawns have been stripped away and the cruel reality of eight years of Labor Government is starkly before all of us. We might well look at the cruel reality of that record. Of one million people unemployed, 300,000 have been unemployed for more than 12 months. Thirty per cent of young Australians are unemployed—and 30 per cent of that 30 per cent have never been able to find a job—and 160,000 breadwinners are on the dole.

For every two job advertisements there are 100 people looking for jobs. That is the record of this Government in employment. Of course, that flows over into bankruptcies. During the eight years of this Government, 50,000 companies have become bankrupt. In Western Australia alone, the numbers have doubled from 1,000 to 2,000 in the last 12 months. That is the achievement of this Government after eight years.
I well remember something that the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, said at his 1983 policy launch. Talking about the record of the Fraser Government, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: One in ten Australians out of work—a figure no Australian would have believed possible a few years ago, and which no Australian government should ever be forgiven for creating.

Now we see a level of unemployment a great deal higher than that. The truth of the matter is that this recession is not a recession we had to have; it is a recession that this Government has induced. It has dragged Australian society into deep misery, unparalleled since the depression of the 1930s. The Government has caused despair, bankruptcy and desperation, not because of circumstances beyond its control but because of circumstances within its control.

PARA.TAB: The great tragedy for Australian society is that this is a Government that has been driven by minority groups. This has never been a government of consensus; it has never been a government for all people. It has been a government for selective groups who promise, at the end of the day as part of their blackmail, to deliver votes. This is a government that has survived on the basis of promises. This is a government whose single objective is to survive, and to govern for itself alone and not for Australians. Manifest in that is the recession we are presently having. If ever there was a dispirited, discredited and failed government, it is this Government led by a pathetic, humiliated and bullied Prime Minister whose total preoccupation is keeping his own job, with total disregard for everybody else's jobs.

I want to list the types of jobs that this Government has deliberately and wilfully passed up—meaningful, sustained, long term, productive jobs. Let me cite a number of projects: the Jabiluka uranium mine in the Northern Territory, 600 jobs denied; Koongarra, 500 jobs denied; Kintyre, 300 jobs denied; Coronation Hill, 515 jobs denied; Marandoo, 800 jobs denied; Yakabindie, 400 jobs denied; the Clinton mineral sands project, 180 jobs denied; the titanium oxide plant at Whyalla, 240 jobs denied; the Yeelirie project, 165 jobs denied; the Wesley Vale pulp project, 120 jobs denied; Amcor's bleached kraft pulp and paper mill project, 1,000 jobs denied; WA Chip and Pulp kraft pulp and paper mill, 1,200 jobs denied; ANM's Albury plant, 700 jobs denied; Daishowa's Grafton mill, 1,000 jobs denied; Forest Resources bleached chemi-thermo plant, 500 jobs denied; Paper and Pulp's Bagasse pulp mill, 500 jobs denied; and the ANM Albury recycling plant, 700 jobs denied. That totals over 7,500 jobs that this Government has refused to allow to proceed. The cost to Australia is $8 billion in investment alone and $2,920m in foreign exchange earnings.

This is not a recession that we need to have. This is a recession we are having because this Government has chosen, for political reasons, to visit it upon the Australian people. I imagine that tomorrow we will see another phoney statement talking about phoney jobs. We can always tell when this Government is in absolute despair, and that is when we can feel a ministerial statement coming on. We have had industry statements, mini-Budgets, tax summits, housing summits and job summits—none designed to relieve the problems which drove the Prime Minister to have them. They were only designed for the purpose of soothing, seducing and disarming the Australian public.

But alas, like all these things, there is an end point. Perhaps that end point was yesterday when the six State Premiers, five of them Labor, said, `Mr Prime Minister, we will not go through another charade. We will no longer visit Canberra as mendicants, simply to sit around for another talk-fest so you can put out another press statement saying, "All is well with the world, trust me, rely on me, I will cry some but in the end it will work out"'. Perhaps the final point has come with the Premiers. If it has come with the Premiers, it has come with the overwhelming majority of Australian citizens.

The solutions to the present problems in Australia are not sophisticated or complicated; they are simple but they take courage. They require the gumption and the fortitude to deregulate the labour market. They require the introduction of micro-economic reforms of meaningful purpose, whether they be on the waterfront, to coastal shipping, to transport or communication—all those things that are capable of making us competitive. They require the privatisation of those fat, bloated government enterprises that are consuming Australian taxpayers' money. More than anything else, they require a reforming of the tax system to give incentive, to reward effort, endeavour and savings so that the tax is not on income but on consumption.

Again, that is something that the past Treasurer, Mr Keating, knows about because he proposed it under his own option C. But because the ACTU knocked it on the head and this weak, vacillating, failed Prime Minister of ours capitulated, we did not get the consumption tax that we could have had at the beginning of this decade; and so Australia paid the price.

I have no doubt that tomorrow's statement will be ridiculed in the way that previous statements have been and that come the next election this Government will be ignominiously dumped from office. It no longer has the right to govern; it has forfeited that right.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Hawke Government has had a priority of economic growth and the achievement of sustainable job opportunities since its inception as a government. Tomorrow the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) will announce initiatives to accelerate job opportunities in this country. This matter of public importance criticises the Government's Budgets and statements, especially the March industry statement. I should like to refer to some industry issues because some very superficial things have been said today by the Opposition in this debate.

PARA.TAB: Contrary to the terms of the matter of public importance, I believe that government statements have not been public relations statements. There is something in the issue of public policy, because one of the problems in industry policy that we make no apology for is that this Government has sought to change attitudes on industry policy. It is not a simple matter of a snippy, snappy decision being made by some politicians, as one would have thought from coalition speakers. In industry we have had to change and transform entrenched attitudes of both management and employees.

Many changes have been made by this Government, and I will try to describe some of them. Indeed, there have been many qualitative changes since 1982, and I should like to mention a few of them to rebut what Senator Olsen said when he claimed that there were a few simple things that could be done. With the usual Liberal Party obsession, he proposed removing the cost of the impediments, referring to the unions as the key point of his formula.

This Government has furthered the education, training and multiskilling of our work force, which is a prerequisite for creating effective employment. We have also established, without question, compared with the previous Liberal regime, a cooperative industrial relations climate. We have had a basic reform of the public and private infrastructures. All of these initiatives represent an integration of workshop reform, education and training, which is the foundation of the effective creation of productive employment.

Senator Olsen referred to research and development in Spain. I thought that was very unfair because this Government introduced a 150 per cent research and development tax concession. It was announced in March that from 1993 the research tax concession will remain permanently at 125 per cent. In that area there is a contribution by this Government, but we cannot get over the problem that we have with Australian industry where there has been a tendency for industry not to recognise the need for its own research and development. But to give an unbiased and a balanced description of these changes one has to take into account all the factors involved.

I mention again, as I did the last time I spoke, because it has to be mentioned, that this Government has changed the culture. The most recent initiative was the $20m to promote the advanced manufacturing technology development proposals. All of those are important because jobs cannot be created in a vacuum.

I turn now to the critical area of education. To create employment in the current climate means that one has to plan. This Government has planned by making sure that during its term of office the retention rate at secondary schools has increased. It has gone from 34 per cent to 70 per cent. So we are laying the basis for young people to be trained properly to take their place in the modern industry situation that Australia faces.

Senator Brownhill, in criticising the Government, referred to Federal-State arrangements. No better example exists than that of TAFE in the State of New South Wales, where both Senator Brownhill and I come from. It is estimated that in 1992 90,000 students will be turned away from TAFE colleges in that State. That State has a Liberal-National Party government. Those 90,000 account for 56 per cent of all unmet demand in 1992. That unmet demand for TAFE nationally is projected to be 160,000 in early 1992.

The Commonwealth is obviously concerned that participation in TAFE over the last decade has been virtually static. While our Government has raised the retention rate, unfortunately under the State governments the TAFE area has remained static. That is the critical area for successfully going into modern technology and creating jobs that will be effective in both the manufacturing and the service industries. In fact, in the last three years the number of TAFE students has fallen significantly. This is unacceptable for a nation like Australia because jobs do not come in a vacuum, and we need a skilled work force to fill the jobs in the service and manufacturing industries. So I hope that the Government, whether it is tomorrow or in the near future, will take its education policies and the education and training of the work force to the next stage.

In the short time I have left, I draw attention to the fact that this is a very strange debate that we are having on the eve of the Government's statement. I feel that we should have this debate after the Government has made its statement tomorrow so that we can deal with the reality of the next stage of the Government's program. When it is introduced next week, or whenever it is introduced, the Opposition's proposal will not be to develop the human capital of our country, as I have described it. It will be to adopt a policy based on greed; on the old fistful of dollars that has served the Liberal Party so well in election after election; on literally a public relations process of trying to fool the Australian people that a consumption tax will not undermine the living standards of ordinary people, because it certainly will.

We can bet, even a week before the consumption tax is announced, that there will be significant cuts in the public infrastructure. We have seen the model. It exists in New Zealand. It is a model that the Liberal Party and—probably reluctantly—the National Party will adopt. The National Party will do as it always does; it will go along with the Liberal Party policy but, at the edges, it will criticise it and say, when it is in the country, that it does not quite support it.

The reality is that when the coalition introduces its consumption tax there will be a tremendous effect on employment, and that is what we are talking about, because it will add to the costs of ordinary people and reduce the amount of money that they have to use. We have to remember that whatever figure the Opposition decides upon for the consumption tax we can be guaranteed that it will increase if it were ever in government.

In the United Kingdom there was a 75 per cent increase, from 10 per cent to 17.5 per cent; in New Zealand there was a 10 per cent increase in just three years; in Austria there was a 150 per cent increase. So when we are talking about projected statements, honourable senators should watch for the coalition statement and not believe that the figure as announced will be the final figure that will be affecting ordinary people in this country. It is based on that threat to employment, as the purchasing power of ordinary people will be reduced, that we will have a very serious situation if the consumption tax is introduced.

When this proposal is introduced, part of the Opposition's package will include the inevitable cuts to pay for the fistful of dollars; the removal of Medicare; the privatisation of essential services; and the removal of indexation of family allowances, which is one of the achievements of this Government. Do honourable senators remember what happened when Liberal governments were in power before? Pensioners got their increases just before the election. This Government has indexed pensions so that people know where they stand and they have a guarantee of equity in their financial arrangements when they are on the pension.

So, for all these reasons, it is not simply a matter of talking about what the Government has done. I think it would be fair for us to come back in a fortnight's time and have a real debate comparing the consumption tax of the Liberal Party and the cuts that it will offer with the Government's position.(Time expired)
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crowley)—Order! The discussion on the matter of public importance is concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make a few brief remarks about this annual report. All honourable senators get bombarded with these reports during their time here in Parliament House and we all have a look at them. This report particularly attracted my attention, because I wanted to ask myself the question, `Why did the Commonwealth need to have a fire board?'.

PARA.TAB: At the outset, I am sure that the people who serve on this board do a very good job and try to meet the objectives of the board. Basically, the objectives of the board, as outlined in the annual report, are to: advise the Commonwealth on fire protection in its own buildings and properties occupied by Commonwealth public servants; advocate uniformity of practices and standardisation in fire protection; advise Commonwealth departments on fire protection matters; give consideration to the responsibility of the Australian Construction Services section; carry out inspections; act as a source of advice in relation to fire protection matters; advise Commonwealth departments where it is considered that deficiencies in fire protection exist; and so forth.

I come back to my question: why does the Commonwealth really need this body for fire protection? Obviously, it is something that is done very well at a State and local level right across the country. There is obviously cooperation between local fire brigades around Australia. I can see very little need for the Commonwealth to get involved in fire protection by having this Fire Board. It raises the supplementary issues as to what this board actually did during the last year, which the annual report refers to.

It is a nice looking report; it has a nice cover and it fills up quite a few pages. As far as I could judge from reading the report very briefly, the board investigated major fires, that is, fires where damage over $100,000 occurred, and the total cost of those fires investigated came to about $1.25m. The actual cost of running this board in the last 12 months was about half a million dollars. So the Commonwealth taxpayers—the poor old taxpayers of Australia, a diminishing breed—have paid out about $500,000 to investigate fires where the damage came to about $1.25m.

I put it to the Senate that those fires would have already have been investigated by the local and State authorities responsible in those States. I see little value in the Commonwealth spending even more money investigating these fires at that level. I would have thought a cooperative approach with the normal construction services and property officers from the Department of Administrative Services could easily do this and fulfil this function without setting up a board with all the associated people. The board has quite a considerable staff for the job that it carries out and, as I said, it spends about half a million dollars a year.

The only other discernible activity of the board that I could find in the report was that it issued three circulars. The board has issued a lot of circulars; it has issued many over the last 10 or 15 years. Last year it issued only three circulars: one on the removal of asbestos; one on portable fire extinguishers; and one which was a subjects index. These were not even new circulars; they were really just revisions of old circulars.

The Senate should be very careful in looking at the funding of these boards by the Commonwealth. The sum of $500,000 may not seem very much in the context of the annual estimates and expenditure of the Commonwealth of Australia. But as we all know, as with many of these groups that the Commonwealth funds, honourable senators should consider the very need for existence of the Commonwealth Fire Board.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to make some remarks about the annual report for 1990-91 of the Australian Safeguards Office by the Director of Safeguards dealing with section 51 of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Act 1987. As a signatory to the non-proliferation treaty, Australia has an interest in the operation of the International Atomic Energy Agency, which supervises the treaty at the international level. In recent months we have seen the total failure of the International Atomic Energy Agency to exercise its proper function with respect to detecting what Iraq was doing with its nuclear facilities.

PARA.TAB: I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that the functions of the International Atomic Energy Agency are of such a nature that it is confused over its role. On the one hand, it is charged with the responsibility of promoting nuclear energy. On the other hand, it is charged with the function of looking after nuclear safety at the international level. Quite clearly, these two functions are in conflict.

On the Dateline program last Saturday night there was an interesting interview with Paul Leventhal, the President of the Nuclear Control Institute in Washington, US, and Hans Blix, the Director-General of the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna. We found that the agency should have been well and truly aware, over quite some time, as to what Iraq was doing but, in fact, chose to turn a blind eye to it.
In his introduction to the program, Paul Murphy referred to the International Atomic Agency as a watchdog. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . this particular watchdog was snoozing in its kennel at the time; not that that matters—it has no teeth anyway.
Australia should direct very close attention to that matter because Australia teetered on the edge of nuclear war in the case of the recent Iraq-Kuwait conflict. Paul Leventhal went on to say:

. . . the Agency does a very effective public relations job of making people believe that there really is an effective system capable of detecting bomb-making. They have misled the public and, frankly, it's scandalous, because what we see in Iraq is just fair warning of what's to come.

In other words, Paul Leventhal is saying that Iraq is only the foretaste of what will happen in many other countries. Indeed, if one looks in today's newspaper one will see that South Korea is very concerned that North Korea may be developing a nuclear weapon and refusing international inspection of its nuclear facilities.

PARA.TAB: Also in the interview on Dateline on Saturday night, Peter Marshall said:

SPEECH.PARA: We found that certain figures in the Atomic Energy Agency have long been pressing for its inspectors to act as policemen, following up their own suspicions, but this idea has always been rejected. So frustrated did one inspector become 10 years ago, that he decided to speak out. He warned that one country in particular was planning to build nuclear weapons. For making these comments, the Agency sacked him. The country of which he'd warned was Iraq.

Ten years ago Roger Richter, who also appeared on the program, was an IAEA inspector who warned of what Iraq was doing. For his pains in warning the world as to what was in store, he was sacked by the IAEA. The program concluded with Paul Leventhal stating:
The only way you're going to have spot checks—
he is saying that that is absolutely necessary—
is if you take the safeguards authority away from the board of governors of the International Atomic Energy Agency and give it to the UN Security Council . . .
I strongly urge the Australian Government to dissociate those two functions—the promotion of nuclear energy on the one hand and the supervision of nuclear safety on the other—from the IAEA.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
