Then there is a section empowering courts to exclude people who have been convicted of offences for a certain or an indefinite period and sections dealing with the removal of the exemption from income tax, the imposition of statutory liens, the removal of aircraft under lien from Australian Territories and the validation in the form of regulations of a practice that has been going on for some while with reference to private companies in safety matters.

The first general observation I make about the amendments to the Civil Aviation Authority Act is that they are clearly written by the same person or persons who wrote the amendments that came before the Senate, I think, just before we rose for the winter recess. In other words, the amendments still have the same jackbooted, stand and deliver approach. I spoke at some length about that in the presentation of the last series of amendments to the Act. The same vein runs through the present Bill.

Almost everything attracts a penalty of two years in gaol if people are found guilty. That is at variance with many of the other penalties that this society exacts for misdemeanours, crimes or breaches of the law. Last time the argument that was put by the Government was that the Parliament had agreed to these rather severe penalties in similar circumstances with respect to aviation in the past and it was only conforming with that. We had the usual assurances that the legislation would be interpreted sensitively and carefully with due respect to the community. That is all very well, but the unfortunate fact of life is that, where we have draconian penalties, there will always be people who will use those penalties in a way that is not sensitive and at times inappropriately.

One of the problems we have is that the powers granted to the Civil Aviation Authority are very great with respect to somebody's livelihood. It can take away a pilot's licence and thereby deprive him of his livelihood. It can take away an airline operator's licence just as rapidly or it can take away a maintenance organisation's licence. The difficulty I have is that, after my involvement in the aviation industry of well over a quarter of a century, I do not see any change in the way the Civil Aviation Authority inspectors operate today compared with their operations 25 years ago.

I do not wish to get this out of perspective. The great majority of the inspectors and investigators do conscientiously discharge their duties honestly and accurately and with due caution to the best of their abilities. There are also those who do not. As I say, I have been involved in aviation for a long while. I have no illusions about the people who are involved in the industry. There are the good and there are the bad; there are the honest and there are the dishonest. But I do think that in the time that I have spent in the industry I can make a reasonable assessment of the good ones and winnow them out from the bad.

One of the difficulties I have is that the Authority very rarely goes after the bad ones. It may be that it does not have the insight to detect them, which it should have because the aviation community in Australia is a small community. It has always been a small community and people know what is going on. The Authority should know the good from the bad. It may be, as I suspect happens in a number of cases, that the Authority gets bullied by the bad operators who stand over the inspectors. I am not talking necessarily about very wealthy operators; once we get away from the airlines, there are no wealthy operators in the aviation industry. People who are doing the wrong thing often seem to be able to bully their way out. The people who end up in trouble with the Authority are often honest operators who just get harassed and get into a great deal of difficulty in their relationship with the Authority.

Unfortunately, as somebody in the former Department of Civil Aviation told me when I first learned to fly, the Department never forgets. Once there has been an infraction or a run-in with the Department in some way, the corporate memory is such that it stays with that body. That is an affliction that someone involved commercially in the aviation industry has to bear.

In relation to the amendments that are before us, I think that the penalties by and large are too severe. There are too many penalties of two years in gaol without any option. I come back to the way in which the investigations are carried out. One of the unfortunate things about the industry is the way in which investigators often operate alone, without any witnesses. At the end of the day, when an operator complains about something that has been done to him by the Civil Aviation Authority, it ends up being his word against the Authority's; there are never any witnesses.

I have had a large number of complaints made to me over the years. There are still complaints being made. If I could generalise without identifying any company, I could say that where a company or an operator is investigated the operator may hear nothing about it for four or six months. Meanwhile, those people do not know where they stand. I think the operators ought to be told the decision and be told as soon as possible.

Then there is the other problem, which I referred to before, of the abuse of authority. I will give two examples which have come to my notice in the recent past. The first concerned a company which was operating an aircraft. The aircraft landed to refuel somewhere and the Civil Aviation Authority inspector went up to the pilot in command of the aircraft and accused him of exceeding his flight time limitations. There was a tight schedule to be followed. The company was not exceeding its flight time limitations. But, in the end, it had to hire another pilot to complete the operations for the day because it had a contract to perform. The schedules were delayed. So the company was involved in unnecessary expense and emotional trauma. In that example, which happened some months ago, the company has not heard another word about it.

In another example, a company fired a pilot. That pilot made a complaint against his former employer, alleging certain breaches of regulations. The pilot, by the way, was fired for lack of competence as a pilot; there was no dispute about that. The company was not then investigated, but the Civil Aviation inspector went to one of the junior pilots of the company and said, `We have had these allegations made about the company; what can you tell us about it?'. The pilot concerned told the Department all it wanted to know, and there was no incriminatory evidence at all because the company is quite ethical. When the interview was over, the Civil Aviation inspector said to that pilot, `Don't tell your management about this. Keep this quiet; it is just between us. We will take it up with the company at a later date'.

The pilot concerned was very worried about that. After several sleepless nights, he told his manager. The manager called in the inspector and had a meeting with him. The long and the short of it was that the Authority denied that it had tried to stand over this pilot in any way—it had used quite a heavy-handed technique of interrogation on the junior pilot. In the end the manager of the company said to the inspector, `Look, you're telling me this didn't occur. My pilot said it did. I'm going to have no option but to fire him, because we run an honest company here and we won't tolerate untruthfulness. So what's the position? He's going to be fired on your say-so because your story is correct'. At that point the inspector ummed and ah'd and said, `Well, it may be that that interpretation could have been put on what I said'.

It is very hard to prove this in a court of law because it gets down to the inspector's word against the company's word. But I have been around long enough to form a judgment on this particular situation, and I am satisfied in my mind that a minority of people—I stress that it is a minority—in the Department are abusing their power. I think that is an intolerable situation and, as a legislator, I will do all I can to stop abuses of power in that way.

But I do think it ought to be brought to the notice of the CAA, because I am quite sure that if the Chairman of the CAA, Dick Smith, were to be interrogated by one of these people he would go off the deep end about it. He would not tolerate it for five minutes. But the very nature of the operation of the CAA means that it would never take on someone like Dick Smith in the same way as it would pick on a poor charter pilot operating somewhere around Australia.

I now turn to the amendments before us today. First of all, there is the business of futures contracts which is quite minor. We then come to flying an unregistered aircraft, which the Opposition takes no exception to. It is quite reasonable that there should be penalties for that. We then get to the point about the issuing of a certificate of airworthiness and a maintenance release. I flag the fact that in the committee stage I will be moving an amendment to this section.

An aircraft operates with two forms of authorisation. Firstly, one has to have an overall certificate of airworthiness. I have forgotten, but I do not think that is time dependent; once the aircraft is registered the certificate of airworthiness is granted and that document is necessary to operate the aircraft. On top of that, a piece of paper called a maintenance release is issued. The general rule for a maintenance release is that it operates for a period of 12 months or 100 hours flying time, whichever expires sooner.

The law has always required that an aircraft must have a valid maintenance release. Either the ground engineer or the pilot taking responsibility for the aircraft, each day it flies, must sight the maintenance release and sign for the aircraft on the maintenance release. The maintenance release contains any special conditions with respect to the maintenance of the aircraft. It always has a running total—the time in airframe hours at which it was issued—and each day, at the end of flying, the number of hours flown has to be entered on it. That is quite proper; we have no quarrel with that. But proposed new subsection 20AA(5) of the Act states:

SPEECH.PARA: An owner, operator, hirer. . . or pilot of an aircraft must not:
(a)operate the aircraft; or
(b)permit the aircraft to be operated;
so as to contravene subsection (3) or (4).

This refers to operating without a certificate of airworthiness or a maintenance release. I think the Government's intention there is very clear. But, since the penalty is mandatory imprisonment for two years, I think the word `knowingly' ought to be inserted so that it reads that an owner, operator, et cetera must not knowingly operate the aircraft. That would be much more appropriate.

PARA.TAB: If I were in the business of hiring aircraft and I hired an aircraft to someone else, it would go out with a valid maintenance release. But, once that aircraft leaves my physical control—it could be hired out from Sydney and it could go to Perth, Darwin or somewhere like that—a person could fly it beyond the terms of the maintenance release, it could go beyond its 100 hours, and the maintenance release would expire. In that circumstance, I think it would be quite wrong to put the owner of the aircraft—who physically could not do anything about it—in gaol for two years. I think a simple amendment there would be in accordance with the Government's wishes.

The next amendment deals with flying an aircraft without a licence. There have been a number of changes in regulations covering that in recent years and, again, we have no difficulty with that. I think the exclusion period after an offence is a good idea. If the Department does get the bad people in the industry, I think those people ought to suffer more than a fine; particularly where they are operating in an irresponsible or reckless way, as some people do.

I, personally, have one case against me at the present time where I view one agency as having operated in a grossly incompetent way with respect to the safety of a maintenance procedure. I think guilty people should be deprived of the right to be authorised by the Department to perform certain tasks—whether it is in the maintenance field or in the operating or flying field.

The exemption from income tax has been waived, and we have no difficulty with that. We then come to currency contracts and the imposition of a statutory lien. I will also be moving an amendment here in the committee stage. I think the imposition of a statutory lien is quite valid for the Department when it is going about its statutory functions of licensing and regulating the industry. If it imposes a fine and it is not paid, I think it is proper that it should take a lien. But we are now dealing with a government business enterprise which is involved in all sorts of other commercial activities. I am unaware of any other body in Australia which can put a statutory lien on commercial activities in order to recover debts. I have a reservation about that being a matter of statute; but it may be that the Government can explain its position a bit more clearly.

This is not something that I am just pulling off the top of my head. If one reads Sections 67 and 69 of the parent Act, one will find that in that legislation the Government differentiates between charges for regulatory and licensing functions and for other commercial enterprises. One clause also says that charges must bear a reasonable relationship to the service provided and must not be a taxing element.

Finally, we come to the amendments to the CAA Act that were passed to us at a late hour last night. In the guise of an environmental heading they provide certain compensatory powers for damage arising from wave vortices. I have no objection on behalf of the Opposition to what is involved there. However, I find that some elements of it are quite unusual, and I will be taking time during the committee stage to go through them in some detail.

It is a discretionary compensation, which is a little unusual because it may or may not be applied. I am interested to know how the CAA, which is underwriting the compensation, will protect itself. Since the amendment is specifically restricted to vortex generation but excludes the effects of vortices on other aircraft in flight, it does have an unusual element to it. I look forward to the explanation by the Government as to why it wishes to do that. I do not anticipate any opposition from this side of the chamber to that section being included in the parent Act.

The final part of the amendments deal with the Federal Airports Corporation. They are really quite simple. They are in two parts and deal with the transfer of Commonwealth land which had been acquired for airport construction in the future to the Federal Airports Corporation, and for the Federal Airports Corporation to develop that land for airport use in the future. The final part is the clarification of the Corporation's liability to pay income tax.
With those few comments I conclude my remarks. I will explore the points that I have foreshadowed in more detail in the committee stage of the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of amendments within this omnibus Bill, the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill 1991. They have been outlined extensively, firstly, in the second reading speech by the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) and, secondly, by Senators Coulter, Parer and MacGibbon in their contributions, so I will not reiterate them. None of them would constitute a major amendment, but as a piece of legislation they collectively make significant changes for the individuals concerned. What is to the nation as a whole often considered to be minor can be very important to the individuals, industries or corporations affected. For that reason I thank honourable senators for their consideration.

PARA.TAB: Two or three specific matters were raised in the second reading debate to which I wish to respond. Most of them will be better dealt with in the committee stage and I will leave those to that time, but there are three particular matters to which I wish to make brief reference.

I was distracted during the best part of Senator Parer's contribution, but I understood him to be expressing concern that the amendments to the Australian National Railways Commission Act 1983 perhaps did not go far enough. At the moment, the Government has considered that issue; it is not the first time that the matter has come before it. The Government does not accept that criticism. We think that it enables AN to enter into bona fide hedge transactions to reduce its risk, but it does not authorise it to go beyond that into more speculative activities. The balance is what the taxpayers would expect the Government to be imposing on a statutory authority with a particular and designated task. I am sure that Senator Parer will continue to monitor that matter as these amendments are implemented, as will the Government. In any event, that is the Government's position on that matter.

Senator Coulter raised a matter which I accept is of importance. In one sense it will come up in the committee stage. There is an important question of principle involved concerning the change in the requirements for disallowance. That is not something that ought be dealt with lightly by the Senate, because the disallowance procedures are important to the Parliament's power of scrutiny. We all know that at the moment that is effectively exercised in the Senate. The Government would not lightly move to change it.

Senator Coulter acknowledged, and it is clearly the case, that the power of the Senate to disallow is not in any way impaired; it is simply a question of changing the time within which that can be exercised and within very clearly defined and circumscribed limits, particularly concerning the problem with the sale of the second carrier.

The sale of the second carrier and the consequent commencement of network competition in telecommunications is dependant on the bidders having certainty about the regulatory regime in which they will be operating. It is an appropriate balance to say that we will provide that certainty to enable that competition within the timetable envisaged, but in a manner that preserves the ultimate authority of the Parliament to disallow the instruments if it is concerned with them. There will be a sunset clause for that section so that it will have no continuing effect.

The last matter I wish to refer to in the second reading debate relates to a point made by Senator MacGibbon. He expressed concern that the Act did not give discretion to the courts with regard to the penalty to be imposed under certain offences. My advice is that the sections concerned have to be read in conjunction with the provisions of section 4 of the Crimes Act 1914, which means that those penalties have to be interpreted as maximum penalties only and that the courts will, as a consequence of the impact of the Crimes Act on this Act, have a discretion as to whether to impose the maximum penalty and to look at the circumstances of the particular case. It would also mean that the court has a discretion to impose a pecuniary penalty instead of the custodial sentence. That is resolved because of the impact of the other legislation.

The other queries which a number of senators raised, in particular towards the end by Senator MacGibbon, will be dealt with in the committee stage. It is more appropriate to deal with them then rather than duplicate the debate now. I thank honourable senators for their essentially positive contributions to the debate. I commend the Bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) agreed to:
That consideration of the Bill in Committee of the Whole be made an Order of the Day for the next day of sitting.
Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991 and raise a number of matters with regard to the proposed guidelines that have been established as far as the hardship test is concerned, particularly as it affects the farm sector. I also want to say that, as far as that sector of the community is concerned, it is indeed a sad day when we have to be here debating this in the way that we are.

PARA.TAB: I want to begin by referring to the industry statement that was brought down last March. If that had been enacted last March instead of coming before us this week in this place, with regard to the changes to sales tax some $200m could already have been saved to the sector in terms of costs and imposts on it.

The other point I raise is in relation to costs and imposts—and it is a position I raised the other day and will continue to raise until something is done about it—of the Commonwealth Development Bank and its lack of access to all credit lines that other banking operations have. It is absolutely crucial that such access be given; it would not cost the Government one cent if in fact the Commonwealth Development Bank was given access to full credit lines and was freed up in that sense so that it could operate properly as a bank. My personal view in the longer term is that, in due course, the Commonwealth Development Bank should be privatised and allowed to operate as such. However, I will not deal with that subject today.

I raise a matter particularly affecting the south-eastern part of Western Australia where I come from—the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs will be looking at this in relation to the drought—where the seasonal conditions and rainfalls for the last two years have been some 60-odd per cent below their normal average. A survey was done of operations in that area, not only concerning the farm sector in isolation but also the small businesses in towns like Esperance, Ravensthorpe, Munglinup and Lake Grace.

It was found in the Ravensthorpe and Munglinup shires that 38 per cent of the debt in that area was held with the Commonwealth Development Bank. To put it very simply, that debt to the Commonwealth Development Bank amounted to just in excess of $200,000 per business operation. If the Commonwealth Development Bank had access to commercial bill roll-over loans, whether rolled over monthly or set at five years which can be done, there is the opportunity to reduce the interest rates on those loans by 5 per cent which, on the average level of borrowing, amounts to $10,000 per property or business. That would be a significant way, without having to go through the process of filling out forms and the trauma associated with it, in which these operations could have an impost removed. I will not use the word `assistance', but those people could have an impost taken off them which other people, using different lines of credit, do not have.

It is not easy to change from the Commonwealth Bank because of the penalties that exist in the system. I believe this would in fact lower their overall costs. When we are talking about hardship, there is much room for a number of things to be done. I emphasise that this would not be like the rural adjustment operation which comes from the public purse, but this would come from allowing full access to credit lines for what is and has been a very large and a very successful banking operation. But with the changes which occurred five or six years ago to the financial arrangements in this country, it is beyond my belief that, in this country, with financial deregulation we have had that financial operator left with limited access to credit lines.

Turning to the hardship provisions, the particular area that concerns me is the working capital component and the way that it is structured. I have to acknowledge that in terms of the correspondence that we have had back from the Minister we have come a long way from where we were a couple of weeks ago. I certainly acknowledge the work that Senator Alston has done in terms of this matter and getting us to this point. One must recognise that the honourable member for O'Connor, Mr Wilson Tuckey, who represents much of the area I have been talking about, also raised a number of these points which have been addressed.

The particular area I want to address concerns the matter of shares and debentures in a public company. I seek clarification of this point for a number of reasons. If one looks at the situation which exists in Western Australia, and I am sure in other States but I am familiar with Western Australia, we find operations such as SBS Rural Ltd and Wesfarmers Ltd and others which do not fit into the cooperative status but which are major suppliers of merchandise or goods used in farming.

Wesfarmers Ltd's main activity, as far as the farming sector is concerned, is that it is a monopoly manufacturer of fertiliser. Many farmers hold very small shareholdings—it can be from $1,000 to $5,000—in that operation, and this is important for two reasons. Firstly, it maintains shareholder control of a major supplier to the agricultural industry. Of course, Western Australia is by far and away the largest user of fertiliser per farming operation or per acre of any of the States. Whilst there are not large dividend returns, it is very important that that control stay in the hands of the users of this product where a monopoly in manufacturing to the agricultural industry exists. There is of course a very small amount used on lawns in Perth and such like, but that would be very insignificant.

I make an appeal to the administrators of the guidelines and to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), who is the Minister at the table—I was hoping that Senator Richardson would be here—that small shareholdings in a public company, such as Wesfarmers Ltd, not be considered readily saleable assets. It is very important from a business point of view that that control in fact stays in the hands of the people who use the product.

The same situation applies to SBS Rural, which is the largest supplier of farming merchandise in Western Australia. It does not deal in anything else, although obviously some people who are not farmers buy its products. It is worth looking at the history of SBS Rural and putting it on the public record. SBS started off in Esperance some 20-odd years ago with a small group of farmers—and I was one of them—who were concerned at the cost of their inputs. We put together what is known as EOPP—Esperance Organised Purchasing Power—which became the basis for the structure of what is known as SBS Rural today. EOPP still operates, and there is a similar operation in Geraldton and another in Albany.

In fact, there is a structure across Western Australia which in essence appoints SBS Rural each year as the agent which supplies these goods and services. This has enormous benefits to the individual users of the product because in essence they control it, both through that membership of the EOPP and, with the floating of the company some two years ago to increase its capital base, by being a shareholder. The majority of people invested somewhere between $1,000 and $5,000. It had nothing to do with investing in a public company, in the true sense of an investment portfolio, but was done for the supply of the required merchandise in terms of the operation of the farms. I would hope, in terms of the guidelines, that some consideration will be given to the situation I have mentioned. It is very important that farmers help themselves. There have been many self-help programs which we have heard about in just over 12 months since I have been in this place.

In many instances the individuals who took out the $5,000, for example, of shares actually borrowed the money to do it because they believed, and they were encouraged by people such as me, that if there were some mode of control over a major supplier and effective competition were kept in the marketplace the cost would be kept down. Of course, that is the name of the game.

On the guidelines, there is one other very important point that I would like to raise in relation to education. I refer to the people who live in isolated areas of Western Australia. I hope that provision can be included in the guidelines so that people who have set aside money for the education of their children, as many have done because they do not have access to public sector secondary education, are not required to use that money for another purpose. They have no option, because of distance, but to work through the private school system. I just happen to be one of those people who have set aside money for the education of their children. I hope that the money that is held in cash reserves designated for education is not included as realisable assets.

I refer to hardship provisions and the issue of working capital. I note what the Minister for Social Security, Senator Richardson, said. On the surface, it looks okay but one always lives with a degree of fear or trepidation when one reads the written word and then one sees what actually occurs when matters get in the hands of the bureaucrats. We have seen this consistently. This is a criticism of the Rural Adjustment Authority. Its interpretation is quite different to what was the intention of the decision makers who passed the legislation at the time. I hope there is some training for the bureaucrats who have the role of determining whether a particular input of working capital is realisable, because I am certain that at times it is not.

On income equalisation deposits, I have no problem with those deposits being nominated as ready, realisable assets, because that is what they are. However, I would caution that such a determination could impact on particular cases in south-eastern Western Australia and, I am sure, on other States. That is the case where operators, because of the drought, have sold stock. They have put that money away in income equalisation deposits for restocking purposes. There has to be some flexibility in the operations of IEDs in those cases. Maybe the guidelines could be written in such a way that, if money has been put away in IEDs for specific purposes, especially for restocking—money raised from the sale of stock—there should be some flexibility in its application.

On these hardship provisions, we intend moving an amendment to remove the two-year period. It seems absolutely ludicrous or unbelievable that we could be sitting here trying to make a judgment that in two years there will not be any hardship. Regardless of whether one has high commodity prices, which have occurred in the past, or low commodity prices, in a country as wide and as broad as Australia there is always some sector, whether it be in fruit growing, dairying, wheat growing, wool growing—and I could run through many more—that is under financial pressure for a variety of reasons. It could well be caused by drought, flood, fire or famine.

I would strongly urge the Australian Democrats to support us in removing the two-year period. Once hardship provisions are in place it is ludicrous for us as decision makers to try to determine that at such and such a date there will no longer be any hardship under those hardship provisions.

There are many ways in which the pressure can be taken off those people who are now suffering from this recession. Much of it has come from the policies and the directions that we have had to put up with from one ex-Treasurer, Mr Keating. Had he been a little more flexible in his application of monetary policy and put a little more emphasis on micro-economic reform and fiscal management, we would not be sitting here debating the way we are today. While there is a world-wide impact of a recession in many countries and low commodity prices, many of the problems today have been engineered by none other than the ex-Treasurer. It will be a very sad day if he ever gets to lead this country, because he proved clearly that he did not have a clue how to manage and run a business. In that period of time, he did his best to send it broke.

I reiterate what I said about the Commonwealth Development Bank and wholesale sales tax on oils and lubricants. Most of the harvest will be off. We will find that from the March statement virtually a full year of operating costs has gone by. If the industry or job statement that the Government brings down tomorrow is going to do any good, it should be acted on immediately and the Government should not wait for another 12 months.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening the Senate is debating the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991. Labor claims to be the party of the battler. Yet its policies have often failed to do much to assist those in need of help. The assumption that the worst off will always do better under Labor is now seen to be untrue. Lower and middle income earners have suffered most from Labor's economic mismanagement, with their real disposable income and their share of the national income reduced. Labor's spending initiatives and redistributive taxation have not brought with them equality or prosperity—only inflation, debt, high interest rates, unemployment and bureaucratic interference.

PARA.TAB: We are debating yet another example of Labor's redistributive taxation and bureaucratic interference in a number of aspects of this social security legislation. The Social Security Amendment Bill we are debating this evening will implement the major part of the Budget announcements in the social security area. The most significant changes include a proposed assets test on the family allowance, changes to the existing family allowance supplement assets test and a new hardship provision on the family allowance supplement. There are many other changes outlined in the Bill, but the major initiatives relate to the family allowance and the family allowance assets test changes and the introduction of hardship provisions.

The family allowance is an income tested payment which used to be known as child endowment and was paid fortnightly to the principal carer of children. It is a payment that recognises the costs of raising children. In 98 per cent of cases the principal carer is the mother, but in the other 2 per cent of cases it is paid to fathers, guardians and even, in some cases, State and Territory juvenile detention centres. In conjunction with the family allowance supplement, it aims to maintain the real value of family payments through indexation as well as keeping it relative to other social security payments.

The family allowance cuts out when family income reaches $62,057 in respect of one child, with the threshold rising by $3,104 for each additional child. The family allowance supplement is paid as an add-on to family allowance to low income working families. Its purpose is to eliminate poverty traps, that is, to ensure that families do not find themselves financially better off being dependent on social security than they would be at work.

Last year many of us had cause to debate the merits of an assets test on the family allowance when the Government proposed in the 1990-91 Budget to impose a ceiling of $300,000. This figure was subsequently raised to $500,000 in the hope of ensuring acceptance. But this was to no avail as it was not ultimately passed by the Senate.

The simple fact is that last year the Government suggested that families with more than $300,000 in assets should not be eligible for family allowance. The opposition to that proposal was so great that the Government took that figure up to $500,000. This Bill now sets the asset test threshold for the payment of family allowance at $600,000. This time we are now back discussing not $500,000 but $600,000.

In the case of rural communities, the asset, typically the family farm, is home, business and income. It is the lot. That is all the farmers have. Very few farmers have any substantial extra assets. The family farm is the only asset. It has been inherited; it has no value. The farmer has no plan to sell it and, in most cases, he did not buy it.

When we go back to these two provisions—$62,000 for the income test and $600,000 for the assets test—the clear inference is that farming assets after debt return 10 per cent. But if we look at the ABARE figures for recent years we find that in 1988-89 ABARE declared that the return on the assets of a farming enterprise was 3.7 per cent. In 1989-90 it was 2.5 per cent and in 1990-91 it was minus 0.3 per cent. Any average of those figures is well below 3 per cent and I remind honourable senators that 1988-89 was a good year. I have received a number of representations from organisations and constituents pointing out what they see as the injustice of the Government's proposals. In particular, I refer to the NFF and also the Victorian Farmers Federation.

I accept the fact that many rural people have assets but they do not have liquidity. They cannot say that they will pay their bills with their stockyard. Perhaps they could pay them with the sale of stock—that is, if they had some stock, or crops, that were of some value. The trouble is that Queensland and perhaps a great deal of New South Wales are experiencing a terrible drought at present. As a result, farmers do not have any crops and they do not have much stock either. The problem is that no money is coming in.

Parents need actual cash to cope with the expenses of raising a family. Until now they have appreciated what has been of some help by the Government to give country children an opportunity similar to that which applies to children who live in the cities. Furthermore, by the very nature of farming, a certain amount of working capital is essential to pay for fuel, seed and fertilisers. It is quite easy, I can assure honourable senators—and I know this from practical experience—to spend tens of thousands of dollars on these items.

The Government has stated that these changes will principally benefit farmers and rural communities. If the Government really wanted to help farmers, small business people and communities in rural areas, because of the severity of the rural downturn and the deterioration in estimated incomes as a result of its economic policies, I believe it should abolish the assets test altogether. I have always believed that families should be tested on their income and not on their assets. I read an article in the Australian yesterday which says, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: It's estimated that between 55,000 and 60,000 commercial farms in Queensland and New South Wales are affected by the drought, and more than 60 per cent have some form of long-term debt.

An article about Phil and Donna Lewis of Max Creek Station, Wyandra, in parched south-western Queensland, whose dreams have gone down the drain, shows a very sad state of affairs. The article says that the crunch comes when the banks review the situation. I have a somewhat similar feeling in regard to our son's property, Ten Mile, in central Queensland;

I know something of what those dear people are experiencing. Articles like that justify my belief that families should be tested on their incomes and not on their assets. I would like to feel that the Government and the coalition would agree with that. I ask honourable senators whether the Government really appreciates the difficulties being experienced by the rural and farming communities.

PARA.TAB: When first introduced in the 1940s and 1950s, child endowment was not assets tested or means tested and neither was the rebate for dependent children. The family allowance was the product of fundamental changes to the child endowment system introduced during the Fraser-Anthony Government days. Its intent was to ensure that those with children were not disadvantaged in the overall structure of the social welfare tax system.

With these current changes, the nature and character of family allowance are being fundamentally changed because, for the first time, a number of people are to be excluded from any entitlement at all. Now it seems that family allowance is seen merely as a welfare measure, put in the same category as unemployment and sickness benefits and the like. Instead, it should be seen as an investment in the next generation of Australians.he Australian Family Association said that family allowances were:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . designed as a social justice payment to assist Australian families who are investing in our future by nurturing children.

Assets testing, like its predecessor means testing, is an attempt to convert a social justice payment into a social welfare payment: one not available because of family status, but because of perceived wealth, or lack thereof. It is an attempt to cast families as social welfare recipients: people who take out of the community when in reality they are net contributors to social welfare.

I can think of few better investments than in the young children of the families of Australia.In our migration program we pay to bring in children from other nations. It would surely be far better for us to support Australian families and to encourage them to bring up Australian children in the great traditions of our national way of life. Indeed, we ought to encourage children to be raised within the traditional family units of our nation where child-care at home is seen as a worthy career and an honoured role. There can be no doubt that a dollar spent on family allowances is a far better investment than a dollar spent on child-care centres. The family is the cornerstone of society.

PARA.TAB: All too often, I regret to say, government policy seems to be directed at, and certainly has resulted in, undermining or even breaking up the family as the fundamental social unit, rather than assisting it in times of stress when family support and security are most needed. The Government has abused the family allowance, firstly, by means testing or income testing it; and, secondly, by making it subject to an assets test. Although the Government's amendment seeks to increase the ceiling, there is no appreciation on the part of the Government as to what the family allowance is and what it means to families throughout Australia.

Indeed, as I said earlier, the Government did not seek to amend its original proposals last year until there was a considerable outcry about the injustice and the insensitivity of these new asset test arrangements, particularly coming as they did in an announcement at a time of a massive rural crisis. I can recall that even some Government members eventually acknowledged that there was a very real problem. The Australian Labor Party member for Grey, Mr O'Neil, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Many farmers might be asset rich but income poor, particularly with this year's rural downturn.
We should remember that he was speaking last year. He went on:
In many cases, people in rural areas will not be earning any income whatsoever and I think this is a complete indictment of this Government.

Nothing has happened to alter the rural situation since the honourable member for Grey made his statement. Indeed, the drought has become worse in many parts of rural Australia, particularly in my home State of Queensland and in New South Wales. I think Western Australia has been more fortunate so far in that it has had good rain and, as I understand it, it will have a wheat crop. Many people in Queensland have not been so fortunate.

PARA.TAB: I suggest that if the Government really wanted to help farmers who have been hard hit by the severity of the rural downturn and by the deterioration in farm incomes as a result of its economic policy, it would not even have thought of introducing a test on the family allowance. I believe that it should have been left just as it was in the days when the Fraser-Anthony Government introduced it. Family allowance is a very important source of income for many farmers—and their wives, of course. Therefore, it is not appropriate to have an assets test which has a very different impact depending upon where people are.

However, there have been proposed changes to the legislation as it was originally drafted. The legislation now includes quite generous hardship provisions. I believe that the assets test has, therefore, been made a little more palatable for farming families, and that enables me to support the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My brief comments this evening will be directed towards the imposition of the assets test on the family allowance and family allowance supplement. I say at the outset that I very seldom speak on social security measures, but as the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991, which puts the assets test on family allowance, will affect people in the country far more than anything else, I have decided briefly to take part in the debate this evening.

PARA.TAB: The family allowance and the family allowance supplement are the major welfare payments—for want of a better word. I have never believed that they were welfare payments; they were just an update of the child endowment scheme where families that had children were rewarded as against families that did not. What was received in child endowment in years gone by and what is received in family assistance now certainly does not reward us too much for having children. I believe the reward in having children is in the children themselves. The welfare payment certainly used to help, and helps quite a few household budgets now. It is the major welfare payment that is left at this stage.

If we were to eliminate this concession—in other words, put an assets test on it—I believe it would be a retrograde step. Even accepting the economic reforms that are being undertaken at the present time, I have some very great concerns, my greatest concern being that the assets test could not have come at a more difficult time. It has been pointed out by other speakers that the assets test has come at a very hard time, for all the reasons that Senator Bjelke-Petersen, Senator Crane and others who have spoken before me have given. We have the worst depression—the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) may want to call it a recession—as admitted to by Mr Kerin in Bangkok—

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Westpac Bank.

—Yes, and the Westpac Bank. It is the worst depression since the 1930s. I think this recession will surpass the one that we had in the 1930s, because in the 1930s people were more self-reliant than they are now. In copping this sort of economic situation, this level of unemployment, people cannot cope as well as they did in the 1930s. I remember talking to my parents about the depression they went through in the 1930s. I believe that they handled that depression far better than people are handling the present situation.

PARA.TAB: Senator Richardson has told us that the assets test will affect only 2 per cent of families with dependent children. Unfortunately, that 2 per cent of families will be the hardest hit in Australia. I know that there may be other measures. Senator Richardson announced measures a few weeks ago by which farmers and others can get certain social security help. The assets test will affect the hardest hit families in Australia. As I said, they have been hit at this time as they have never been hit before.

I accept, although reservedly, that we will eventually take off this assets test. One of the reasons it is hard to accept is that, even though the assets test limit has been put at $600,000, we have an income test limit of $60,000. Senator Richardson has told us consistently that there should be no correlation between the two. Why should there not be a correlation? If there is an income test limit of $60,000 and an assets test limit of $600,000, presumably $600,000 will produce $60,000—in other words, 10 per cent. We are told that there is no correlation. Why is there no correlation? There has to be correlation. We have to look at the two in the same context. That is why my colleague Mr Tuckey in the other place moved an amendment to extend the assets limit from $600,000 to $2m. Farmland returns, on average, about 3.3 per cent. No doubt, that is the figure that Mr Tuckey used to get the $2m.

No-one in the Government wants to believe that there should be a correlation between the two. I am not saying this off the top of my head. If we look at the assets test and incomes test for the age old pension, for instance, we see that a correlation is in place. If we have so much cash in the bank, sitting in a cheque account, not gathering any interest at all, there is a deeming provision. The last I knew, the deeming provision was 10 per cent; it might have been reduced to 9 per cent. In fact, it is about time it was reduced even further. Madam Acting Deputy President, you know about interest rates and the interest that can be earned on deposits in the bank. There is a deeming provision. I fail to understand why the deeming provisions cannot go right across the board.

It may be that if the limit were raised to $2m we need not have an assets test at all. But, if we can have a deeming provision for pensioners and on retired income, we should have it across the board—even though time and time again the Government will say that there is no correlation. We have had hardship provisions introduced into the guidelines—not into the legislation. The hardship provisions have a sunset clause of two years. In other words, we are putting a sunset clause on hardship. Senator Crane made this point very well. Who can sit here and say that there will be no hardship in two years time?

Senator Richardson told us that we can look at it in two years time. The Government of the day can look at any legislation in six months, nine months, two years, three years time or whenever it wants. There does not have to be a sunset clause to do so. Unfortunately, when there is a sunset clause legislation is forced because legislation goes out and new legislation comes in. Things are under pressure. That is why my colleague Senator Alston is moving an amendment to eliminate that sunset clause. No-one can say what sort of conditions we are going to have in two years time.

Hopefully, all of Australia, and especially the rural sector, will have turned around in two years time but, even if it has, there are such things as pocket droughts—as you, Madam Acting Deputy President, would know in Queensland—which can be very isolated. I have seen pocket droughts that have been in a radius of 150 kilometres. It happens. There can be rain shadows that stay the whole year. Apart from that, there could be a hailstorm on a crop; a flood, as mentioned by Senator Crane; and any other major disasters in minor areas that can happen to farmers or anyone else. It is the same story with small businessmen on a very small and isolated scale, because a lot of small businessmen live off farmers. Do not tell me that that is not hardship, because hardship is certainly there.

Also in the guidelines—in whatever form they may be—there will be an exemption on working capital. I am very surprised that our side of politics was able to convince the Government to put it in its guidelines. I commend the Government for taking up Senator Alston's recommendation that working capital not be counted in the assets. I believe it will be very hard to define what working capital is—I have tried to define it before—but in the spirit of the situation I think it can work.

I would like to see the Government look at another measure which I have mentioned in certain quarters. If a family receives a family supplement it is received by the main carer of the children, and in 99 per cent of cases I presume it is the wife. The Government could at lease look at giving the 2 per cent of families that are going to lose it four weeks notice that they are going to lose it. In other words if, after royal assent, they are going to be without that family supplement, they should be paid for four weeks.

This would line up with the measure in this Bill for the four weeks notice of cutting off the family supplement. It resulted from that case in Sydney where a child was killed and the family was getting family supplement and was going to continue to receive it for four weeks. I believe that the four weeks notice could be looked at in this situation, especially as Christmas is coming and these hard-pressed families have to budget to give their children and their family something extra over Christmas.

I will carry on with the line about giving a bit of notice. We had the March statement—and I know I have harped on this for a few months—in which the Government made a lot of noise about what it would do at that time. Certainly, some of those measures were welcome. But here we are, seven or eight months down the track—we now have the legislation in front of us—after the Government told us about what better depreciation schedules we were going to have and the elimination of sales tax at certain points. These families are going to lose the supplement on 1 January, the Bill says. Perhaps the Government could have seen the light and given families a bit more leeway, such as it took for itself in implementing the March statement.

The asset Bill will finally put the test on everything, but one point that stands out is the assets test on isolated children's allowance. I will always work in this place to eliminate it because isolated children, or any children in Australia, have two basic rights: the rights to be looked after in health and education. I support all the points made by colleagues and the amendments that Senator Alston will be moving.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991, introducing as it does a number of changes to the family allowance, is likely to be highly contentious, particularly as many people, like me, were brought up in the days when child endowment—which was the forerunner of family allowance—was available to all families.
—I didn't think you were that old.

—It is surprising, but years fly away with the wings of a dove, I am afraid. The concern that many people will have is that the imposition of an assets test may cause a great deal of hardship to those in this country who are, as the saying goes, asset rich and income poor. In particular, I am thinking of the people in Queensland and New South Wales who live outside the capital cities and who, directly or indirectly, have had their incomes badly affected, not just as a result of this drought but also as a result of the economic policies of this Government which have so clearly and demonstrably failed to achieve any improvement in the lot of ordinary Australians. We are not just talking about farmers; we are not just talking about the small businessmen: we are talking about millions of Australians who live outside the capital cities and who deserve equal respect and consideration by this Government and by this Parliament.

PARA.TAB: I turn to the imposition of the assets test. In the Budget this Government originally proposed that the assets test should be applied at $300,000. It subsequently revised that proposal and suggested that the figure should be $500,000. On both occasions we in the coalition—in the Liberal Party and the National Party—signified to the Government our refusal to agree with such draconian measures. The Government now comes before the Senate recommending that the assets test be applied at $600,000. Were the Government merely offering an assets test alone, I could not in good conscience support the passage of this legislation but, as you said, Madam Acting President, it should be income to which one looks principally and foremost.

I am pleased, however, to see that my colleague the shadow Minister for social security, Senator Alston, has negotiated with the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) a number of important concessions. Foremost among these is the hardship provision which will ensure that, even if families have assets in excess of the $600,000, they will be in receipt of the family allowance if their income falls below the amount of $13,078 per annum, and they have less than $10,000 in cash or stocks and shares in publicly listed companies.

Of course, this is not an ideal situation. I agree with the comments that were made by you, Madam Acting Deputy President, and by my colleague and friend Senator Panizza, in drawing the attention of the Senate to the fact that there seems to be no correlation between the amount of assets, the estimated average rate of return and the income test itself, which stands at $60,000. This is of concern to me. I believe the Government has to recognise that there will always be situations where people may have assets but cannot adequately provide for their families.

I believe that the work done by my friend and colleague Senator Alston, the shadow Minister for social security, in getting the Government to agree to these hardship provisions is a major step forward in ensuring that people are not discriminated against simply because of assets which they cannot sell and which they cannot apply to the benefit of their families. For these reasons, I am pleased to see the package of legislation that will be coming before the Senate. I will be supporting the amendments that the shadow Minister, Senator Alston, will be moving in this place.

The effect, of course, will be to ensure that people who live on farms, for example, have the value of the residence and the associated land removed from the value of the farm before assessing the value of that farm for the purposes of the assets test. This is one of my major concerns and I am pleased to see that it has been answered by the Government in this legislation. It would be wholly iniquitous to include the value of a residence in assessing the value of a farm when the value of a residence in the city is not assessed.

The National Party is concerned to ensure that people who live outside the capital cities get the same treatment as those who live in the capital cities and to ensure that people who live on farms are not discriminated against solely because of the fact that they live on farms.

Another major point that I must make, Madam Acting Deputy President, is that the Opposition will be moving an amendment which will eliminate the two-year provision on the hardship test. That, of course, has been of concern to many of us on this side of the chamber because we recognise that hardship is not limited by the days in a calendar and that, even when this drought lifts, there will still be people in cities and in country areas who will be suffering hardship. We believe that it is ludicrous to impose merely a two-year period on the hardship test. For that reason, I will have great pleasure in supporting the amendment that Senator Alston will be moving.

I turn to the amendments that have been foreshadowed by the Australian Democrats to be moved in the committee stage. I am very pleased to see that Senator Lees has finally arrived in the chamber. I know she spoke in the second reading debate. I intend to make my comments in respect of these amendments now, rather than delay the operations of the Committee by talking at length in the committee stage.

The effect of these amendments, supposedly, is to exempt the whole of the value of a family farm or a small business—and I will come to the definitions of both of those shortly—from the assets test for the purposes of calculation of a person's assets. This creates a certain conundrum, because, if one accepts the fact that we have an assets test and that we have a hardship test, one wonders what is the effect of these amendments.

The effect of these amendments would be to exclude all farmers and all small businessmen from the assets test, except, of course, if they have $600,000 worth of assets, not being their residence, not being their working capital and not being their business. I know very few people who would fall into that situation. I know very few people who would have $600,000 worth of Mercedes. I know very few people who would have $600,000 worth of runabouts. But this would be the effect of these amendments.

For that reason, I cannot really clearly see the logic behind the amendments that will be moved. I suppose it is yet another attempt by the Australian Democrats to move amendments solely for their own political benefit and not for the benefit of the people in question. That brings to me a grave sense of concern and dismay, because our task here should be to legislate for the benefit of the people, not to legislate for the benefit of our electoral prospects. For that reason I will not be supporting those amendments.

I turn now to the definitions and the provisions contained in the amendments proposed by the Democrats, because I think they are quite interesting and also quite badly flawed. For example, the amendment in respect of the assets test for family allowance for primary producers—and this is replicated in the other two amendments in respect of primary producers—is quite interesting. It talks about a person's assets and, of course, the assets in question are those of the primary carer. Amendment 2 states that, where the person has his or her principal home on a farm that is owned by the person, the person's partner, or the person and his or her partner, if the person works in a full time capacity and the whole of the land and so on are used for the purposes of farming, those assets shall be excluded.

Of course, this is rather simplistic. It assumes that all farms are owned by individuals or by partnerships. Of course, they are not. It varies from industry to industry, but many farms are actually held in corporate structures. So we would find a situation where one group of farmers is advantaged because the farm is not held in a company and another group of farmers is discriminated against because the farm is held in a company.

I cannot see the logic or the sense in that and I do not think many other people could either, because there is no logic or sense in it. In fact, it is interesting to note that that clause, that particular condition, is inconsistent with the provision in respect of small businesses because, of course, the amendment proposed by the Democrats talks about a person carrying on a business as defined in subsection 6(1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. We have to have some sort of sense of consistency, and clearly that is not present in these amendments.

My other concern is in respect of primary producers. The requirement is that the person in receipt of the benefit, that is, the principal carer, ordinarily works in a full time capacity as a primary producer on the farm. Madam Acting Deputy President, you would well know that many mothers who live on farms may not necessarily work in a full time capacity as a primary producer. They may, for example, work in an administrative sense. They may solely care for the children. Of course, this amendment is again applying an arbitrary condition which really has no meaningful value, except, of course, seemingly to bolster the electoral success of the Democrats. But it is not going to work.

No member of the coalition will support these amendments. We have looked at them very carefully and we can see how absurd they are. We accept the fact that there is a responsibility on us to legislate in a reasonable and responsible fashion. We believe that the Government has come a long way from its original position in amending the legislation and we believe that the amendment that will be moved by Senator Alston, the shadow Minister for social security, to delete the two-year limit on the hardship test, will also be of considerable importance in bringing this legislation into line.

I support the comments of my colleague Senator Panizza, who said that he hoped that after the enactment of this legislation there would be a period of grace before the Government and the Department cut benefits to some of the people who may be affected, especially as we are coming very close to Christmas. It is unlikely that the Bill, even if it passes here tonight, will receive assent before the end of the month, and so a four-month grace period would quite neatly and, I think, compassionately take those people beyond Christmas and put them in a situation where they can adequately plan and rearrange their budgets.

I hope that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), who is at the table, and the Minister for Social Security, Senator Richardson, will accept the spirit in which this proposal is made. It is my very sincere hope that the Government will show a bit of compassion in line with some of the reasonableness that it has shown in dealing with the proposals that we have made to it which have ultimately been accepted.

Finally, we hope that the Government will recognise that hardship tests must be put in place in respect of other legislation that bestows on people a benefit which is tested on the basis of assets. We do not believe that we can have a situation where people can be discriminated against solely on the basis of their assets when those assets may not necessarily be realisable. We believe that it is incumbent on this Government to show a little of the humanity about which the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, so frequently speaks but which he has yet to demonstrate adequately to the people of Australia.

I conclude by saying that this Bill is not entirely satisfactory to many people on this side, but we are pleased to see that the Government has come a long way. We are very pleased to see that our efforts and our persistence on behalf of millions of Australians will be paying off here this evening.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3), which has been of great concern to many of us and also to the survival of a great many Australian families who, in turn, are an essential part of our long term national export industry. I refer to the effect of the new assets test on the family allowance, and the adequacy of hardship provisions to enable farm families to continue receiving this necessary assistance. As a Liberal senator for Western Australia, I believe that it is essential that this legislation be framed and administered so as not to exclude a section of the community that is recognised as being rich in unrealisable and wealth producing assets and so often poor in income. My colleague Senator O'Chee has very clearly outlined exactly that problem. For 1990-91, the return on farm assets was a mere 0.3 per cent.

PARA.TAB: I make no apology for saying that if, through indifference, this Government were to fail to provide adequate hardship provisions, it would be a tragedy not only for so many individual farm families but also for our economic future as our export earning rural base contracted, and contracted even further. This country simply cannot allow our farmers to walk off the land at a greater rate than they have already been doing.

It is relevant to this debate to note that the wheat harvest for 1991-92 anticipated by the Australian Wheat Board is 10.6 million tonnes, down from a 1980s average of 15.5 million tonnes. Were it not for the 4.7 million tonnes from Western Australia, there would be great trouble in servicing our traditional markets. The last thing that Australia can do in a time of massive rural depression is prevent farmers from putting in their next crop. This is why the guidelines for hardship provisions are of such critical importance.

I note from the guidelines released by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) last week that amounts of liquid cash in the accounts of such unincorporated businesses as farms are to be exempt from the assets test where they are required for `essential and usual expenditure' in operating a farm or business.

It is important that the word `essential' not be defined in a manner that would in effect hamper normal farm operations. I do not believe that it is feasible to strike upon some arbitrary amount as necessary working capital, and I have been concerned that an attempt to do so will result in injustice to grain growers in particular.

While it has been stated that the cost of planting a crop averages at $100,000, I would submit that $250,000 could be a more realistic figure for the wheat belt of Western Australia, just as $40,000 may be sufficient working capital for a beef property. Averages, however, cannot take into account the fact that a large operation supporting several families could be looking at $750,000 as the cost of putting in the next crop. These costs, indeed, can vary from shire to shire, with different soil qualities requiring greater expenditure.

At a time of rural recession, the family allowance can have great importance in balancing the family budget. It is that particular area that we must not lose sight of, because too few Australians are aware that the annual amount of $2,254 as family allowance for four children under 16 is greater than the $2,100 that is the net value of production per farm for 1991-92. That is a particularly significant figure, because it demonstrates the importance of what we are talking about here tonight in respect of family allowance.

It demonstrates that the rural families who are concerned about this, and their members of parliament who are equally concerned about the ramifications, are not just whistling in the wind about the possibility that they could have lost family allowance. To think that the small amount of $2,100 is the net value of production per farm is very tragic. It is also as well to remember that the purchasing power of farmers is expected to be 5 per cent of its value three years ago. This is not the time to be depriving farm families of one source of income when in 1990-91 a record $34.5m was paid to Western Australian farmers through the Rural Adjustment and Finance Corporation.

The problems of farm families and the rural economy have a very deep regional impact. It is no accident that, of 21 offices of the Department of Social Security in Western Australia, the one showing the worst rise in unemployment registrations in the 12 months to October was Albany, which serves an essential farming area. That is of great concern to many of those rural families. They are facing not only great hardship but also more and more unemployment. Therefore, it should be of major concern to all of us that the unemployment rates are rising in these areas, and we have to make sure that the impact of this depression will not be felt as badly as it might otherwise be. An 85 per cent rise in those registered for Jobsearch allowance and Newstart, compared with the State-wide average rise of 53 per cent, really tells its own story.

I also remind the Senate that farmers do not look on the family allowance as a welfare payment, and nor do we. We have never looked on it as a welfare payment. It was intended in 1976 as a measure of horizontal equity to recognise some of the extra cost involved in rearing the next generation of Australians. That is the way it should remain. Perhaps it is inevitable in the time of deepening economic crisis, otherwise known as a depression, that we are currently going through that the family allowance must be withdrawn from those who do not need it—or who need it rather less than their neighbours. But I certainly would not put farming families in that category.

It is unfortunate that it has been converted into an effective welfare payment in a gradual and indirect manner, with an income test in 1987 presaging an assets test. I would strongly oppose any future move to restrict the eligibility of family allowance to the level of the Jobsearch allowance, unless the Government had the honesty to redefine the whole nature of the payment. An income test of $62,000 approximates two modest incomes; it is certainly not overgenerous. The test of these hardship provisions is that they should not result in the withdrawal of necessary support from families who require it.

The coalition has successfully sought from the Minister an assurance that documentation of actual working capital should involve no more than a statement of the previous year's expenditure, with the recognition that usual expenses may not always be easily identified. I think there is now a recognition, since we have pushed the issue, that these things cannot be hard and fast and that there has to be some latitude. Appeal provisions will be safeguarded through the normal procedures, with ultimate recourse to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

While these assurances represent an important gain for hard-pressed farm families, it is not, however, good enough that these hardship provisions are to apply for only two years. It is for that reason we have sought, and now gained, an agreement from some people that this should be put up as an amendment. We hope that the Government and the Australian Democrats will now see the wisdom of what our amendment really seeks to do: to wipe out that two-year proviso from the hardship provisions. It is not adequate to say that things will be different in two years and that the benefits will be chopped off. We are really saying that we must leave the provision open-ended and not put that two-year limit on the benefit.

I am aware that Senator Lees is very familiar with this legislation. We are on the same committee. I hope that Senator Lees will see the problems associated with this and the wider economic problems. I am aware that the Democrats amendments go much further. The problem that we have is that we must look at whether we all cut off this benefit lock, stock and barrel in two years or make sure it is extended.

This may be considered a reasonable time frame for a recovery from a recession which, even the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) in more candid moments has conceded, is the worst depression since the 1930s. Only today the Westpac Bank has come out and agreed with him. Moreover it is sadly true that, while sections of the economy may pick up in time, the rural sector has no such assurance through the effects of drought and commodity prices.

Madam Acting Deputy President, you eloquently went through the problems associated with drought that are being experienced in your own State of Queensland and in many parts of Australia. The drought affected areas are certainly not going to be looking down the barrel of a quick pick up in the next couple of years. The two-year limitation should, therefore, be removed as it is very foolish to anticipate that many farming families will not need to have recourse to hardship provisions over the longer term. Without these provisions, as we have made clear, this legislation will be draconian and highly unacceptable.

Other aspects of this Bill have the support of the coalition. I welcome the increase in the child disability allowance to its 1987 level and the extension of the $4.30 fortnightly increase to those receiving the new youth disability supplement. In the inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs into accommodation and employment of the disabled, it was made clear that the additional care required by young disabled people at home is quite significant and considerable.

The coalition does, however, oppose the spending of an extra $9.3m in 1992-93 through the reduction in the period for rental assistance from 26 weeks to 18 weeks. This does nothing more than increase the rate of this particular benefit at a time when rentals are in a depressed state. I would seriously question an apparent philosophy that encourages rental over home ownership as we do not provide welfare beneficiaries with help towards their mortgages. It could be argued that we are subsidising the providers of rental accommodation. In the context of legislation that seeks to achieve savings, it is inappropriate for this kind of generosity at public expense where real need for change cannot be demonstrated.

Altogether, the real impact of this legislation should mean a net rise in spending of about $60m in 1992-93, its first full year of operation. While the coalition is opposed to only one of the spending initiatives, the onus comes back on this Government to ensure that these massive amounts of public money are not misspent as we have been seeing through a number of questions from Senator Patterson this week.

I think the Minister was advised of some of the deplorable rip-offs. From an example in a letter that was sent to him, only yesterday the Minister was forced to concede that at least $23m in welfare benefits paid to immigrants through failure of families to provide promised support was not recoverable. That $23m is a little less than the $25m that will be saved in 1992-93 through the operation of the family allowance assets test. Had the Department been only a little more vigilant and made sure that it had not paid out that money, we would not be having some of the problems we are having today with balancing the books.

It is an indictment of welfare and immigration policies that essentially worthless undertakings of support are made under the family reunion scheme, with the newly arrived family member applying for the special benefit within days of arriving in Australia. I was always led to believe that the restrictions were very tough and that people did have to provide the support they offered. Quite clearly, from what we have seen in recent weeks, that is not so. These cases amount to deliberate fraud. A case has been described of a person who was able to receive this benefit on arrival and use the money to visit Sri Lanka. While the benefit was then cancelled, it was renewed on that person's return to Australia. We did not learn anything from the whole exercise.

The Minister was advised of this, as in so many other examples of social security rip-offs, in a resignation letter of an employee of his Department dated 21 August. If the Minister actually read the letter, we might ask what action he has taken. If he has not been shown the letter, he should be asking for a copy of it from his Department. Australians who lose their family allowance through the new assets test will not be impressed by stories of couples who received single rate benefits when clearly living in de facto situations.

In today's society, with so many Australians genuinely unable to survive without welfare, it is not funny to learn about the woman who got the sole parent pension claiming separation because she and her partner slept on different sides of the sheet. It would be funny if it were not so serious. Other people are deprived of benefits when people are ripping off the system, and ripping it to shreds. Targeting of welfare is supported strongly by the coalition. However, any examples of this lax administration that amounts to the condoning of fraud are absolutely unacceptable. This Government has a very clear responsibility to try a great deal harder in this area. I hope that it does it sooner rather than later.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3). I agree with some aspects of this Bill. One of those aspects was mentioned a moment ago. That related to the increase that is proposed in the child disability allowance, though I believe that is very inadequate. It is proposed to restore the child disability allowance to the same value it had in real terms when introduced in 1987.
