Of course, it goes without saying that since that time the child disability allowance has reduced in value and those who were entitled to that allowance have had their money stolen from them by this Government.

PARA.TAB: I want to address my remarks to the question of family allowances. I do so in the context that, as I understand it, the Senate wishes to have the second reading stage of this Bill completed tonight. Therefore, I shall be short. I see the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) nodding away, and I undertake to the Senate to be short. Senator Knowles has pointed out, and I have pointed out time and time again in this place, that the family allowance is not a social welfare measure; yet Senator McMullan in the second reading speech says that the family allowance is the only major social security payment not subject to an assets test.

The family allowance is not a social security payment. It is part of the tax transfer system which recognises that a family with dependent children at any level of income has more costs and pays more indirect tax than does a family without dependent children. I believe that we should remind the Government what the spokesman on social security said in 1976 when the old tax rebate system was abolished and cashed up into the family allowance.

The then spokesman for social security, former Senator Grimes, said at that time—and he repeated it at the tax summit—that family allowances were a tax transfer measure. He indicated quite clearly that they were not a social security measure. Now we have—possibly for the first time in print—a Government Minister saying that they are, despite the fact that at the Estimates Committee hearing that same Government Minister had generally agreed with what Senator Grimes had said. If there is to be any credibility allowed to the Government, surely it should stand up for what it said previously when the tax rebate system was abolished. If we had known then what we know now there would have been an enormous outcry against the abolition of tax rebates for children.

At the time—I am talking about 1976—I agreed with it. I remember standing in the old Parliament House agreeing with the proposition that the money should go directly to the mother, who is generally the carer of children for the purposes of family allowances. I also agreed that the research had shown that most of the tax rebates for children went into the hip-pocket of the husband. What we were really doing then was taking the tax rebates for the children out of the hip-pocket of the male taxpayer and putting them into the purse of the mother. I agreed with that, but I warned that, unless it was indexed, an enormous injustice would be perpetrated against the mothers of Australia; and that is what has happened.

At that time it was not the Government's money; it was the husband's money. Through the legislation which abolished the tax rebate system and transferred the money to family allowances, it was taken out of the back pocket of the husband and put into the mother's purse. Since that time, the Government has stolen much of this money out of the purses of the mothers. Since that time, the true value of the family allowance has been cut by approximately one-third so that in 1991 the real value of the family allowance is, on average, only two-thirds of the value of the original 1976 allowance. If that is not daylight robbery, I have never seen it.

That is what has happened because of the failure of the Government to index that allowance. Yes, it has indexed the allowance now, but from a low base. Still the situation occurs where the money is being purloined by the Government out of the purses of the mothers, to the extent that the Government is stealing $16.32 per fortnight from the purse of a mother with two children. From the purse of a mother with four children, the Government is taking $50 every fortnight—$49.60 to be exact. That is what the Government is stealing out of the purses of the mothers every single fortnight. It should be ashamed of that.

Now the Government is getting to the mothers on the land—the farmers and the families in distress. The situation has been described in this chamber by Senator Lees, Senator O'Chee and a number of other honourable senators. Senator Alston and others have indicated their concern as to what is happening out in the bush. We all know what is happening out in the bush. I know because I have relations on farms.

One of them came down from Senator Bjelke-Petersen's area in Queensland. He grows strawberries—or used to—in the Lockyer Valley. Because of the drought it is a bit like a dust bowl up there. The farmers are in dire straits and a large number of others are in dire straits. Yet this Government comes in here and refuses to recognise that family allowances are not a social security payment. In fact, it not only refuses to recognise that they are not but also says that they are social security payments and then big-heartedly says, `We will introduce some hardship provisions'. I remind the Senate that those hardship provisions will not be triggered for many affected farmers until they sell the farm. I think that is most disconcerting.

I come back to the principle of the matter. If the Government has any principle at all, it ought to stand up for what it has said consistently about family allowances—that they are part of the tax transfer system. If it does not stand up for that, let Government members get up in here and say that they were deceiving the electors by maintaining that it was not a social security payment but, in fact, a tax transfer system. That is the issue with which we are faced. I know we have faced that situation previously, but I believe that that is the situation we face, in principle, with regard to this Bill.

I limited myself to speaking for 10 minutes, and I have now gone for 12 minutes. I hope there will be another opportunity—undoubtedly there will be occasions next year—for us to deal with this matter at greater length. I believe it needs to be dealt with at greater length as there is a very major question of principle involved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine made the statement that the hardship clauses will not be triggered until the farm is sold—
—I said `for some'.

—The fact that they will not be triggered for some until the farm is sold is of great concern to me. When we come to the committee stage of the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991, I will be most interested to hear his case to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) and the response that the Minister gives. I followed what Senator Harradine had to say closely and I felt that I should make that comment.

PARA.TAB: Tonight we are once again debating Budget decisions. There are five dot points to be addressed. I will speak only to two of them because the others are self-explanatory. Those dot points are: firstly, the introduction of an assets test for the family allowance, which is something totally new to Australia; secondly, the introduction of a family assets test for family allowance supplements; thirdly, an increase of $2.15 in the child disability allowance; fourthly, a $200 up-front education payment for sole parents undertaking general education who are eligible for Austudy supplement, with the presumption that the $200 will assist them to start their education; and fifthly, an attempt to bring independent young persons—that is a nice way of saying `homeless youth'—into the Austudy entitlement. The Minister calls them independent 15-, 16- and 17-year-olds. What on earth is he talking about? I would say that they are still very young children.The Minister is just making himself feel good by calling what are really homeless youth, independent youth. Of course we all remember the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that by 1990 no child would be living in poverty.

As I said, I will deal with only two of these areas because the others are self-explanatory. I would like to start with the assets test for the family allowance. The family allowance is described by the Government in the second reading speech as the only major social security payment not subject to an assets test. I do not believe that, just because the family allowance is handled by the Department of Social Security, it is a social security payment. We know that many years ago a Liberal government and the conservative parties brought in the family allowance in the form of child endowment. The government of the day said to the taxpayer that this payment was a refunctioning of tax because of the recognition that children are a great cost to a family. If a couple has children, they are doing something for the benefit of Australia. This is apart from anything else, such as the joy that children bring to families.

The Liberals have never considered that children are a luxury or that parents should be completely exempt from tax relief. But this is the way that this Government sees it. The first thing the Government did was to introduce not only an assets test but an income test on the family allowance. Before it did all that, it commissioned Bettina Cass to bring forward a report to recommend what should be done with regard to the family allowance. But Bettina Cass did not bring forward the report that the Government thought she would. Indeed, she said that, for both horizontal and vertical equity, the family allowance should not have an income test or an assets test placed on it. It was acknowledged that, irrespective of what income bracket couples are in, the cost is greater if one has children.

As I said, Bettina Cass presented this report to the Government. But the Government did not like the report. It washed its hands of it and wasted taxpayers' money because it had already made up its mind what it was going to do. It was sheer hypocrisy for the Government to commission a report like that because it had no intention at any stage of taking note of the report unless it came down the way it wanted. Of course, it then could have pointed to the report and said, `We have had this report from Bettina Cass and that is why we are introducing an incomes test and an assets test'. The Government first introduced an income test and it is now going for an assets test.

It may be argued that the some people—for example, the Prime Minister's mates, such as Bondy, Packer, Skase and all the rest of them—should not perhaps claim a family allowance for their children. But they pay their taxes and, even if they have very large incomes, their children are an additional cost. I believe that they should be entitled to get this allowance on the grounds of vertical equity. Many people say, `No, this is not so'. I believe that they would be right if it were a social security payment. But because historically it is not really a social security payment but, rather, a transfer of tax, I believe that even they would be entitled to it. That is one way of viewing family allowance; it is the way that I view it.

I will now come to the assets test. The Government has admitted that this test will disadvantage a whole group of people that it does not really intend to be disadvantaged. But because of its ideology, it has gone ahead with it anyway. We have the situation now where the assets test will indeed disadvantage quite considerably the farming community and lower income groups.

We heard Senator Lees, Senator Bjelke-Petersen, Senator Harradine and many of my other colleagues say how bad it is in the rural community at the moment. Senators cannot go around any State in Australia doing their job without recognising the tremendous hardships

SPEECH.PARA: that the rural community is facing. Farmers do have very large assets. They only have to own a small bit of dirt or borrow from a bank for their asset to be considered valuable.

PARA.TAB: It is very difficult for members of the farming community not to say that their land is of value. It is of considerable value if they have had to borrow against it. Farmers wishing to get a loan hope that the banks will consider their land a pretty valuable asset. So these days they cannot really claim that land against which large loans have been taken out and in respect of which the banks have given a certain value is not of any great value.

It is only because of a considerable amount of pressure that Senator Richardson has finally come forward with details of hardship clauses. In Senate Estimates Committee C, I questioned Senator Richardson on the hardship clauses. I asked what was entailed when the Government says that a farmer with certain liquid assets would be exempt from the family allowance assets test.
Debate interrupted.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—Order! It being 7.30 p.m., under the sessional order I put the question:
That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 24 September 1991:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the failure to obtain funding in this country for clinical trials of a `super' sunscreen derived from coral on the Great Barrier Reef and which its developers say could revolutionise skin cancer protection, what final opportunities in the form of loans or grants are available so that products such as the sunscreen may further be developed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator's question consists of a number of parts, the answers to which are as follows:

PARA.TAB: The Ultra Violet blocker has been jointly developed by the Australian Institute of Marine Science (AIMS) and ICI (Australia) as the commercial partner. It is a synthetic analogue of a coral-derived natural product. The chemical can be synthesised on a commercial scale and has undergone extensive evaluation as both a skin care product and in paint and plastic protection applications. It has world-wide patent protection.

The next stage of testing involves clinical and associated tests on humans. These are required to provide data so that the chemical can be assessed for safety and efficacy by drug regulation authorities before it can gain marketing approval. Only if it gains marketing approval will commercial production proceed. In Australia the Therapeutic Goods Authority has responsibility for giving this approval. Approval for commercial release in other markets is given by national regulatory bodies, for example, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in the United States.

Clinical trials are both expensive and extensive involving the testing of many people and taking considerable time and money. However, it is not only adequate resources that are important. The commercial experience is that a major international company already involved in marketing of UV-blockers is essential to commercial success.

ICI (Aust) has recently sold its Family Health Division (FHD) to Colgate-Palmolive. FHD was the area of ICI (Aust) involved in the development of the sunblocker. The sale has meant that ICI (Aust) are unlikely to have the resources to pursue the sunblocker's further development. AIMS is actively pursuing all aspects of development of a final product including finance, chemical trials and commercial partner or partners. It is my understanding that there is a definite potential to raise the necessary funding in Australia but I stress that this only one part of the necessary action.

In answer to the other part of the honourable Senator's question the Government has a range of programs to support industrial R&D in Australia. These include the 150% Tax Concession for R&D, the Grants for Industrial Research and Development Scheme and the National Procurement Development Program.

Other Government initiatives are aimed at encouraging the development of strong links between industry and the research community. External earning targets of 30% have been set for the major Commonwealth research organisations: CSIRO, AIMS and ANSTO. A major new initiative has been the Cooperative Research Centre program. This program brings together researchers from industry, the Universities and public research organisations in centres of excellence in research.

A sunblock used in current products is not considered as a pharmaceutical. However, as this chemical is a new chemical entity it is likely to be treated as a new therapeutic entity by most regulatory authorities. It could therefore be thought of as a `pharmaceutical'. Pharmaceutical companies undertaking R&D in Australia may be eligible to participate in the Pharmaceutical Industry Development Program (Factor F).

The Government does not make direct grants or loans to private companies to commercialise the results of R&D. It believes that private companies are best placed to make decisions on the commercial worth of any new product, and that such decisions should be left to these companies.

The Government supports a number of initiatives that provide finance for innovative companies such as the Management Investment Company Scheme, the Australian Investment Development Corporation and the Commonwealth Development Bank. However, these organisations operate autonomously from Government and their decisions on lending are based on specifically commercial and economic criteria.
The Government provides supplementary support to business through the National Industry Extension Scheme (NIES), a joint Commonwealth-State/Territory initiative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 8 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the USSR's initiative of the fast tracking of free trade zones, especially in the Pacific ports of Nakhodka and Vostochny, where multiple incentives are in place for trade with foreign companies:
(1) What action is the Commonwealth Government taking to take advantage of these incentives.

(2) With the multiple benefits and the flow-on to be enjoyed from trade with the huge Soviet market, does the Government offer financial and/or technical assistance to Australian companies wishing to trade with the USSR.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Australian Senior Trade Commissioner in Moscow has visited these free trade zones, established good relations with its managers, and alerted Australian companies to the existence of the zones.

The Government, through the Australian Trade Commission (Austrade), has been actively involved in promoting Australia's trade interests in the Soviet Far East (SFE). This has included a number of trade visits to the region as well as the successful Australian Trade Exhibition in Vladivostok last year. The Senior Trade Commissioner visits the SFE every three months, and has recently appointed a trade correspondent in Vladivostok to provide trade and economic information to the Senior Trade Commissioner, develop programs, and provide interpreting and other services for Australian business visitors to the SFE.

(2) The economic and political crisis in the Soviet Union has resulted in a substantial decline in Australia's bilateral trade with the Soviet Union at the present time. The lack of any clearly defined division of economic powers between the central authorities and republican governments have created an extremely uncertain trading environment, which may take some time to recover.

To support Australian exporters, the Government has underwritten two credit lines with the Soviet Union through the national interest provisions of the Austrade Act, which is administered by the Export Finance and Insurance Group (EFIG). The first is for a $A100 million 2-year credit for grains, and the second is for a $A400 million 240 day rollover credit to support Australia's traditional commodity exports to the Soviet Union. Australian exporters interested in pursuing trade opportunities in the Soviet market can avail themselves of the services of the Senior Trade Commissioner in Moscow, and the full range of services provided by Austrade.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 9 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the research paper The Science and Technology sector in W.A., produced by Murdoch University's Institute for Science and Technology Policy, which draws attention to the lack of research and development funding and resourcing in Western Australia, are the claims made in the report accurate and will any action be taken to redress the claimed shortcomings.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The claims made in this report regarding the proportion, and per capita expenditure by the Commonwealth on R&D to WA are of the right order.
Commonwealth policies for research and development are developed on the basis of national needs and opportunities.

The location of institutions will reflect decisions on the appropriate site for individual institutions at the time they were established, subject to review by the agencies from time to time. Public sector research agencies, such as CSIRO, allocate their funds according to the priorities which are set by their Boards.

Research granting bodies such as the Australian Research Council, the National Health and Medical Research Council and the Rural Research Corporations, allocate their funding on a competitive basis to the best researchers according to the selection criteria determined for individual schemes. Western Australian researchers receive funding through these schemes.

The Cooperative Research Centres are also allocated on a competitive basis. While none of the 15 Cooperative Research Centres selected in the first round were located in Western Australia, in the second round, six of the shortlisted 32 centres are located in Western Australia.

The role of State Governments in science and technology policy development has been considered recently by the Australian Science and Technology Council in Research and Technology: Future Directions. This report was tabled on October 17, 1991.

That report made the point: ``In a country as large and sparsely populated as Australia, the combination of funding and critical mass considerations means that there cannot be a strictly equitable distribution of national research facilities. The location of many such facilities is not as important as fostering more extensive and effective linkages between users and performers, and between performers engaged on similar projects, wherever they are.''
However, the report is timely in that it raises matters that should be considered in the White Paper on Science and Technology, due to be tabled next May.
